column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Clashes between self-defence groups and MINUSCA elements. No casualties reported.
Armed men attacked and tortured a man, suspected of being part of an armed group.

Looting: 6 suspected LRA fighters ambushed a group of 19 people, including men, women, and children, who were fishing on the Sorongou River. The 6 assailants, all male, spoke Zande and Acholi. They looted smoked fish and 00 hunting cartridges from the fishermen.
Security Measures: A curfew was declared by armed groups on the PK 3 site. Fines are imposed on those who do not comply with the measure.
Looting: An NGO vehicle was seized by armed men.
A man was attacked with a machete along the Bambari - Alindao axis (PK8).
Clashes between armed groups were reported. Houses were burned and goods were looted.
Clashes between armed groups were reported. Houses were burned and goods were looted.
Clashes between armed groups were reported. Houses were burned and goods were looted.
Clashes between armed groups were reported. Houses were burned and goods were looted.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: As a further reprisal, armed men attempted to attack the refugees' camp at the Catholic church. The attack was crushed by MINUSCA forces.
As a reprisal of the February, 1st murder, armed men killed a person beloining to the opposing ethnic group.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 05 February. MNLC members killed a woman in Begatara, on the Bossangoa road.

column9: Farmers (Central African Republic); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: 05 February 2018. An LRA group, containing women and children, ambushed a group of women in their fields in Koumboli. The combatants abducted a girl.
Clashes between armed groups: toll unavailable.
The village of Wanga was attacked by armed men: one dead and one wounded.
Armed men attacked the Derbissaka village: 5 dead and one wounded.
Clashes between armed groups: 2 dead (1 civilian) and several wounded.
Looting: LRA men attacked 9 hunters, taking cassava, smoked fish, meat and ammunition. No reported injuries.
Clashes between armed groups: toll unavailable.

Looting: An armed LRA group composed of men, women, and children looted rice, peanuts, and cassava from a storage building in a field, near Mboki, CAR. They wore military and civilian clothing. The owner of the field was able to escape after observing the group.
12 adults were abducted from the communities of Ngui 1 and Ngui 2, CAR. They were later released , but the child, a 12-year-old boy, remains in captivity.
Armed men attacked herders. One wounded.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 2 Western journalists were severely beaten up by ex-Seleka men after filming dead bodies along the river.

An LRA group composed of men, women, and children ambushed 7 people on 3 motorcycles. The assailants looted the motorcyclists of their goods, including clothes and money. The LRA group released 4 of the 7 travelers, but abducted the 3 others, all men.
Looting: Over January-June 2018, reports of at least monthly incidents of lootings by the Siriri coalition in the Amada-Gaza, Mambere-Kadei, area.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: The killing of a young trader by robbers triggered intense demonstrations against MINUSCA's inactivity. Protesters blocked several streets in the city.
An armed group killed a refugee in Bria which triggered a tense situation among armed groups in the city.
A group of women were taken hostage and raped by a local armed group on 17 February, according to ten survivors who arrived at Bossangoa Hospital for emergency medical care.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: 110 people were abducted and 1 killed by Bahar's MPC. They were freed on 19, February.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: A 32-year old woman was physically attacked by a Km5 self-defense element in Bangui.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 18 February. MNLC forces led by al-Katim looted five civilians of their agricultural products and threatened to kill them in Toulmbo (no coordinates available; assumed to be in Paoua based on area of MNLC presence).

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 18 February. The MNLC attacked Benambouna (no coordinates available), located on the Bossangoa road 20 km from Paoua. The perpetrators killed an elderly man and child, forced two women to carry out work for them, and 'ill-treated' two other women.
19 February 2018. An unidentified armed group clashed with an unspecified ex-Seleka group in Pambayamba. The clash resulted in four fatalities.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: ""One INGO staff member was kidnapped and held for three days by the Front Populaire pour la Renaissance de Centrafrique (FPRC). A ransom was demanded for the release of the staff member and it was paid, however, it is not clear whether it was a family member or another individual or entity that paid for his release.""

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: A 40-years old woman was allegedly beaten with sticks by policemen following the incrimination of his son and her repeated efforts to support his cause, leaving her injured.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 20 February. A Fulani militia attacked a MINUSCA convoy 37 km south of Grimari. One peacekeeper was injured and five militia members were killed.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 20 February. MNLC combatants killed a 15 year-old and abused his father in Korozian (coordinates are approximate; based on UNICEF map), Paoua.
Armed men raided the Bekoro village: one wounded.
Three people were wounded by gunshots following the incursion of armed men in the Koraian village. 6 people kidnapped and 150 houses were burned.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Two self-defense groups (""Force"" and ""You, le Geant"") clashed following a moto theft. Three dead. Including one from ""You, le Geant"" men.
Youth in Bria demontrated in support of peace.
Displacement: The Ngberehou village was attacked by armed men causing displacement but no mentioned injury.
Armed men raided the city: 5 dead and several wounded.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 23 February. An Anti-Balaka group ambushed a MINUSCA convoy in Banda-Deka. MINUSCA returned fired and the perpetrators fled. One peacekeeper was injured.
Self-defense groups in PK5 clashed: 7 people died
Between 23/02 and 27/02, recurrent clashes were reported in Karama and Bandadeka. Recorded 2 events for each location.
Armed men opened fire on two civilians: one severely wounded.
Between 23/02 and 27/02, recurrent clashes were reported in Karama and Bandadeka. Recorded 2 events for each location.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-); Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Suspected MPC ambushed a convoy of state officials and aid workers in Boguila, Markounda prefecture. The convoy was led by an NGO vehicle (Bangui Sans Frontiere). 6 killed among the state officials and BSF vehicle burnt down.
Armed men killed two couples.
Between 23/02 and 27/02, recurrent clashes were reported in Karama and Bandadeka. Recorded 2 events for each location.
Between 23/02 and 27/02, recurrent clashes were reported in Karama and Bandadeka. Recorded 2 events for each location.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: MINUSCA forces opened fire on armed men: 5 wounded.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 25 February. Twenty-two men were abducted by the UPC in the Mingala area. The abductees were subjected to sexual violence and assaults while they were held at a make-shift UPC prison.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 26 February. MNLC forces attacked Beboye (Beboi) 4, Paoua. The group fired at the local population, shooting one man in the leg. The assailants then looted livestock and a shop.

An LRA group armed with AK-47s attacked civilians in Yalinga, CAR. The group was composed of men, women, and children who spoke Acholi, Sango, and Lingala. The LRA group set 19 homes on fire, abducted 4 people, and injured 3 others.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 27 February. Anti-Balaka forces attacked a MINUSCA convoy in Bangassou. MINUSCA returned fire and the attackers fled.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 27 February. An Anti-Balaka group ambushed a MINUSCA convoy 28 km south of Alindao. MINUSCA returned fire. One peacekeeper was injured during the clash.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 27 February. A MINUSCA team, responding to an earlier attack in Banda-Deka, was attacked by Anti-Balaka forces in Banda-Deka. Four peacekeepers were injured during the clash.
Since 20/02, clashes were reported at Gounomon (17 km from the Alindao-Mingala axis). Toll unknown.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 28 February. MNLC members shot and injured a man in his field in Bebounda, Paoua.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 28 February. The MNLC attacked three people in Bezoye 3 (Bozoy 3). The perpetrators also stole cattle.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 28 February. The MNLC attacked Kebe, wounding two civilians. The perpetrators also looted the town and burned down one home.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: UPC armed men occupied the Rafai sub-prefecture and the Guerinda commune, advancing towards Bangassou.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 01 March. The MNLC abducted six women from the PK 5 neighborhood in Paoua. The perpetrators released the women later that day and instructed them to tell the locals to turn their weapons over to the MNLC.
Clashes between armed men reported In the Datoko village (7 km south of Alindao): 6 dead and one wounded.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 03 March. An Anti-Balaka group attacked a MINUSCA convoy in the Bangui Ville neighborhood of Bangassou. MINUSCA returned fire and the perpetrators fled. Two peacekeepers were injured in the clash.
03 March 2018. The LRA ambushed three people traveling on motorcycles in Bani, Yalinga. The assailants killed one of the civilians and abducted the others to carry looted goods.
03 March 2018. An unidentified armed group looted an NGO vehicle 35 km from Mboki.
Houses were burned by armed men in Gofo village. 4 dead.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Rafai was taken by UPC after battling against the local self-defense militia. Identity of self-defense militia not known.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 04 March. An unidentified armed group attacked the MINUSCA base in Agoumar, where IDPs were seeking shelter. MINUSCA repelled the attackers.

column7: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 04 March. Three women went to Beboura with an infant to find food. Upon their arrival, armed Fulani with ties to the MNLC slit the women's throats and stabbed the infant in the leg.
On 4 March LRA men attacked the village Mbangana, clashing with suspected locals. 2 LRA dead and 1 taxi driver killed.
On 4 March, LRA men captured and looted civilians along the Obo-Mboki road. They forced 11 civilians to shell groundnuts releasing them the next day.
Looting: On 4 March, a motorcyclist was ambushed and robbed by 9 alleged LRA members on the Kitesa-Zemio road between Begoue and Zeperou. They allowed him to go south, towards the Mbomou River.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Looting: several lootings perpetrated against humanitarian actors were reported.
On 5 March, an LRA group attacked and looted Kitesa of its radio communications equipment, injuring the chief operator in the process.

On 5 March, an alleged LRA group comprised of men, women and children abducted a young man and looted granaries in Yangou Baindji, CAR. Later, they robbed a motorcyclist of his belongings on the Sam-Ouandja road.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: FPRC men tortured and killed a man accused of witchcraft.
Women in Bangassou marched to claim for peace and security in the region.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 07 March. Anti-Balaka forces ambushed a MINUSCA convoy traveling from Alindao to Dimbi. The peacekeepers returned fire and the attackers fled.
Movement of armed forces: On 7 March armed men entered the village of Guerekindo provoking a civilian displacement.
Women organised a march to claim the enforcement of the gender equality bill of law.
Women organised a march to claim the enforcement of the gender equality bill of law.
Women organised a march to claim the enforcement of the gender equality bill of law.
Women organised a march to claim the enforcement of the gender equality bill of law.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 09 March. Anti-Balaka forces attacked a MINUSCA patrol in Bangassou. The peacekeepers exchanged fire with the attackers, who then fled.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 10 March. MINUSCA clashed with Anti-Balaka forces near an IDP camp in Bangassou.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 10 March. The MNLC killed a civilian in Betoboinda 4 (coordinates are approximate based on location being 13 KM east of Paoua).

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 10 March. MNLC combatants shot and injured a man in the bush near Betoboinda 2 (coordinate are approximate; based on UNICEF map and towns location 15 KM from Paoua).

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: Looting: On 10 March, gunmen looted the Cordaid and MSF headquarters in Bangassou.
Detonation: On 11 March some explosions were heard in Bangassou, triggering panic among civilians. Many crossed the river to seek shelter in DRC.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Movement of forces: On 12 March UPC-linked armed men arrived to Bakouma in order to prepare the attack on Bangassou. The CAR army was also redeployed to Bangassou ahead of attacks.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 12 March local sources claimed that Mauritanian blue helments tortured some civilians in PK3 site in Bria.
On 13 March, a dead body was found on the Alindao-Mingala axis. This triggered clashes in the area two days later.
On 13 March, 4 people were kidnapped on the Bria-Ippy axis by armed men while going to their fields.
13 March 2018. A member of an armed group sexually assaulted and shot a young girl in Rafai. The victim died from her injuries.

13 March 2018. A group of LRA, including women and children, ambushed travelers along the Bria-Nzako road. The assailants looted goods from the civilians. They also shot at two members of an ex-Seleka faction traveling along the road, killing one.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 14 March. MNLC members under the command of General Bahar beat a man with the butts of their guns in Kelehou (no coordinates available, assumed to be in Paoua region based on MNLC territory).
On 14 March, a group of 16 men and boys, 2 women and 2 babies was ambushed by LRA forces. They abducted 2 boys. They released the others in exchange for 13 motorcycles.
15 March (approximately). Anti-Balaka attacked a Fulani camp in Mbaidou, Ouaka. Approximately 15 people were killed.
Looting: Over January-June 2018, reports of at least monthly incidents of lootings by the Siriri coalition in the Amada-Gaza, Mambere-Kadei, area.
On 15 March, clashes erupted between armed groups two days after the discovery of a dead body. No casualty toll available.
On 16 March, displaced people erected barricades on the road to protest the arrest of Jean-Francis Diandi, leader of Anti-Balaka in Bria.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Arrests: On 16 March, Minusca confirmed the arrest of a leader of the anti-Balaka armed group at its Bria displaced people's camp. The leader of the anti-Balaka armed group, who has been identified as Jean-Francis Diandi, is accused of taking part in an attack which resulted in the death of a Mauritanian peacekeeper in December last year.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 17 March, an educational counselor was kidnapped by Anti-Balaka men in Bangassou, as they found contacts of ""muslims"" in his cellphone. A ransom was asked to free him.
18 March 2018. The LRA looted two women and one man near Yalinga. The assailants proceeded to kill the man and hold the women captive until releasing them later that day.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 19 March. Anti-Balaka attacked a MINUSCA convoy in the Bangui ville neighborhood of Bangassou. MINUSCA forces repelled the attackers.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 20 march, UPC members killed an anti-balaka man in Gotile, 35km north of Bambari. This triggered reprisal attacks by the AB on the same day, who killed 15 men in Tagbara, 72 km from Bambari.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 20 march, the execution of an anti-balaka man by the UPC in Gotile (35km north of Bambari) triggered reprisal attacks by the AB, who killed 15 men in Tagbara, 72 km from Bambari.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On the week of 18 March, some UPC elements were killed and two peacekeepers were injured as MINUSCA forces intervened to protect civilians during another clash between the Anti-Balaka and UPC in southern Alindao.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 21 March, UPC men attacked some villages around Markounda including Silambi et Dayou. At least six women killed.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 21 March, UPC men attacked the villages around Tagbara in reprisal for earlier clashes, killing several civilians and burning their houses.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 22 March, the clashes between UPC and Anti-Balaka continued in Seko (60 km N of Bambari). Around ten civilians, including children, were killed in the crossfire.
On or around 24 March, five children and one Catholic priest were kidnapped by AB militants in Bangassou area. The priest was later released.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column9: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Looting: On 24 March, an ICRC convoy of nine vehicles including six trucks transporting food supplies to IDPs in Markounda was ambushed by suspected UPC armed men close to Nangha Boguila. All goods were seized, and after negotations the convoy was released.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 25 March. MPC forces attacked a MINUSCA patrol in Boria, Nangha Boguila. MINUSCA forces returned fire.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 27 March. MNLC forces under the command of General Bahar assisted by armed Fulani men attacked Bedoro, Paoua. The assailants killed one civilian.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 28 March. MNLC members ambushed three motorcycles in Beboura 4 (coordinates are approximate based on the towns location 25 km north east of Paoua). One of the motorcyclist bodies was discovered near Bekoro (45 km north of Paoua). The perpetrators also abducted a pregnant passenger, who later escaped.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 31 March, a MINUSCA patrol was attacked by PK5 armed men in PK5, Bangui.
On 31 March, an alleged LRA group abducted 4 hunters in Obo surroundings.
On 1 April, clashes between two armed groups were reported in Boungou 2 (Bria-Ouadda axis)
On 1 April, a group of presumed LRA kidnapped 18 civilians in Bozongui in Obo and looted radios, food and tools.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 1 April, LRA forces attacked the Koubou village, Obo, taking 15 civilians as hostages and looting goods. FACA and MINUSCA forces intervened immediately after they were alerted of the attack, exchanging fire with the assailants who escaped in the bush with the hostages. One hostage died after the events. 9 hostages were freed by the LRA on 4 April.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme; Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: On 1 April, LRA forces attacked the Koubou village, Obo, taking 15 civilians as hostages and looting goods. FACA and MINUSCA forces intervened immediately after they were alerted of the attack, exchanging fire with the assailants who escaped in the bush with the hostages. One hostage died after the events. 9 hostages were freed by the LRA on 4 April.
During the week of 2 April, armed men attacked some civilians in reprisal for the killing of a man belonging to the armed group's community. 4 dead.
During the week of 2 April, LRA armed men attacked Bani village (Yalinga- Sam Ouandja axis). 4 people were killed and other were kidnapped.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: Arrests: 02 April. UPC arrested suspected Anti-Balaka associates and turned them over to MINUSCA.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 3 April, clashes between suspected AB and MINUSCA forces were reported in Tagbara (Bambari-Ippy axis), as the armed group attacked the MINUSCA base: 21 civilians , 1 blue helmet and 23 armed men died.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 03 April. MNLC members shot and injured a man in Kebe.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 03 April. The UPC killed 23 civilians following the withdrawal of MINUSCA troops from the St. Charles Lwanga Church in Seko after its base in Tagbara was attacked by ABs. The Church has hosting Christians seeking refuge.

column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 4 April, police auxiliaries demonstrated in front of the Prime Minister in Bangui headquarters claiming their integration to the public service.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 8 April, shots were fired around the Presidential Residence in Bangui. Russian forces intervened to secure the president. It is unclear if there was a clash.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme; UN Panel of Experts
column17: 8 April. MINUSCA forces engaged into an operation against local militias in KM5 neighbourhood attempting to disarm them: initial reports of 3 dead and 30 wounded (11 among MINUSCA elements). However, MINUSCA later confirmed two people were killed and 45 were injured during the operation. 8 militiamen were arrested, weapons and drugs seized. Militiamen set fire to the local police station.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 9 April, several protesters demonstrated in front of the MINUSCA HQ in Bangui, deploring the escalation of violence.
Detonation: On 10 April, gunshots were fired in Dilapoko (30 km north-west from Gamboula) where an armed group's checkpoint is set.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 10 April. MINUSCA and an armed group from PK5 clashed in the 3rd District of Bangui. One peacekeeper was killed and eight individuals were injured.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 10 April, local militiamen and the regular army, supported by international forces, clashed at the KM5 neighbourhood. One MINUSCA soldier and 18 militiamen died and 100 were wounded. OCHA report a week later stated 31 dead and 145 wounded on the two days of clashes (3 coded on 08/04).

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 10 April, prisoners of Ngaragba's prison in Bangui mutined and clashed with the CAR and MINUSCA security forces deployed in the area the same day: 2 dead and one wounded among the mutineers.
On 11 April, a NGO staff was abducted by an armed group in Gousseima (66km west from Kouango). He was freed after the payment of a ransom.

On 11 April, angry protesters victims of the previous days' clashes between MINUSCA and KM5 militiamen deposed 17 dead bodies in front of MINUSCA Headquarters in Bangui, claiming UN soldiers were responsible for their death.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 11 April, 8 men working for a sensibilisation mission were kidnapped by ex-Seleka men.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 12 April, Siriri men opened fire on a MINUSCA patrol at a check point in Amada-Gaza, Mambere-Kadei. 4 armed men were killed.
On 12 April, an armed group attack Nouffou (85 km north-west from Gaboula). No toll available, but around 18900 were displaced.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 12 April, 12 people (including an MP and a deputy-prefect) were abducted by alleged FPRC men after an official visit in Yalinga. Later on, 4 were freed.
On 13 April, an armed group attacked Dimbi, Kembe clashing against another armed group occupying that locality. Toll unknown.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 14 April. MNLC combatants fired shots at a family traveling from Paoua to Bena 2.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: April 2018. Claim that six MINUSCA peacekeepers from Cameroon raped civilians. Investigations were launched.
Looting: Over January-June 2018, reports of at least monthly incidents of lootings by the Siriri coalition in the Amada-Gaza, Mambere-Kadei, area.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 15 April. MNLC forces ambushed nine civilians near Bedam, Paoua. The perpetrators shot and seriously injured one of the civilians.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 15 April. During the month, the UPC received a notable weapons shipment of rifles, machine guns, and ammunition from Sudanese traffickers. The acquirement of additional arms was believed to be in preparation for the deployment of FACA soldiers throughout the country.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Movement of forces: On 16 April, ex-Seleka forces gathered in Kaga-Bandoro to counter the FACA deployment in the area and discuss about a march on Bangui.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 16 April. MNLC forces from Nzakoundou beat and abducted a man in Lemouna, Paoua.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 17 April. An unidentified armed group attacked the MINUSCA headquarters in Bangui. Peacekeepers repelled the attackers.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 20 April. An armed man shot at the MINUSCA base in Betoko. MINUSCA forces returned fire and killed the attacker.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 21 April, MINUSCA forces attacked armed members of the ""Siriri coalition"" that were levying taxes on travellers in Nassole and fired at them. 10 dead among the armed men and several wounded.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 22 April. A group of Siriri Fulani fighters attacked a MINUSCA patrol in Mambere-Kadei. 5 combatents were killed.
Looting: On 22 April, LRA group looted near Sodi.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 23 April, the village Nguevongba, 17 km from Ippy, was stormed by an armed group: 8 people dead and 7 wounded.
On 23 April, a group of 5 armed LRA combatants abducted 1 young girl and 1 young boy in Bria, as they were returning home from the field with their parents.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 24 April, Mbarara Fulani attacked the villages of Garo, Boloum, Bongono 2, 15 km from Batangafo, asking for an indemnisation for some injuries on cattle. They reportedly shot on civilians.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 24 April, Mbarara Fulani attacked the villages of Garo, Boloum, Bongono 2, 15 km from Batangafo, asking for an indemnisation for some injuries on cattle. They reportedly shot on civilians.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 24 April, Mbarara Fulani attacked the villages of Garo, Boloum, Bongono 2, 15 km from Batangafo, asking for an indemnisation for some injuries on cattle. They reportedly shot on civilians.
Looting: On 25 April, unknown assailants attacked the Karandja mine , 15 km north of Bakala. Unclear if casualties but 800 people were displaced.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Weapons seizure: In the last week, 691 weapons were collected in Bria and 900 in Bangassou by MINUSCA elements in the framework of the disarmament process.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 26 April. MNLC members ambushed two motorbikes in Betoboinda 2 (coordinate are approximate; based on UNICEF map and towns location 15 KM from Paoua). The perpetrators killed one of the drivers.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 26 April. MNLC members killed a man in Betani (coordinates are approximate based on location being 15 km east of Paoua). They also stole a cow.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Looting: Since the occupation of Kaga-Bandoro by ex-Seleka men, they set up illegal checkpoints and looted peoples' properties.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 29 April. An unidentified armed group attacked a MINUSCA security post at the Seko church in Tagbara. MINUSCA forces repelled the attackers.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 29 April. RJ forces attacked a MINUSCA escorted WFP convoy in Borosse. MINUSCA exchanged fire with the attackers, who fled.
On 30 April, a man was abducted by some LRA elements 10 km northeast of Zemio.
01 May, as a reprisal for the earlier attack on the Fatima church, an irate crowd set fire to a mosque in Bangui and lynched two Senegalese Muslims.

On 1 May, some armed men, reportedly belonging to PK5 militia, attacked the Fatima church in Bangui, close to PK5 neighbourhood, killing around 30 people attending the service, among which pastor Tougoumale-Baba, and wounding 99. The attempt by security forces to arrest the PK5 militia leader (""Force"") is deemed to have caused the Fatima attack.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: AFP; Radio Ndeke Luka; Africa News
column17: On 1 May, clashes were reported between the PK5 militia and MINUSCA after their earlier attack on the Fatima church.

Security Measures: Since 1 May, armed militias have been erecting baricades and checkpoints from sunset until dawn in Bangui. While this phenomenon appears quite generalised in Bangui, it is stronger in neighbourhood around KM5, which appear almost under ""siege"".

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: Looting: 08 April. During Operation Sukula, witnesses reported that members of FACA who were not a part of the operation entered the Senegalese neighbourhood in PK5 and looted homes.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 02 May. During the night, MNLC forces killed a herder in Betokomia, Paoua and stole his cattle.
In the first week of May, serveral security incidents involving armed men and civilians were reported in Nzoro, 20 km east of Ngaoundaye. These incidents triggered the displacement of 500 families.
On 3 or 6 May, a security incident against armed an aid worker was reported as armed men led incursions in Bombo (42 km north-west of Amada-Gaza) and Gbambia villages. 1296 people fled pre-emptively.
On 3 May, a boy was kidnapped by an LRA group near Yangou Issi, as he was travelling by motorcycle along the Bria-Nzako Road.
03 May. IDPs demonstrated and burned tires on the runway of the Paoua airfield to protest against insecurity in the region.
03 May. Anti-Balaka killed one civilian accused of witchcraft.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 4 May, MINUSCA elements attacked an FPRC column attempting to reach Dekoa, after bypassing Ndomete's checkpoint, 10 km from Kaga-Bandoro. A pick-up was neutralised and a FPRC fighter taken prisonner.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 4 May 2018, angry people looted a mosque in the 7th neighbourhood of Bangi in retaliation for the death of a women caused by the Fatima attack three days prior. [size=no report]

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 4 May, civil society organisation launched a ""dead city"" strike. People built barricades and blocked the circulation, notably in 2nd and 6th neighbourhoods. MINUSMA vehicles were targeted and had make some dissuasion shots.
On 05 May, clashes reported between armed groups in Gbambia, Amada-Gaza. 3823 people sought shelter in the bush. The following day, a humanitarian agency was looted.

05 May. Anti-Balaka forces under the control of Pino Pino killed eight women accused of witchcraft in Bema. The coordinates for this location are approximate, based on NGO reports that it is located in Ngbandinga, in front of Yakoma on the DRC side of the border.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 5 May, PK5 militants looted and burned down houses and religious buildings in the Castors neighbourhoods of Bangui.They were repulsed by the security forces.
Several clashes between civilians and herders were reported in Kounkpala, 35 km on the Bocarenga-Paoua axis. 1200 people were displaced.

Movement of forces: On 3 and 6 May, armed men incursions were reported in Bombo (42 km north-west of Amada-Gaza) and Gbambia villages. A security incident against an aid worker was reported during one of these incursions (coded on 3 May). 1296 people fled pre-emptively.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 6 May, clashes were reported between KM5 armed men and CAR security forces as KM5 militants attempted to burn down and loot properties, including religious buildings, in several neighborhoods of Bangui (Castors, Yakite and Kpetene). 2 dead and 10 wounded.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 08 May. An armed group attacked the MINUSCA headquarters in Bangui. MINUSCA repelled the attackers. On the same day, unidentified assailants also opened fire on a MINUSCA patrol while they were clearing a barricade in Bangui. One peacekeeper was injured.
Looting: During the week of 7 May, a humanitarian vehicle was ambushed by armed men in Bobafio on the Batangafo-Lady axis. The assailants looted the belongings of the aid workers aboard the vehicle.
Looting: On the night of 9-10 May, armed men looted 6 houses in Kaga-Bandaro including 2 belonging to humanitarian agents. On 10 May, assailants also ambushed and stole an NGO vehicle.

column7: MDREC: Democratic Movement for the Renaissance of the Central African Republic
column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 10 May, a march organised by the MDREC against violence in Bangui was dispersed by police forces.
On 11 May, two rival factions on an armed group clashed in Ouazzoua, Ouango. 700 houses were burned down as a result of clashes. Toll unavailable.

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 13 May, FPRC rebels gathered around Kaga Bandoro claimed they were bombarded by French Mirages close to Kaga-Bandoro. Injuries reported.
Looting: On 14 and 15 May, two humanitarian vehicles were attacked and looted in two separate incidents in Batangafo and 24km away from the town.
On 14 May, 3 Fulani men on a motorbike were killed by some armed men 7 km from Bambari, on the Alindao axis.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: May 2018. Claim that MINUSCA peacekeepers from Mauritania sexually abused minors in the southern region of CAR. Investigations were launched.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 15 May, as a reprisal for the killing of 3 Fulani men, UPC forces attacked security forces and civilians in Bambari. At least 10 people were killed, including some in targeted killings on the side of the clashes. UPC engaged in lootings and executions of civilians in the area for another two days, setting up checkpoints throughout the city (10 fatalities spread over two events on 16 and 17 May).
Looting: In May, 9 humanitarian organisation structures were robbed in Bambari by armed men.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa (Ousta Faction)
column17: 15 May. During May, the FPRC under General Ousta's control subjected three men in Bria to ""cruel and inhumane"" treatment following allegations of witchcraft.
Looting: Over January-June 2018, reports of at least monthly incidents of lootings by the Siriri coalition in the Amada-Gaza, Mambere-Kadei, area.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 17 May, Anti-Balaka men ambushed a MINUSCA patrol 30 km from Alindao: one blue helmet dead and 8 wounded. 40 assailants killed.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 15 May, as a reprisal for the killing of 3 Fulani men, UPC forces attacked security forces and civilians in Bambari. UPC engaged in lootings and executions of civilians in the area for another two days, setting up checkpoints throughout the city (10 fatalities spread over two events on 16 and 17 May).

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 18 May. Two unidentified gunmen fired at a MINUSCA patrol near their base in Nana Bakassa. Two peacekeepers were injured.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 19 May, three old women suspected of witchcraft were killed close to Mbaiki, Lobaye, by youngsters.
On 21 May, two people were kidnapped in Batangafo by two armed men.

column7: MDREC: Democratic Movement for the Renaissance of the Central African Republic
column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 21 May, a march organised by the MDREC in Bangui against the UN embargo was blocked and dispersed by police forces. MDREC leader was briefly arrested.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 22 May. A MINUSCA patrol clashed with Anti-Balaka forces 5 km north east of Bambari on the Bambari-Pladama road. Three Anti-Balaka members were killed.

On 23 May, a grenade was thrown by some unidentified armed men in the neighbourhood of KM5, killing two people and wounding several. This followed clashes between two local militias that left another 10 dead.
On 23 May, two armed groups holding the checkpoints of Fatima and KM5 clashed. 10 killed. A grenade explosion was thrown in the neighborhood by unknown assailants soon after, killing another 2.
On 25 May, some ""self-defence"" armed men threw a grenade against the residence of the 3rd arrondissement Mayor. Nobody was wounded.
On 25 May, as a reprisal to the grenade attack, PK5 militias and other armed men clashed in PK5 neighbourhood. 1 dead and several wounded.
On the week of 28 May, several clashes between armed men were reported at the Dilapoko village (pk30 North-West of Gamboula). Two events coded with a date precision of 2 on that week.
28 May. One civilian accused of witchcraft was executed by Anti-Balaka members in Batangafo.
On 29 May, presumed LRA men looted the village of Yangou-Pendere, Haute-Kotto, and kidnapped 5 men.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 29 May. Two UPC fighters exchanged fire with MINUSCA peacekeepers in Bambari, near the Maidou school.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 30 May, UPC men attacked the gendarmerie in Bambari following the looting of a Muslim's shop by the army: one gendarme was reportedly killed.

column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: Looting: On 30 May, several NGO offices and several private and government buildings were looted by armed men in Bambari.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 30 May. A local Anti-Balaka leader raided cattle in Kouki and clashed with a MINUSCA patrol while fleeing.
30 May. Anti-Balaka forces under the leadership of Line Roger killed a woman accused of witchcraft.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 31 May, MINUSCA air forces struck UPC positions in Bambari. 70 people were reportedly killed and 10 wounded. Ten houses were burned down.
Looting: On the week of 28 May, 6 looting incidents were reported in Kaga-Bandoro, with 4 targeting humanitarian organisations.
On the week of 28 May, several clashes between armed men were reported at the Dilapoko village (pk30 North-West of Gamboula). Two events coded with a date precision of 2 on that week.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 1 June, UPC elements left Bambari for Kouango, attempting to shelter following MINUSCA air raids on Bambari the day before.
Looting: between 2 and 5 June, reports of incursions of armed men and looting of civilians' properties in Betein, Makandji and Betoko villages in the Paoua area.
On 2 June, 3 people were severely wounded in PK3, Bria by armed men.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 3 June, the Siriri militia attacked the UN patrol in the village of Dilapoko, in southwest Mambere-Kadei. One peacekeeper was killed and seven others injured.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa (Ousta Faction)
column17: 03 June. The FPRC faction under the control of General Ousta killed one woman accused of witchcraft in Bria.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 04 June. Approximately 50 Anti-Balaka combatants attacked a MINUSCA patrol in Ouango town. The peacekeepers repelled the attackers.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 05 June. Between 40-50 Anti-Balaka fighters attacked a MINUSCA patrol at 1:15 am, 8 km north of Ouango town. The patrol repelled the combatants. The same group attacked a MINUSCA patrol, for a second time, at 5:15 am, 8 km north of Ouango town. The peacekeepers also repelled the second attack.
Looting: Between 5 - 8 June, reports of incursions of armed men in Ndim, Bocaranga and exactions against civilians causing displacement.
On 6 June, armed men attacked the village of Mbiti (45km from Kaga-Bandoro). People fled the village and took shelter in the bush.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 6 June, UPC and self-defense elements clashed in Bambari: several dead reported.
On 7 June, a group of LRA combatants ambushed, looted, and abducted 2 cyclists in Koumboli, Zemio. They were later released.

Looting: On 8 June, armed men attacked and looted a humanitarian convoy in Bissingale (7km from Kaga-Bandoro). Another humanitarian vehicle was looted the following day in Kanga (50km from Kaga-Bandoro).

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Looting: On 8 June, armed men looted an humanitarian vehicle around Bria.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 10 June, CAR armed forces directed to Bangassou were attacked in Bambari by UPC men. 2 soldiers and a Russian instructor were wounded. 5 attackers were killed.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 10 June. A UN patrol was attacked by armed men in Bambari, killing a Burundian peacekeeper.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 11 June, UPC men and CAR armed forces, together with the Russian instructors, clashed in Bambari for the second consecutive day. Many UPC men left Bambari following the clashes.
On 11 June, a child was killed during an attack by armed men in Bekam, 21 km from Paoua. Another child was wounded.
On 11 June, armed men attacked Dilapoko, 85km from Berberati: abuses on civilians were reported.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 12 June, a trader was executed by some armed men in Boungou, 41km from Ouadda.
On 13 June, an armed man attacked the refugee camp in Ippy, killing one and wounding 6.
Looting: On 14 June, armed men looted the vehicles of a religious mission in Yagarandji (15km from Kaga-Bandoro)
Looting: On 14 June, armed men looted the vehicles of an NGO in Ndowara (5km from Kaga-Bandoro) - approximate coordinates used.
Looting: On 14 June, armed men looted the vehicles of a NGO at 20 km from Ouandago.
On 14 June, LRA elements kidnapped 12 people and wounded one in Bassokpolo, 3 km south of Obo town, Haut-Mbomou (approx. coordinates used)

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: Looting: On 15 June, incursion of soldiers in the Dele village (21km East of Markounda).
Looting: On 15 June, a group of LRA combatants looted goods from 3 civilians in Nguiringuiri, Haut-Mbomou.
Looting: Over January-June 2018, reports of at least monthly incidents of lootings by the Siriri coalition in the Amada-Gaza, Mambere-Kadei, area.

In June 2018, the local Mujahidin communal militia clashed repeatedly with Anti-Balaka forces (led by Yagbengue aka Pele) in the areas surrounding Mbres, Nana-Gribizi. During the intermittent clashes, 18 civilians were killed in total, 1500-2000 houses burned down, and 7000 people forced to flee.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 15 June. MNLC forces gang raped an elderly woman in Bebenguere.
On 16 June, Oyouth in Obo organised a march to denounce the bad humanitarian situation of Obo.
Looting: On 18 June, some alleged armed men raided the Binitouli village (15km of Benamkor, Paoua).
On 19 June, some armed men clashed in Dilapoko, 85 km Ouest of Berberati.
On 20 June, a group of LRA combatants ambushed, looted, and abducted 17 civilians around Obo, Haut-Mbomou.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

column17: On 20 June, FPRC and MPC men clashed in Ndele: 28 dead, 5 wounded.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Looting: On 30 June, a NGO office was raided by armed men.
30 June. In retaliation for MINUSCA operations, Siriri forces attacked Gbambia, looting the village. The perpetrators abducted 11 residents, eight of whom they killed.
On 1 July, two armed groups clashed in Gbambia, 27 km from Amada-Gaza, Mambere-Kadei.
On 2 July, crowds of people including beneficiaries forced their way into a humanitarian food stock warehouse in Bocaranga, OuhamPende, on two occasions, stealing large amounts of food.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 3 July, the temporary MP from Bambari was kidnapped by Anti-Balaka men, in retaliation for his refusal to finance them. It is unclear whether he was killed.
On 3 July, two dead bodies were found at PK3, near a mining site, following tensions between armed groups at the site.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 4 July, local security forces and LRA men clashed in Ngilingili, Haut-Mbomou, after LRA people attemted to kidnap a couple plowing their field.

Over 2-10 July, report of regular acts of initimidation, arbitrary arrests and assassinations of IDPs/refugees by gunmen in PK3 following tensions around a mining site. Unknown dates coded as two events with a date precision of 2. Unknown fatalities coded as 10 (spread acorss events).

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: On 4 July, several MSF workers were threatened and assaulted by armed men in Bria, who seized some material. MSF suspended its operations in the area as a result.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 04 July. MNLC members shot at a MINUSCA patrol, which was stuck in the mud in Bemouli, Ouham Pende. The patrol returned fire.
Looting: On the week of 2 July, at least 6 4x4 vehicles seized by armed men in KM5, Bangui.

column9: Women (Central African Republic); Men (Central African Republic)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 06 July (on or around). Anti-Balaka abducted civilians from the Bangassou area and held them for six months. They were subjected to sexual violence (including minors) and forced labor.

column9: Women (Central African Republic); Men (Central African Republic)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 06 July (on or around). Anti-Balaka abducted civilians from Mbingora (no coordinates available) in Kembe. They held the adbuctees for six months during which time they were subjected to sexual violence (including minors), killings, and forces labor. One woman indicated her 15 year old son was killed.
On 6 July, one dead and three wounded after sounds of grenade-like explosions and heavy weaponry were heard in Alindao, Basse-Kotto.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 07 July. Two armed men fired at a MINUSCA patrol in Benanh I, Ouham Pende.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 08 July. A peacekeeper was shot and wounded by an armed Fulani man outside of the MINUSCA headquarters in Bambari.

Over 2-10 July, report of regular acts of initimidation, arbitrary arrests and assassinations of IDPs/refugees by gunmen in PK3 following tensions around a mining site. Unknown dates coded as two events with a date precision of 2. Unknown fatalities coded as 5 (spread acorss events).
On 10 July, the inhabitants of Bria marched to denounce human rights violations and abuses performed by armed groups against people and humanitarian agents.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 11 July. FPRC members attacked a MINUSCA convoy in Bria at the Amameu church. The peacekeepers exchanged fire with the combatants. 20 minutes later, FPRC fighters shot at MINUSCA peacekeepers near the Bria hospital, causing damage to the UN vehicle.
On 13 July, some traders of the Petevo market occupied the CEMAC avenue in Bangui, 6e, spreading fruits on the road to prevent passage.

During the week of 13 July, 10 cases of rape perpetrated by armed men were witnessed, 4 on the Bria-Yalinga axis and 6 on the Bria-Irabanda. Coded as two events in each location on 13 and 16 July (precision of 2).

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 13 July. Siriri forces attacked a MINUSCA patrol, which exchanged fire, in Bombo, Mambere-Kadei.

During the week of 13 July, 10 cases of rape perpetrated by armed men were witnessed, 4 on the Bria-Yalinga axis and 6 on the Bria-Irabanda (unclear if occurred at the same time). Coded as two events in each location on 13 and 16 July (precision of 2).
On 15 July, 3 civilians were executed by an armed group in Gousseima, Lihoto.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Non-violent activity: 15 July. RRR (3R) forces have been reported in Ngoutere and other parts of Bocaranga. A spokesperson for the group said they were working to negotiate the release of three traders who had been arrested in Bazoum.

On 16 July, anti-Balaka militia attacked an international NGO in Batangafo. A local employee was shot and injured. UN peacekeepers were said to have responed to the intrusion but it is unclear if there was fighting.

During the week of 13 July, 10 cases of rape perpetrated by armed men were witnessed, 4 on the Bria-Yalinga axis and 6 on the Bria-Irabanda. Coded as two events in each location on 13 and 16 July (precision of 2).

During the week of 13 July, 10 cases of rape perpetrated by armed men were witnessed, 4 on the Bria-Yalinga axis and 6 on the Bria-Irabanda. Coded as two events in each location on 13 and 16 July (precision of 2).

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 17 July, the anti-Balaka militia clashed with UN troops in Pombolo. One civilian killed and 20 injured, among them three peacekeepers.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 18 July, APO militia clashed with ""Force""-militia in KM5 in Bangui leading to 6 dead and 10 wounded. Others say that FACA was the target of the Force militia after an earlier attack they blamed on the state forces.

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 18 July, self defense forces from Bangassou attacked elements of the UPC in Pombolo, leading to at least 17 dead.

On 18 July, a PK5 militia killed 1 militant and injured 4 others of the ""Force""-militia of Djamous in PK5 neighbourhood of Bangui. Force elements blamed the attack on FACA troops and engaged in retaliatory attacks later in the night.
Looting: On 19 July, 10 LRA looted a truck of various goods on the Bambouti-Obo Road, 8km east of Ligoua, Haut-Mbomou.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 19 July, the dead body of a FACA soldier on mission was found in Obo. It is unclear who killed him.
On 20 July, LRA forces attacked the Ngoulia mining site, 11km from Kpokpo, Haute-Kotto, on the Bria-Nzako road. They abducted 11 people and killed 1.
On 20 July, unidentified men ambushed a civilian vehicle 5km from Obo which caused the death of one women and injured 4 others.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 20 July. Anti-Balaka forces shot at a MINUSCA patrol at a barricaded erected by the armed group in Lakouetene.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: From 20 to 25 July, suspected UPC and ABs clashed in Lihoto, Kouango (68km West on the Kouango-Grimari axis). No available toll. Thousands of people displaced. New clashes occurred early August involving these groups.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 21 July. Anti-Balaka combatants attacked a MINUSCA patrol on the Kaga Bandoro-Mbres road in the Lakouetene area. The peacekeepers returned fire and repelled the attackers.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: From 20 to 25 July, suspected UPC and ABs clashed in Lihoto, Kouango (68km West on the Kouango-Grimari axis). No available toll. Thousands of people displaced. New clashes occurred early August involving these groups.

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa (Hissene Faction)
column17: On 22 July a member of the Patriotic Movement for the Central African Republic (MPC) killed 2 armed elements of the Patriotic Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa in the city of Kaga-Bandoro after an inter-personal dispute. Movements of FPRC armed men and transfer of their bases were observed in the town in the following days, raising tensions in the town.
On 23 July, a LRA group attacked the village of Ligoua, Haut-Mbomou, abducting 6 people.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: From 20 to 25 July, suspected UPC and ABs clashed in Lihoto, Kouango (68km West on the Kouango-Grimari axis). No available toll. Thousands of people displaced. New clashes occurred early August involving these groups.

In the week of 22 July, armed men attacked the localities of Fah-Village and Fah-Pilote, 25 and 30 km from Kaga-Bandoro. No toll available. Coded as two incidents on 25 July with a date precision of 2 (assumption that only on attack on that week).

In the week of 22 July, armed men attacked the localities of Fah-Village and Fah-Pilote, 25 and 30 km from Kaga-Bandoro. No toll available. Coded as two incidents on 25 July with a date precision of 2 (assumption that only on attack on that week).
Movement of forces: On 27 July, armed men entered Bakala, Ouaka, prompting the displacement of 8000 people to the bush. The armed men were supposedly directed to Mbres and Kaga-Bandoro.
Looting: On 27 July, a NGO office was looted by armed men in Bambari. A similar incident occurred the following day.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 27 July, a MINUSCA convoy was attacked by some Anti-Balaka elements at 10 km from Gambo, Pombolo: two soldiers were severely wounded.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 30 July, three Russian journalists were kidnapped by an armed group and later exectued in Bakou, 20 km from Sibut.
On 30 July, a biker leaving Nzelete for Alindao, was shot dead by armed men.
Looting: On 30 July, armed men looted the ""Mbari"" radio station in Bangassou.
On 31 July, armed men and herders clashed in Dere, 18 km south of Kaga-Bandoro. No toll available.
On 31 July, an armed group member killed 8 civilians in Pavika, Alindao.

""A national staff member of a local NGO was found dead on the road between Alindao airfield and the city center. His motorcycle was also found charred. No further details are available at this time.""
In the week of 30 July, armed men abused 4 people accused of sorcery in Bambari, killing 1. The source reports that these cases are on the rise.
Around 1 August, armed groups skermishes were reported in two villages around Kongbo, Mobaye. No available toll.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 2 August, Anti-Balakas and UPC men clashed in Lihoto, Kourango. 25 dead and several wounded.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 3-4 August, clashes between Anti-Balakas and UPC men have reportedly continued in Lihoto, Kourango.Toll unknown.
On 3 August, armed groups clashed in Polonda, 44 km North of Mobaye. No available toll.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 04 August. A MINUSCA patrol clashed with Anti-Balaka forces who refused to remove roadblocks 3 km south of Grimari along the Grimari-Lioto road.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 4 August, MINUSCA and an armed group clashed in Ngoulinga, 5 km north of Grimari. No toll available.

column17: Between 5-12 August, report of continued clashes between armed men on the Bria-Yalinga axis. Several material damages were reported as well as 4 civilians killed. Coded as 8 events with date precision of 2. 4 fatalities spread over four events. Given the mainly UPRC vs Anti-Balaka confrontation in Bria town and the proximity of these events to Bria, it is likely that these two groups were involved in the violence.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 14 August. Anti-Balaka shot at a MINUSCA guard at an IDP camp in Bria. The peacekeeper returned fire.

Property destruction: 14 August. An unidentified armed group attacked Ndenga. Fifty-nine homes were looted and burned. An estimated 900 residents were displaced, however, many have returned since. No indication of fatalities or injury.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: August 2018. Claim that MINUSCA peacekeepers from Mauritania sexually abused minors in the southern region of CAR. Investigations were launched.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 18 August. A group of 30 Anti-Balaka fighters attacked a MINUSCA convoy 25 km from Mbres. Peacekeepers returned fire and the assailants fled. The MINUSCA convoy was attacked a second time by Anti-Balaka forces 7 km from Mbres and three peacekeepers were injured.
20 August. LRA members abducted five men and looted food goods from the Yangou Issi mine. The coordinates are approximate.
20 August. LRA qbducted an unknown number of men and looted clothing and food from the Kotto 2 mining area.
20 August. LRA members kidnapped 15 men and looted the Yangou Brindi mines in Sam Ouandja.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Non-violent activity: 22 August. The FPRC has increased the number of road blocks on the Bria-Bambari road. Those traveling on the roads must pay fees at these checkpoints. These fees are making it cost prohibitive for the movement of goods and people in the region.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 23 August, Anti-Balakas attacked UN personnel in Alindao. MINUSCA soldiers sent in support were also attacked. One MINUSCA soldier killed.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 24 August. A group of three unidentified armed assailants attacked a joint MINUSCA/FACA patrol 10 km east of Boya. One attacker was killed.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Banda Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Labour Group (Central African Republic)
column17: 25 August. The FPRC ambushed Banda miners in Matabissi (coordinates are approximate based on location being 18 km north of Bria), killing at least 11-15 civilians.

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: AFP; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 25-26 August. Anti-Balaka forces clashed with FPRC forces who also had support from UPC fighters around Bria. FPRC killed 11 civilians on 25 August on the margins of the fighting. The fighting also displaced local residents.

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: AFP; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 25-26 August. Anti-Balaka forces clashed with FPRC forces who also had support from UPC fighters around Bria. FPRC killed 11 civilians on 25 August on the margins of the fighting. The fighting also displaced local residents.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 27 August. The chief of Bera was kidnapped. The attackers are believed to belong to the Siriri Coalition.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 27 August, week of. During the week, four women were killed based on witchcraft allegations in Bouca. The perpetrators were not identified. The area is under Anti-Balak control. Coded as four separate events during the week of 27 August with fatalities spread over the four events.
28 August. Seven civilians (two women and five men) were kidnapped by the Siriri in Gamboula. Three have been released while four remain captive.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Non-violent activity: 29 August. Ex-Seleka constructed barricades on the road from the PK3 IDP camp to the Bria hospital. The armed group is preventing NGOs from delivering supplies to the camp. FPRC was said to be responsible for several roadblocks in Bria the week before.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 27 August, week of. During the week, four women were killed based on witchcraft allegations in Bouca. The perpetrators were not identified. The area is under Anti-Balak control. Coded as four separate events during the week of 27 August with fatalities spread over the four events.
