column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 02 September. Ex-Seleka forces reportedly attacked civilians who went to collect wood 7km from the PK3 site. No fatalities reported. FPRC are suspected to be responsible for the erection of several roadblocks nd ambushes in the area.

03 September. Siriri forces abducted five civilians from Ore (no coordinates available) and held them at their base in Dilapoko. The abductees were assaulted while they were held. Two abductees were released on 10/09, while the others were freed a week later following a ransom payment. The abductions were in retaliation for an arrest in Gamboula.

04 September. Members of RRR (3R) killed a man in Ndongori close to Beloko in Baboua (approx. coordinates used close to Beloko). FACA troops had been deployed to Baboua earlier on that day to restore security in the area following increased activity by the group.

04 September. Elements of RRR (3R) reportedly opened fire on young people around Gamboula, on their way from Beloko to Sangami. FACA troops had been deployed to Baboua earlier on that day to restore security in the area following increased activity by the group.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 05 September. An ex-Seleka group attacked a joint MINUSCA-FACA patrol in Bekoro, Paoua. The security forces returned fire.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 05 September. Suspected MNLC members killed a village chief and woman between Bekoro Mission and Bemal.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 05 September. A man was kidnapped by FPRC members in Bria, UN forces in the town later negotiated his release. According to local sources, the FPRC searched IDP camps in the area to find members of the Anti-Balaka.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 06 September. The FPRC abducted 12 IPDs from PK3 in Bria. When the Anti-Balaka refused to agree to the FPRC's release terms, the FPRC killed nine of the IDPs, including seven women.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 06 September. Report of violence clashes between the FPRC and Anti-Balaka forces 6km outside of Bria. At least 9 IDPs were reportedly abducted and killed by one of the groups.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 07 September. Over 400 protesters gathered outside of the MINUSCA base in Bria carrying the bodies of people killed in the Bria area the day before, to express frustration over the force's failure to protect civilians from the recent attacks by FPRC and Anti-Balaka. MINUSCA reported two grenades being thrown at the base by the protesters, while locals alleged MINUSCA fired tear gas at them.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 07 September. MNLC members set-up a checkpoint in Zora (coordinates are approximate based on location being 22 km south of Paoua). The armed group robbed two NGO vehicles at the checkpoint.
08 September. An armed group looted an NGO office in Kouango. The robbery lead to the suspension of school programs in the area.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 10 September. Two RJ members fired at a MINUSCA patrol in Bedaya I, Paoua. The patrol returned fire and the combatants fled.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 10 September. Women in Bria protested against the killing of civilians in the town the week prior. The protesters demanded the deployment of FACA to the town, as well as the removal of MINUSCA chief of staff, head of security and head of communication at the Bria base over their failure to protect civilians.
Non-violent activity: 11 September. Approximately 45 armed men, believed to be from 3R forces have reportedly entered the village of Mboko Tatale. The reason for their presence remains unknown.
11 September. Armed men broke into an NGO office in Batangafo, took three security guards and two staff members hostge and stole equipment and money before leaving.
12 September. Three herders were killed in the Kouango sub-prefecture. Locals along the Kouango-Pende axis have fled the area in fear of a reprisal attack. No further details.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 13 September. MNLC and 3R ambushed a telecommunications convoy in Kounpala, Paoua. They detained five people and robbed them before releasing them later that day in Ndim.

13-19 September. During the week, three bodies (one woman and two men) were discovered in Obo (unclear location in Obo). The victims are believed to have been attacked on three distinct occasions by unknown armed men amidst rising insecurity in Obo. Coded as three separate events, each with one fatality.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 15 September. During the month, the UPC acquired an estimated $165,000 worth of arms from Sudanese arms traffickers. The acquirement of additional arms was believed to be in preparation for the deployment of FACA soldiers throughout the country.

13-19 September. During the week, three bodies (one woman and two men) were discovered in Obo (unclear location in Obo). The victims are believed to have been attacked on three distinct occasions by unknown armed men amidst rising insecurity in Obo. Coded as three separate events, each with one fatality.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 16 September. FPRC members killed four civilians in Tamangola. Coordinates are approximate, based on Tamangola's location 15 km north of Bria.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 16 September. Suspected Anti-Balaka members attacked a MINUSCA supply operation in Bokoula (coordinates are approximate base off of location 26 km south east of Alindao, along the Alindao-Kembe road).
16 September. Unidentified armed men broke into an NGO office in Kaga Bandoro. The perpetrators assaulted the staff and stole equipment.

17 September. Retired soldiers took to the streets of Bangui to demand their pensions. The demonstrators laid tree branches and rocks to block the roads in front of two military bases, as well as Independence Avenue.

13-19 September. During the week, three bodies (one woman and two men) were discovered in Obo (unclear location in Obo). The victims are believed to have been attacked on three distinct occasions by unknown armed men amidst rising insecurity in Obo. Coded as three separate events, each with one fatality.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 19 September. A group of youth in Bokanga reportedly detained two women accused of witchcraft. They beat one to death, while the military was able to intervene to rescue the other.
19 September. Armed men attacked an NGO office in Zangba, seriously injuring one employee.
26 September. Unidentified armed men killed a woman in a field in Bria.
21 September. An unidentified ex-Seleka group attacked the town of Bemaide. The perpetrators kidnapped two persons and injured others.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 21 September. An unidentified armed group fired at a MINUSCA patrol in Bambari, near PK 0. The peacekeepers returned fire.

22 September. A local dispute in the Ndjoukou sub-prefecture was brought to the attention of Anti-Balaka leader Agnoloma. After becoming involved, Agnoloma demanded a ransom of one million francs for a local chief and one person whom had been involved in the dispute. Only part of the random could be paid. Agnoloma beat the hostages before releasing them.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 23 September. RJ combatants attacked a joint FACA-MINUSCA patrol along the road at Benanh I, Paoua. FACA forces then entered the village looking for the attackers and killed one civilian.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 23 September. Suspected MNLC members ambushed farmers in Bedam, and abducted two men. The two men's bodies were discovered four days later.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 25 September. Anti-Balaka forces attacked a MINUSCA patrol near the PK 3 IDP camp in Bria. One peacekeeper was injured.
25 September. An armed group attacked civilians in Gbanguere, causing around a thousand residents to flee the area.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (1993-2003)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 26 September. The military deployed additional troops to Paoua to increase security along the border with Chad.
26 September, on or about. An unidentified armed group kidnapped a man and later killed him in Obo.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 27 September. Military prevented members of an organization of jobseekers to protest at the planned location in Bangui.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 27 September. The MNLC abducted a humanitarian worker and 11 other civilians along the Boria - Bogila Kete road. The perpetrators took the abductees into the bush, where they robbed them. The abductees were released later that day.
27 September. Armed groups clashed around Nao. Over 1,700 civilians were displaced along the Gbambia-Nao road.

28 September. The LRA attacked a group of civilians 5 km west of Yalinga. The attackers looted the civilians belongings and injured one person before splitting into two groups and heading in the directions of Bria and Nazika.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 28 September: Participants in DDR programs protested in Bangui. The demonstrators demanded five million CFA francs and lamented that the DDR programs failed to help them secure employment.
29 September. An armed group kidnapped humanitarian staff between Kebe and Barya and looted their belongings. The aid workers were released later that day.
30 September. Siriri forces attacked Gamboula, injuring four during the attack. The perpetrators also abducted four other civilians during the attack.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: Mid-September-mid-October. Residents in Ngaoundaye report that MNLC forces under the command of Bahar, attacked and looted locals in Bang, Kore, Ndjim and Mboum in the Ngaoundaye periphery throughoutthe month, resulting in limited economic activities.
Mid-September-mid-October. Residents of Ngaoundaye report that 3R forces under Sidiki have been looting and attacking the local population around De Gaulle during the month.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 01 October. The body of a soldier was found hung from a tree in Bangui's 3rd district. No indication of the attackers or motive.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 01 October. FACA was deployed to Bambari, which was under the control of the UPC.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: Mid-September-mid-October. Residents in Ngaoundaye report that MNLC forces under the command of Bahar, attacked and looted locals in Bang, Kore, Ndjim and Mboum in the Ngaoundaye periphery throughoutthe month, resulting in limited economic activities.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: Mid-September-mid-October. Residents in Ngaoundaye report that MNLC forces under the command of Bahar, attacked and looted locals in Bang, Kore, Ndjim and Mboum in the Ngaoundaye periphery throughoutthe month, resulting in limited economic activities.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: Mid-September-mid-October. Residents in Ngaoundaye report that MNLC forces under the command of Bahar, attacked and looted locals in Bang, Kore, Ndjim and Mboum in the Ngaoundaye periphery throughoutthe month, resulting in limited economic activities.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 02 October. The FPRC and an Anti Balaka faction under Ramazani's command reached an agreement in Bria, where the groups have been fighting for control. Ramazani was arrested by MINUSCA in March 2018. Another Anti-Balaka faction is led by Bokassa in Haute-Kotto.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 02 October. A member of the MNLC raped a woman in Mboum

02 October. The PK5 communal militia- 'Force' clashed with members of Moussa Danda's militia in Bangui's PK5 neighborhood. At least three people were killed (the UN indicates six fatalities, three of which were civilians) and two were wounded. Security forces have increased their patrol of the area.
At one point between 30 September- 6 October. Armed groups clashed near Kongbo. Civilians fled the town, with many seeking refuge in the bush.
04 October. An angry crowd in Sosso Nakombo killed three Chinese nationals and injured at least one other. The attack followed the drowning of a local youth leader who worked for the foreigners.
04 October. Unidentified armed men shot and killed a Muslim motorcyclist in Miskine.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 05 October. MNLC forces exchanged fire with a MINUSCA patrol in Ngaoundaye.
05 October. A group of Muslims killed a Christian in the Etoile neighborhood of the 3rd district in Bangui. The attack was in retaliation for the shooting of a Muslim the day prior.

6 October. Abass Sidiki of 3R and Marcel Ndale, the leader of Anti-Balaka in Nana Mambere, signed an agreement in Bouar. The commanders sought to assure civilians of their commitment to peace and to urge displaced persons to return.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Special Forces Battalion
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 07 October (on or around). The Government announced the establishment of a Special Forces Battalion, which is responsible for both autonomous operations and coordinated operations with FACA. Some have speculated that the autonomy of the new division is a means of circumventing the FACA-MINUSCA mission.

column7: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-); Labour Group (Central African Republic)
column17: 08 October. Employees of the Ministry of Transportation and Civil Aviation protested in front of the ministry. The protesters are calling for the resignation of Theodore Jousso, the Minister of Transportation. The employees alleged numerous accounts of corruption.
10 October (on or about). Armed groups clashed in Sam Ouandja. 1,000 displaced.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 11 October. FSI arrested seven UPC fighters after they were forcibly disarmed by MINUSCA in Bambari.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 11 October. UPC fighters began firing in the Adji district of Bambari. According to locals, the UPC were attempting to attack the police station to free members who had been arrested earlier in the day. MINUSCA deployed forces to respond and was attacked by the UPC fighters.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: UPC forces entered Grimari town. They informed locals that they intend to continue on to Kaga-Bandoro.

15 October. Members of an ex-Seleka group (likely the UPC) and an Anti-Balaka group exchanged fire in Mobaye. The clash followed a misunderstanding between members during the signing of a peace agreement.
15 October. Members of Apo's communal militia killed a pregnant woman in her home in Bangui's 3rd Arrondissement. The perpetrators accused her husband of stealing motorcycles belonging to Apo.
16 October. Demobilized combatants barricaded the road in Bangui. The demonstrators claim that the DDR program failed to help them gain livelihoods and economic integration.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 18 October. MNLC forces at an illegal checkpoint in Ndoubouri exchanged fire with a MINUSCA patrol before fleeing.

column6: CNDS: Coalition for National Defense and Security
column17: On 19 October, the CNDS (coalition of UPC, FPRC and MPC) announced their withdrawal from the Russian backed-Khartoum peace negotiations. Ex-Seleka groups met in Kabo in Ouham two days later. People left in fear.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa (Adam Faction)
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: 19 October. Two MINUSCA police and one soldier were kidnapped in Bria. It is believed that they were abducted by the FPRC faction led by Adam. MINUSCA is negotiating their release.
20 October (on or around). An unidentified armed group killed 'several' Fulani families, including five women and twelve children, north of Zemio.
22 October. An armed group entered Bocaranga, displacing an estimated 22,000 people between Bocaranga and Bozoum.
23 October. Armed groups clashed 40 km west of Zemio.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column17: 23 October. MNLC members shot at three civilians on a motorcycle in Lepourou, seriously injuring one.

23 October. PK 5 residents and others from the 3rd district demonstrated against a petition for the removal of Karim Mchassoua, the President of the National Assembly. Mechassoua, a Muslim, was seen as a balancing force against the Christian presidency. His dismissal is viewed by some as an attempt by President Touadera to concentrate his control and created a fall out in PK5 and among the CNDS ex-Seleka coalition.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 26 October. The National Assembly removed Karim Mechassoua, the President of the Assembly. Mechassoua, a Muslim, was seen as a balancing force against the Christian presidency. His dismissal is viewed by some as an attempt by President Touadera to concentrate his control. The following day, the CNDS (a coalition of ex-Seleka groups) urged all groups associated with the government to vacate the areas under their control within 48 hours, although a separate statement issued by FPRC denied this ultimatum.

column6: MNLC: National Movement for the Liberation of the Central African Republic
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 26 October. Suspected MNLC members attacked three FACA soldiers, who were being deployed to Bembere. The attackers abducted one of the soldiers. The soldier later escaped on 28/10.

column6: CNDS: Coalition for National Defense and Security
column17: 26 October. Sporadic gunshots heard for a few minutes in PK5, Bambari and Bria following the dismissal of Mechassoua. Mechassoua, a Muslim, was seen as a balancing force against the Christian presidency. His dismissal is viewed by some as an attempt by President Touadera to concentrate his control and created a fall out in PK5 and among the CNDS ex-Seleka coalition.

column6: CNDS: Coalition for National Defense and Security
column17: 26 October. Sporadic gunshots heard for a few minutes in PK5, Bambari and Bria following the dismissal of Mechassoua. Mechassoua, a Muslim, was seen as a balancing force against the Christian presidency. His dismissal is viewed by some as an attempt by President Touadera to concentrate his control and created a fall out in PK5 and among the CNDS ex-Seleka coalition.

column6: CNDS: Coalition for National Defense and Security
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 26 October. Gunmen fired at a MINUSCA check-point along the Bambari-Alindo road. The gunmen are suspected to be linked to members of the CNDS coalition as the attack followed the dismissal of Karim Mechassoua from the National Assembly.

column6: CNDS: Coalition for National Defense and Security
column17: 26 October. Sporadic gunshots heard for a few minutes in PK5, Bambari and Bria by suspected ex-Selekas of the CNDS coalition. This followed the dismissal of Karim Mechassoua from the National Assembly. Mechassoua, a Muslim, was seen as a balancing force against the Christian presidency. His dismissal is viewed by some as an attempt by President Touadera to concentrate his control and created a fall out in PK5 and among the CNDS ex-Seleka coalition.

29 October. During a parliamentary dispute, MP Alfred Yekatom fired a gun into the air before running away. He was later arrested. Yekatom is the representative of the M'baiki district and a former anti-Balaka leader.
On Oct 30, clashes were reported between unidentified groups in Banangui.

column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 30 October. Eight suspected ex-Seleka combatants (likely MPC or FPRC) attacked two adults, one teenager, and a child along the Bouca road, 17-19 km south of Batangafo. The child escaped as the attackers killed the others.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; UN Panel of Experts
column17: 31 October. FACA and MINUSCA forces clashed with the UPC in the el Haji neighborhood of Bambari. At least 12 people were injured.
31 October. Anti-Balaka combatants stabbed and wounded two Fulani civilians in the Lakouanga neighborhood of Batangafo.

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Muslim Group (Central African Republic)
column17: 31 October. In the morning, unidentified perpetrators attacked a local Muslim MSF employee with a machete in an IDP camp in Batangafo.

column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa; Muslim Militia (Central African Republic)
column17: 31 October. Armed groups (likely MPC, FPRC and Muslim militias vs Anti Balakas), clashed in Batangafo, forcing over 10,000 residents to seek refuge in the city's hospital while others fled to the bush.

column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa; Muslim Militia (Central African Republic)
column17: 31 October. Following two separate attacks on Muslims and Fulani the same morning (coded separately), the MPC, FPRC and armed Muslims attacked IDP camps, homes, the church and the market in Batangafo. IDP camps were targeted as the attackers suspected Anti-Balaka of hiding in them. Eleven people were killed and 37 were injured. Investigations that the attackers sought to permanently remove IDPs from the town by destroying the camps but the perpetrators instructed women and children IDPs to flee their huts before they were set on fire, elderly and disabled persons accounted for the majority of fatalities according to MSF.

column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 01 November. The FPRC and MPC continued their attacks on IDP camps, homes, the church and the market in Batangafo. 15 fatalities (11 civilians and four Anti-Balaka) were reported between 31/10- 11/11, the UN reported 11 during the initial attack on 31/10 and the remaining four are disaggregated between incidents reported on 01/11, 05/11, and 06/11.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 02 November. UPC forces attacked MINUSCA forces in Bambari.

column9: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 05 November. Anti-Balaka forces clashed with the MPC and FPRC in Batangafo. 15 fatalities (11 civilians and four Anti-Balaka) were reported between 31/10- 11/11, the UN reported 11 during the initial attack on 31/10 and the remaining four are disaggregated between incidents reported on 01/11, 05/11, and 06/11.
05 November (on or around). Two bodies were discovered near Maboussou. They had been killed with automatic weapons.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 05 November (on or around). MINUSCA and FACA have increased their patrols in Bambari, following attacks on the town by the UPC the week prior.

column7: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 05 November. A group of retired soldiers demonstrated in front of the Prime Minister's office in Bangui over the government's failure to provide retirement benefits.

column9: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 06 November. Clashes continued between Anti-Balaka forces and the FPRC and MPC in Batangafo. 15 fatalities (11 civilians and four Anti-Balaka) were reported between 31/10- 11/11, the UN reported 11 during the initial attack on 31/10 and the remaining four are disaggregated between incidents reported on 01/11, 05/11, and 06/11.
07 November. LRA members fired on three men, including two ex-Seleka combatants, 8km southwest of Bani. The LRA killed the motorcycle driver and injured one ex-Seleka member.
07 November. LRA ambushed a man and woman traveling on the Bria-Mbangana road eight km southeast of Bani. They stole goods from the couple and held them until later in the day.

column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); UN: United Nations
column17: ""One male national UN contracted staff member was shot and killed during an ambush. He was travelling on the road between Bassangoa and Paoua when his truck carrying food items was ambushed by unknown assailants.""

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On Nov 12, UPC militants held hostage 6 members of the Islamic committee for negotiation in Gbokolobo, located 60 km away from Bambari on the way toward Alindao. They were released two days later.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On Nov 13, a joint force of the Central African army and UN soldiers reportedly attacked UPC combatants in the Bornou and Hadji neighbourhoods of Bambari, destroying their base their and overtaking the areas. UPC combatants fled to other parts of Bambari.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On Nov 13, following defeats against the Central African army and UN soldiers in the Bornou and Hadji neighbourhoods of Bambari, UPC combatants moved to the Mbrepou and Maidou areas, where they expelled residents from their homes and occupied them.
On Nov 14, civil servants from Bangui stormed the Ministry of Finance and Budget to ask for parts of their salaries that had not been paid since 2003.

column9: Muslim Group (Central African Republic); Farmers (Central African Republic)
column17: 14 November. Anti-Balaka killed a Muslim farmer at the outskirts of Alindao (1km away).
On Nov 14, clashes were reported between unidentified groups in Banangui.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: In the week of Nov 12, a merchant was killed in Sam-Ouandja by unidentified gunmen on the Ouada-Djalle-Sam-Ouandja road.

column9: Refugees/IDPs (Central African Republic); Christian Group (Central African Republic)
column17: 15 November. After the UPC and Mujahedin militia had finished attacking the IDP camp in Alindao, Anti-Balaka fighters returned and looted the remaining goods in the camp.

column9: Muslim Group (Central African Republic); Taxi Drivers (Central African Republic)
column17: 15 November. Anti-Balaka ambushed a Muslim moto-taxi driver at the outskirts of Alindao, killing two of his passengers.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On Nov 15, Anti-Balaka fighters attacked Muslim civilians in the town of Alindao, prompting a reaction from UPC fighters. The UPC, along with members of a local militia calling themselves the Mujahedin, attacked an IDP camp hosting around 20,000 Christians which the Anti-Balaka operated out of. The UPC also brought civilians into the camps during the attacks, but it is unclear if they were used as shields to prevent a reaction from MINUSCA or if the civilians participated in the attack. The Anti-Balaka clashed with the UPC in the camp but ran out of ammunition, at which point UPC forces overran the site. At least 112 people were killed in these incidents (MINUSCA obtained in-depth information on at least 69 victims, while the rest of the names were given by local humanitarian organisations) , with no more precision about the nature of the dead (civilian or combatant) apart from two priests - fatalities split across three distinct events.

On Nov 15, Anti-Balaka fighters attacked Muslim civilians in the town of Alindao, prompting a reaction from UPC fighters. The UPC, along with members of a local militia calling themselves the Mujahedin, attacked an IDP camp hosting around 20,000 Christians which the Anti-Balaka operated out of. The UPC also brought civilians into the camps during the attacks, but it is unclear if they were used as shields to prevent a reaction from MINUSCA or if the civilians participated in the attack. The Anti-Balaka clashed with the UPC in the camp but ran out of ammunition, at which point UPC forces overran the site. At least 112 people were killed in these incidents (MINUSCA obtained in-depth information on at least 69 victims, while the rest of the names were given by local humanitarian organisations) , with no more precision about the nature of the dead (civilian or combatant) apart from two priests - fatalities split across three distinct events.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column9: Refugees/IDPs (Central African Republic); Christian Group (Central African Republic)
column17: On Nov 15, Anti-Balaka fighters attacked Muslim civilians in the town of Alindao, prompting a reaction from UPC fighters. The UPC, along with members of a local militia calling themselves the Mujahedin, attacked an IDP camp hosting around 20,000 Christians which the Anti-Balaka operated out of. The UPC also brought civilians into the camps during the attacks, but it is unclear if they were used as shields to prevent a reaction from MINUSCA or if the civilians participated in the attack. The Anti-Balaka clashed with the UPC in the camp but ran out of ammunition, at which point UPC forces overran the site. At least 112 people were killed in these incidents (MINUSCA obtained in-depth information on at least 69 victims, while the rest of the names were given by local humanitarian organisations) , with no more precision about the nature of the dead (civilian or combatant) apart from two priests - fatalities split across three distinct events.
01 - 30 November. During the month of November, 3R forces moved into Siriri territory in Nana Mambere, where they forcibly recruited Siriri members into 3R.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Siriri fighters attacked a UN base in Gbambia at 2000 GMT, sparking clashes that lasted for 45 minutes. A Tanzanian peacekeeper was injured and died from his injuries in the hospital.

On Nov 17, at 0200 GMT, unidentified gunmen attacked the HQs of Nimery Matar (""Force""), leader of the communal/vigilante PK5 militia, in the 3rd district of Bangui. Casualties were reported - unclear if fatalities or injuries.
On Nov 17, clashes were reported between unidentified groups in the Ouham region.

column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On Nov 17, at 0700 GMT, Seleka militiamen opened fire (seemingly at no target) as they were passing through the town of Batangafo, prompting a response from anti-balaka elements. 1 Seleka fighter was reported killed and 10 injured before UN forces arrived and stopped the clashes.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On Nov 17, clashes erupted between two CAR military engineering units following a dispute regarding the security and financial conditions of their work. 3 soldiers were killed and 3 others injured.
On Nov 20, fire exchange in Bangui's PK5 area was reported. Although the source left the actors unidentified, it suggested that PK5 militiamen were likely to be involved.

On Nov 20, Muslim PK5 militiamen held a small protest in Bangui's PK5 area holding signs against Russian presence in the country. This took place after an attack on the HQs of PK5 leader ""Force"" on Nov 17, which some attributed to a Russian drone.

On Nov 21, the targeting of 2 Muslim youngsters in the PK5 neighbourhood by Miskime militiamen sparked wider clashes in the area, which involved gunfire and grenades, and resulted in the death of 2 people and the injury of 6.
On Nov 21, militiamen from Bangui's Miskine Christian neighbourhood carried out a knife attack targeting 2 Muslim youngsters in the PK5 neighbourhood. This sparked wider clashes.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 22 November. UPC forces clashed with Anti-Balaka in Banangui. Twenty-five homes were burned during the clash and thousands of residents fled.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 22 November. Anti-Balaka forces attacked a MINUSCA post in the Alindao IDP camp. The combatants exchanged fire with the peacekeepers for 30 minutes before hiding within the camp. One civilian was killed and one was injured.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme; AFP
column17: On Nov 22, fighters of the PK5 militia clashed with security forces in the 5th district of Bangui, leaving 4 killed (including a taxi driver) and 20 injured. Some reports alleged that CAR forces of the central office for the repression of banditry destroyed a PK5 base in the 5th district and gained control of the site but PK5 militiamen denied this version.
24 November. Two aid workers were abducted by an armed group while traveling on the Bria-Irrabanda road. They were released on 03/12.
On November 25, in Bangui town (Bangui, Bangui), Mahamat Tahir, the leader of a Bangui militia was killed during an exchange of fire with a shop merchant who refused to obey his orders.

On November 27, in Bangui town (Bangui, Bangui), Bangui militia members shot and killed a trader to avenge the murder of Mahamat Tahir, the leader of a Bangui militia who was killed during an exchange of fire with a shop merchant two days priro.

On November 28, in Batangafo town (Batangafo, Ouham), Seleka militia members attempted to rob a weapons cache from Anti-Balaka members. An Anti-Balaka member was found killed after the incident, likely armed.
03 December. LRA members attacked a diamond mine near Pambayamba. A local ex-Seleka group responded and repelled the LRA.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 03 December. The Be-Afrika Association protested against the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Charles Armel Doubane, in Bangui. They called for the minister's removal after he declined to participate in 01/12 festivities.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 04 December. UPC and Anti-Balaka fighters clashed in Ippy.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 04 December. UPC forces opened fire at IDPs at an IDP camp at the Catholic Church in Ippy. Serious injuries occurred. The UPC denied responsibility for the attack and claimed that bandits in a dispute with a group of armed Fulani herders fled to the site and falsely accused the UPC of attacking them.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 04 December. FACA forces arrived in Bocaranga but after being threatened by Abbas Sidiki (3R) - whose forces are stationed 5km from the city - the soldiers left the city.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 05 December. The UPC set fire to the IDP camp at the Catholic Church in Ippy, which they attacked the day prior. Three people were killed.

column6: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 08 December. Police in Bambari arrested Didier Wangai, the second in command of the UPC, for human rights abuses. This reportedly came after the UPC refused to vacate the town.
10 December. A LRA group attacked Ketesia (no coordinates available) in Obo, Haut Mbomou. The group looted supplies and abducted two children. Most of the villagers then fled into the bush.
10 December. Sidiki's 3R forces took up position at the entrance of Bocaranga town. They also moved into strategic positions across Ouham Pende and have blocked the Bocaranga-Bohong road.
13 December. The chief of Pounebanda and his son were killed by an armed group. Over 700 residents fled after the attack.

column16: Twitter; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 13 December. Following the arrest of former Anti-Balaka leader, Edourdo Ngaissona in France, Maxime Mokom released a statement withdrawing his faction's participation in DDR programs and peace negotiations. Ngaissona's faction also released a statement calling for its representatives to withdraw from the DDR program.
14 December. An armed group looted a humanitarian convoy at Ngadza Toko, along the Kouango-Bianga axis. Humanitarian activities along the road have been suspended following the incident.

16 December. A group of LRA members (including three women with babies) ambushed two men and a woman who were on a motorbike 5km west of Guerekindo. The perpetrators killed one of the men, injured the woman, and stole their belongings.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 16 December. Clashes between the Goula and Ronga or FPRC and RPRC (both ex-Seleka) in Charahibou, 85km from Birao, near the border with Sudan. According to local sources, the Ronga accused the Goula of promoting the government's DDR process. At least five killed.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 16-24 December. Tensions rose between the Goula and Ronga or FPRC and RPRC (both ex-Seleka) after the FPRC arrested some MLCJ in a camp in the Ouadda-Djalle area. Clashes averted by the intervention of local security forces.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 17 December. The government launched a DDR program in Paoua. Participant groups are expected to include RF factions of Armel Sayo and Belenga (although there is some reports that this is a contentious issue within the Belenga faction), the UFR, and two Anti-Balaka groups.

column7: APPAP: Alliance of Parties, Personalities and Political Associations
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 19 December. Members of the APPAP demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to show their support for the government and Khartoum negotiations.
22 December. An armed group broke into a humanitarian base in Batangafo and stole goods.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: 24 December. 3R forces stormed the Gendarmerie base in Bohong and released two Chadian detainees.
26 December. The bodies of four men who were missing for a week were discovered at the bottom of a well in Bambari. Some locals suspect that the UPC was responsible for the deaths.

column7: RRR: Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation; Pastoralists (Central African Republic)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 26 December. Armed clash between herders allied to 3R and farmers in Bocarange after a dispute over land damage by their cattle. A gendarme who intervened during the clash was assaulted by the 3R chief.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 27 December. UPC and FPRC forces moved into Bakouma (a mining town). Some local sources report they began arriving on 24/12. There are no security or MINUSCA forces in the town, so many civilians fled into the bush.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 31 December (on or around). The UPC implemented a taxation system for all residents living in areas under their control. In addition to individual resident taxes, fees are also imposed on herders, car owners, farmers, and other small business owners.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 31 December. UPC and FPRC forces attacked Bakouma and clashed with Anti-Balaka and FACA forces. At least a dozen people were killed (coded as 12), including Sultan Madambari, who had ties to Anti-Balaka forces. Homes were burned and property was looted. Many of the residents fled as the UPC and FPRC took control of the town. Joint MINUSCA/FACA forces deployed the next day to initiate talks.

column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 02 January. Moussa Sair (Emperor), a ranking member of the KM5-Force militia was killed during a clash with LT, the leader of another KM5 militia. The clash occurred over the control of a parking area.

column7: GSTC: Trade Union Group of Central African Workers
column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 03 January. Members of the GSTC attempted to gather in Bangui for a demonstration, in conjunction with a three day strike over salaries, but were dispersed by police.
04 January. Women and children barricaded the road 10km outside of Bakouma to call for the protection of MINUSCA/FACA forces and denounce the occupation of Bakouma by the FPRC/UPC.
04 January. An armed group ambushed and assaulted humanitarian workers 18 km north of Bria along the Irabanda road.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 04 January. The FPRC ordered Bakouma government officials to vacate the town four days after gaining control of the town from the Anti-Balaka and military forces (coded in a separate event).
05 January. During an attempted robbery, an armed group shot and killed a security guard at an NGO office in Batangafo.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 05 January (on or before). UPC/FPRC forces gained control of the village of Dimbe (no coordinate available), 5km from Bakouma (clashes assumed considering the presence of Anti-Balaka and military forces all around Bakouma).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 05 January (on or around). During the FPRC's occupation of Bakouma (from late December until 16/01), 32 people were killed - including five women. 20 fatalities coded in two separate VAC events in January and 12 fatalities included in armed clash reported on December 31st.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: UN: United Nations; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: 06 January. FPRC forces undertook 'policing' in Bria and detained/abducted 13 people, including six national UN employees. The abductees were later released following negotiations.

06 January. Clashes occurred between an ex-Seleka group (likely the FPRC which is active in the area) and a group of Fulani herders near Birao. The clash occurred when the ex-Seleka group detained a herder for carrying weapons, they took the herder to the Geremandier. The detainees relative then stabbed one of the members of the ex-Seleka group, sparking a clash which left seven wounded.

column9: Farmers (Central African Republic); Women (Central African Republic)
column17: 07 January 2019. The LRA abducted four women from their fields in Koumboli, Zemio. The assailants released the abductees later that day.
07 January. Residents of Bangassou protested the violence in neighboring Bakouma and called for the withdrawal of armed groups from the near by town.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 07 January. FACA forces were redeployed to Bocaranga. They had initially vacated the city in December under threats from 3R. 3R withdrew from the city and moved their forces back to Koui (their strong-hold).

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 08 January. 3R attacked Bokayan, killing at least five people. A joint FACA/MINUSCA force was deployed the same night in response.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column7: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 08 January. During the night UPC/FPRC forces, occupying Bakouma, clashed with Anti-Balaka forces in the town. Anti-Balaka forces reportedly gained control of part of the city.

column9: Health Workers (Central African Republic); Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: 08 January. An armed group ransacked a health facility in Gbadene. The local population fled during the attack. The aid organization supporting the facility has suspended operations in the town.
09 January. Four people were killed in KM 5, in retaliation for the earlier grenade attack against Fulanis that killed two.

column9: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Pastoralists (Central African Republic)
column17: 09 January. A grenade was thrown into a truck of Fulani herders, on the road between Bangui and Boali. Two people were killed.

10 January (on or around). Armed groups clashed in Bokagnan (coordinates are approximate based on location being 45 km east of Bouar, along the Bouar-Bozoum road). Over 1,000 residents were displaced.
10 January. An armed group robbed humanitarian workers 30 km north of Bouar. The perpetrators stole money intended for beneficiaries and personal belongings.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-); MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-); Military Forces of France (2017-)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 10 January. On a day of festivities in Bambari, the UPC launched attacks on the city and clashed with security forces. Two police officers and several UPC fighters were killed (unknown number on UPC side coded as 3).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 10 January (on or around). During the FPRC's occupation of Bakouma (from late December until 16/01), 32 people were killed - including five women. 20 fatalities coded in two separate VAC events in January and 12 fatalities included in armed clash reported on December 31st.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-); Military Forces of France (2017-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme; AFP
column17: 11 January. Fighting between MINUSCA and security forces against the UPC continued in Bambari. France deployed two fighter jets over the city in a 'show of force.' MSF reported four wounded and one fatality during the day. Additional UPC fighters were reported around Bambari in the next days, entering the city in civilian attire and vehicles.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 11 January. A trader in Ouanda Djalle threw a grenade at local authorities who were arguing if they should turn taxes they collected to the government offices or to armed groups. One person was killed by the grenade and others were injured.
12 January. An unidentified armed group killed three Fulani, including two women, near Zaorossoungou.

column7: Private Security Forces (Russia); Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 11 January - 15 January. FACA forces detained a trader in Bambari, who was accused by locals of being an ex-Seleka member. The man was then taken to a FACA base, where Russian mercenaries, believed to be from the Wagner group, detained and tortured the man using knives, chains, bricks and batons. The man was later freed by Internal Security Forces. The UN has launched an investigation.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column7: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 16 January. After loosing Bakouma to MINUSCA and FACA forces, the UPC and FPRC forces retreated to Nzako and established a base there.

column7: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 16 January. UPC supporters marched in Bambari to denounce the MINUSCA/FACA operations against the group.

column7: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 16 January. Retired soldiers demonstrated in Bangui over delayed payments and benefits. The group barricaded roads in the city.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column9: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 16 January. A joint MINUSCA-FACA force regained control of Bakouma after an early morning incursion into the town. Bakouma had been occupied by the UPC and FPRC since the end of December.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 17 January. MINUSCA forces clashed with the UPC in the Bornou and Hadji neighborhoods of Bambari. UPC movements were observed around Bambari in previous days.
18 January. An armed group carried out four robberies in the Beta and Saint-Jean neighborhoods. The perpetrators killed two people, including a humanitarian worker.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 19 January. Following the attack on two civilians by the UPC, MINUSCA and UPC forces in Bambari clashed in the Bornou and Elevage areas of the town. The UPC is reportedly hiding amongst the local civilian population in the city.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Teachers (Central African Republic)
column17: 19 January. UPC forces killed an ACTED employee and a teacher in Bambari.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: 20 January. Sidiki's 3R forces and armed Fulani attacked Zaoro Sangou, killing at least 13 people including two gendarmerie soldiers (some sources indicated 14 fatalities).
22 January. After a robber killed two children, local residents caught the robber and killed him.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; La Nouvelle Centrafrique
column17: 23 January. MINUSCA responded to a rocket attack by UPC forces. The groups clashed in the Hadji and Bornou neighborhoods of Bambari. Three civilians (including two children) were killed in the clashes.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 24 January. A drunken UPC soldier opened fire on civilians at a funeral in the Djama-Yakania neighborhood of Ippy. 13 civilians were killed and approximately 20 others were shot and injured (other sources indicate a greater number of casualties).

column16: La Nouvelle Centrafrique; Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: 24 January. Bambari residents protested in front of the MINUSCA base with the three bodies of civilians killed during clashes between the peacekeepers and the UPC the night prior.
24 January. An Anti-Balaka group killed three civilians, including a woman and child, along a road near Alindao.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 25 January. The UPC commander in Ippy executed the UPC soldier who killed 13 civilians the day prior.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 26 January. After fleeing Bambari, UPC fighters killed two civilians in Yamalet (no coordinates available), 30 km from Bambari along the Bambari-Balaka road.

column9: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Pastoralists (Central African Republic)
column17: 28 January. LRA forces attacked a Fulani family 42 km southeast of Sam Ouandja, Haute Kotto. The assailants abducted two boys and stole four cattle. One of the boys was later released after the attackers severely assaulted him.
28 January. An unidentified armed group robbed an NGO team in Gbadene, Ouham.

28 January. Thousands of protesters demonstrated in Bangui, calling for the removal of the arms embargo on the country. The embargo expires on 30/01. On 31/01 the UN announced that it extended the embargo until September 2019.
29 January. An unidentified armed group robbed humanitarian workers in Boguidi, Ouham.

29 January. Residents of Berberati protested calling for the removal of the arms embargo on the country. The embargo expires on 30/01. On 31/01 the UN announced that it extended the embargo until September 2019.

30 January. Thousands of protesters gathered in Bossangoa to demonstrate against the arms embargo currently imposed on the country. The embargo expires on 30/01. On 31/01 the UN announced that it extended the embargo until September 2019.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Prison Guards
column17: 31 January. During the night, 18 prisoners escaped from the Mbaiki prison.
01 February. An unidentified armed group moved into Dogo (no coordinates available; 10 km from Bouar). FACA deployed in response but were unable to access the village.
02 February. A convoy of humanitarian vehicles was looted by an armed group 5 km south of Kaga Bandoro.

05 - 19 February. An unidentified armed group abducted and killed 14 civilians in the area surrounding Obo town during this period. This includes five South Sudanese street traders stabbed to death on the 19th. Coded as three events on each week with the fatalities spread across the three events.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Prison Guards
column17: 06 February. Seven prisoners escaped from the Carnot prison, by breaking through a wall.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column9: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa; Anti-Balaka (Mokom Faction); Anti-Balaka (Ngaissona Faction); FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic; MLCJ: Movement of Central African Liberators for Justice; MPC: Movement for Progressive Change; RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People; RRR: Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation; RJ: Revolution and Justice (Belanga Faction); RJ: Revolution and Justice (Aile Sayo Faction); SR: Seleka Renewal; UFR: Union of Republican Forces; UFR: Union of Republican Forces (Fundamental Faction)
column17: 06 February. 14 armed groups signed a peace agreement with the CAR government in Bangui. The agreement calls for the establishment of an 'inclusive' government, as well as the creation of a truth and reconciliation commission.

08 February. Suspected Sudanese poachers killed three Fulani, including a 9 year old child, 20 km outside of Obo. The assailants also robbed two non-Muslims in the area, who returned to Obo and reported the event to MINUSCA. The family of the Fulani victims suspect the involvement of those who reported the incident. However, there is a long-standing dispute between Fulani and Sudanese poachers which others report as the reasoning for the killing of the Fulani and release of the Christians.

column7: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 11 February. Retired soldiers demonstrated in Bangui over the delay of payments owed to them by the government.
12 February 2019. An LRA group - consisting of five women and five men - attacked Ligoua, Haut-Mbomou. The assailants looted goods and abducted three people, including one child.

05 - 19 February. An unidentified armed group abducted and killed 14 civilians in the area surrounding Obo town during this period. This includes five South Sudanese street traders stabbed to death on the 19th. Coded as three events on each week with the fatalities spread across the three events.
13 February. LRA combatants attacked Ligoua, Obo. The perpetrators looted the town and abducted three civilians.
18 February 2019. An unidentified armed group shot at a man and woman on a bike along the Bria-Nzako road, near Manzala. The man was injured.
18 February. Five trader went missing. Their bodies were discovered on 23/02 near Bozongui, Haut Mbomou. The bodies appeared to have been murdered.

05 - 19 February. An unidentified armed group abducted and killed 14 civilians in the area surrounding Obo town during this period. This includes five South Sudanese street traders stabbed to death on the 19th. Coded as three events on each week with the fatalities spread across the three events.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 20 February. The humanitarian corridor along the Mobaye-Kongbo road in Basse-Kotto was reopened following an agreement between the local government and armed groups (UPC and Anti-Balaka).
21 February 2019. The LRA looted food and goods at the Chantier Confluent mine, 25 km north of Mbangana while civilians fled.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 21 February. A police officer stopped three men on a motorbike at a checkpoint in Boda. One of the passengers had a weapon, which the police ordered the man to surrender. When the man refused, the police shot and killed two of the men.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: 21 February. After a police officer shot and killed two people at a checkpoint, angry youth in Boda burned the Gendarmerie barracks and ransacked police station and customs office. Number of demonstrators not reported.
23 February 2019. The LRA ambushed and looted four traders, 18 km from Pambayamba, Haute-Kotto.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 24 February. After the death of Mandakara, an Anti-Balaka leader, the group clashed with the UPC in Kouango. Several casualties reported.

column7: ANECA: National Central African Students Association; Students (Central African Republic)
column9: ANECA: National Central African Students Association; Students (Central African Republic)
column17: 26 February. Members of the ANECA vandalized the organization's office in Bangui, following an internal dispute over the requirements to run for president of the organization.
On 27 February 2019, unidentified armed men assaulted and injured 1 INGO staff member in Bria (Bria, Haute-Kotto) during an incursion into an INGO's project site.

column6: Police Forces of Central African Republic (2016-) Customs Office
column17: 27 February. A customs official shot and killed an economic operator in the customs office in Gamboula. An investigation was launched into the shooting.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 01 March (on or around). KM5 militiamen led by Mahamat alias LT injured a Muslim soldier and the leader of a Muslim youth group in Bangui.
01 March. Two 3R militia members shot and killed a motor taxi driver in Makouzi Ouali (no coordinates available), 20 km from Bocaranga. The assailants then stole the victim's motorcycle.
02 March. 3R combatants killed three hunters and injured a fourth in Bouzou, Ouham Pende.

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 03 March 2019. Members of a self-defense group in Boulangba seized the weapon of a UPC commander in Boulangba, Basse Kotto. The event triggered clashes with the UPC (coded separately).
03 March 2019. The LRA looted 10 civilians a long a road near the Yangou Bakoya mine (approx. Coordinates based on location 68 km east of Sam Ouandja and shown on source map).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column7: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 03 March. Following the unveiling of the new government ministries, as part of the Khartoum agreement, the FPRC and FDPC both withdrew from participation in the new government. The UPC expressed similar displeasure with the new prime minister, Firmin Ngrebada (a close ally of Touadera) but did not withdraw from the process.
03 May 2019. An unidentified armed group looted civilians between the PK 3 IDP camp and Gbadou bridge in Bria.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 04 March 2019. UPC forces abducted Soulemane Daouda, the Livestock and Health Minister, in Gbokologbo (no coordinates available; 60 km from Alindao).
05 March. An unidentified ""rebel"" group from CAR blocked the road between Bouar in CAR and Garoua - Boulai in Cameroon.
07 March 2019. The Boulangba self-defense militia robbed a trader who was leaving the Boulangba, Basse Kotto to travel to Mobaye. The event triggered clashes with the UPC (coded separately).

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 07 and 9 March 2019. The Boulangba self-defense militia clashed with UPC forces in Boulangba and Kandia in Basse Kotto (unclear if clashes in both villages on both days; coded as two events, one in Boulangba prec1 on 7 March, one in Boulangba prec2 on 9 March as no coordinates available for Kandia). Houses were also burned down. Six combatants - five from the self-defense group and one UPC fighter- were killed during the clashes. The fatalities are spread between the two events.

08 March (on or before). KM5 militiamen led by Mahamat alias LT clashed with street traders in the KM 5 market in Bangui. The clash occurred as LT's members sought to extort money from the traders. Grenades and automatic weapons were utilized during the clash.

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 09 March. Anti-Balaka combatants shot at two FPRC members who were riding on motor-taxis a few kilometers from Bria. Both of the FPRC members, as well as one of the motor bike drivers were seriously injured.

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 07 and 9 March 2019. The Boulangba self-defense militia clashed with UPC forces in Boulangba and Kandia in Basse Kotto (unclear if clashes in both villages on both days; coded as two events, one in Boulangba prec1 on 7 March, one in Boulangba prec2 on 9 March as no coordinates available for Kandia). Houses were also burned down. Six combatants - five from the self-defense group and one UPC fighter- were killed during the clashes. The fatalities are spread between the two events.

column7: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: 09 March 2019 (on or before). FDPC elements blocked the Bouar-Garoua-Boulai road at Beloko in a demonstration against the newly appointed government ministers. They ended the blockade on 10/03. [size=no report]

column7: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: 09 March 2019 (on or before). FDPC elements blocked the Bouar-Garoua-Boulai road at Baboua in a demonstration against the newly appointed government ministers. They ended the blockade on 10/03. [size=no report]

11 - 21 March. An unidentified armed group blocks the road between Bangui and Garoua Boulay of Cameroon for 10 days, leaving many drivers stranded. Rebel groups claim the current presidential cabinet is not representative of the population.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Labour Group (Central African Republic)
column17: 12 March 2019 (on or around). FPRC combatants assaulted a male youth who was part of a team drilling a well for Oxfam in Piya, Haute Kotto. The attackers accused the youth of stealing and took him to their base in Calvere, where they tortured him to death.
14 March 2019. Recent graduates protested in Bangui against the inclusion of armed actors in government positions. [size=no report]

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 14 March 2019. Residents of Bangui's 2nd arrondissement voluntarily surrendered weapons as part of a MINUSCA DDR program. 18 arms, as well as explosives and ammunition were surrendered.
Between January and June [coded to 15 March], across CAR, unidentified armed groups have reportedly killed at least 241 civilians.

""One national INGO employee was shot and wounded by two armed assailants while reportedly distributing food near Bamara-Kassai (17km North of Batangafo). The staff member was evacuated to Batangafo for medical attention, and the assailants fled before a UN patrol arrived.""

column7: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 17 March 2019. The FDPC reinstalled their barricade along the Bouar-Beloko road near Zoukombo. MINUSCA peacekeepers were deployed to convince the group to remove the blockade. [size=no report]

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 17 March 2019. During the night, two UPC members - a commander and a lieutenant - were captured and killed by unknown gunmen while traveling through the PK3 IDP camp in Bria.
18 March 2019. Recent graduates protested in Bangui against the inclusion of armed actors in government positions. [size=no report]

column7: Students (Central African Republic); ANECA: National Central African Students Association
column9: Students (Central African Republic); ANECA: National Central African Students Association
column17: 18 March 2019. Members of the National Association of Central African Students threw rocks at each other following elections within the organization at the University of Bangui. Police dispersed the groups. [size=no report]

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme; Corbeau News; Radio Ndeke Luka
column17: 19 March 2019. During the night, suspected elements of 3R killed the mayor of Kounde and his son. Some sources report three fatalities.

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 20 March 2019. Following the murder of the Mayor of Kounde, 3R clashed with a communal defense group in Kounde. Six fatalities reported, including one 3R combatant.

column6: Kella Doukou Communal Militia (Central African Republic)
column17: 22 March 2019 (on or before). After a group of Fulani pastoralists killed a farmer in Kella Doukou, angry residents or Anti-Balaka combatants (conflicting reports of perpetrators) attacked and killed the Fulani militias. Total fatalities unknown,.
22 March 2019 (on or before). A group of armed Fulani pastoralists killed a farmer in Kella Doukou, Nana Mambere following a dispute over their herds grazing on the victim's land.
22 March 2019 (on or before). Following the attack on Fulani pastoralist in Kella Doukou, 3R forces mobilized around the town. The group blames the Anti-Balaka for the attack on the Fulani.

26 March 2019. Suspected Anti-Balaka forces raided the Danga village (no coordinates available, located in the Damara district- 65 km from Bangui). The assailants fired shots and went door-to-door abducting four civilians. More than 1,000 local residents fled to the bush and Bangui.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 27 March 2019. An unidentified group assaulted the Minister of Youth and Sports, Lionel Dounda, outside of his office in Bangui.
28 March 2019. An armed group shot and killed a hunter in the Lybi area (no coordinates available, located near Sibut along the Damara road). Locals have accused pastoralists in the area.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column7: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-); MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 29 March 2019. The FACA Gendarmerie, police force, and MINUSCA retrieved weapons including grenades, ammunition, and two automatic weapons from the 4th arrondissement of Bangui. The weapons had been buried underground and were discovered by youth who were working on the property.

""One national INGO staff member was injured when armed assailants reportedly began shooting at the group riding motorcycles around 1:10pm. The staff member and 3 others were travelling near the town of Pavika on the Alindao-Bangassou axis, when their group was attacked on the road. The injured staff member was admitted to a local hospital for treatment.""

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 01 April 2019. Six soldiers assaulted a moto-taxi driver until he lost consciousness in Bouar.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Prison Guards
column17: 01 April 2019. Prisoners tried to escape breaking their cells' doors in a prison in Bangui. Police forces intervened and restored order. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (Central African Republic); GSTC: Central African Workers Syndicate
column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: 01 April 2019. The GSTC gathered to hold a demonstration calling for increased wages for government employees, but police and Gendarmerie dispersed the protesters.[size=no report]

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: 01 April 2019 (on or around). The FDPC seized a number of vehicles, which reportedly belonged to a national company. The assailants then demanded a ransom for the release of the vehicles. This triggered clashes with the MINUSCA a few days later.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 03 April 2019 (on or around). The UPC clashed with a community defense group in the Zanga sub-prefecture. This triggered four days of attacks by the UPC on villages in the area (coded separately).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 04 April 2019 (on or before). The FPRC systematically extorted aid organizations and civilian drivers in Bria, taxing them on all vehicles and drivers licenses.

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
column17: 04 April 2019. An unidentified armed group stopped a local MSF staff member as he was traveling from Batangafo to Bouca. The assailants held the victim captive in the bush before killing him.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 04-08 April 2019. Following clashes with a self-defense militia in Zangba, the UPC burned down 19 villages and killed 100 people in the Zangba territory. The fatalities are spread across five days of attacks - including 18 fatalities reported on 4 April in villages including Kesse, Gbari, Yambourou, Yaligo, and Yeou. The attacks prompted a large-scale displacement of the local population.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: 05 April 2019. MINUSCA attacked FDPC forces in Zoukombo. The operation came in response to the seizure and ransoming of 11 transportation vehicles by the militia. Five militia members were killed. Most of the local civilian population fled.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 04-08 April 2019. Following clashes with a self-defense militia in Zangba, the UPC burned down 19 villages and killed 100 people in the Zangba territory. The fatalities are spread across five days of attacks - including 18 fatalities reported on 4 April in villages including Kesse, Gbari, Yambourou, Yaligo, and Yeou. The attacks prompted a large-scale displacement of the local population.

column17: 06 April 2019. An unidentified armed group killed the mayor of the Cocho-Toulou district and his accountant while they were traveling to Goya, Kouango.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 04-08 April 2019. Following clashes with a self-defense militia in Zangba, the UPC burned down 19 villages and killed 100 people in the Zangba territory. The fatalities are spread across five days of attacks - including 18 fatalities reported on 4 April in villages including Kesse, Gbari, Yambourou, Yaligo, and Yeou. column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 06 April 2019. FDPC forces ambushed MINUSCA forces in Zoukombo, injuring one peacekeeper.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column8: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: 08 April 2019. The FACA clashed with FDPC combatants in Foro, Baboua. Three militia members were killed and one commander was captured.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 04-08 April 2019. Following clashes with a self-defense militia in Zangba, the UPC burned down 19 villages and killed 100 people in the Zangba territory. The fatalities are spread across five days of attacks - including 18 fatalities reported on 4 April in villages including Kesse, Gbari, Yambourou, Yaligo, and Yeou.
