column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 09 April 2019. Following continued clashes with a self-defense group in the Zangba area, the UPC looted and burned 19 villages along the Zangba-Alindao road. 12 fatalities were reported in total - spread between two events (the clash and attack on civilians).

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 09 April 2019 (on or before). The UPC and Zangba self-defense militia clashed near the Zangba-Alindao road. Later they burned 19 villages. 12 fatalities were reported in total - spread between two events (the clash and attack on civilians).

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: 10 April 2019 (on or before). An unidentified armed group killed a police officer in Obo. Several killings have been reported in the area recently.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 13 April 2019. Two FPRC combatants got into an argument while collecting an extortion in Bria. One of the combatants shot and injured the other.

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: 15 April 2019. Ali Darassa, head of the UPC, participated in a 'symbolic' ceremony in Bambari, as part of his appointment as a military adviser as part of the Khartoum peace agreement.
18 April 2019. An unidentified armed group looted an NGO employee in Kalaya, Ouaka (no coordinates available; located 11 km from Mourouba).

19 April 2019. Bienvenu Guiambi and his combatants (described as a self-defense militia) ambushed several women from Zangba who were trying to cross the Oubangui River. The assailants killed the boat driver and abducted the women. Guiambi has demanded a CFA 150,000 ransom for each of the women.
19 April 2019. A group of armed pastoralists fired at two men who went to pick-up an ox they purchased 5 km from Amou, Kemo, killing one of the men and seriously injuring the other.
19 April 2019. Following an attack on two men by pastoralists, residents of Amau attacked the Fulani community. At least six people were killed and several houses were burned.

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column17: 22 April 2019. The FDPC attacked Lokoti, abducting 11 people. The assailants also destroyed a semi-truck and two motorcycles. The fate of the drivers is unknown.
28 April 2019. The LRA abducted two farmers 3 km from Zemio. The assailants released the abductees the next day.
29 April 2019. The LRA abducted three men near Finzane, Zemio.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: 29 April 2019. The FPRC clashed with three Janjaweed combatants in Birao. One Janjaweed was killed and one FPRC element was injured. The other Janjaweed combatants were captured and turned over to MINUSCA.

05 May 2019 (on or around). During the beginning of May, an armed group of Fulani abducted 10 people from Boganagone, Lobaye (no coordinates available). The attackers carried out the abductions in protest to the extortion of the Fulani community by the local government. After negotiations, the assailants released the abductees.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: 05 May 2019. FACA forces, escorted by MINUSCA, were deployed to Kaga-Bandoro. However, within hours of reaching the city, the military forces withdrew. According to a military source, the contingent was relocated to Dekoa.

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: 05 May 2019. MPC forces killed two civilians in Yagarandji, Kaga Bandoro.

07 May 2019. A mob caught a foreigner (nationality unspecified) suspected of robbing and killing a man the night before in Obo. The mob assaulted the man until MINUSCA and FACA intervened. [size=no report]

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: 08 May 2019. A group of armed Fulani killed a male youth in Bozoy 2, Paoua (no coordinates available).
On 5 August, in Sarki, 3R elements killed a young civilian.

09 May 2019. After a dispute between herders and farmers in Bokpangna, 3R combatants killed a farmer and injured four others in Bokpangna, Ouham Pende (coordinates are approximate based on location 57 km from Bozoum along the Bocaranga axis).
On 5 September, 3R forces entered in Benakoro, prompting the displacement of the local population.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 5 September, near Mingala, UPC forces clashed with an armed group and seized control of the Kolo gold mine.
12 May 2019. After the lynching of a thief, an armed group in PK5 neighborhood of Bangui carried out reprisal attacks in the neighborhood, killing at least two people.
12 May 2019 (on or before). A mob lynched a suspected thief, in a neighborhood next to the PK5 neighborhood of Bangui.

On 18 May, in Bangui, ex-Seleka combatants protested against arrest of one of their members by CAR Police by blocking one of the city roads. The arrest was caused by attempts of illegal installation of commercial kiosk [size=several dozen].

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 19 May, in Kaga-Bandoro, around 100 CAR soldiers have been deployed to the city controlled by FPRC. The leader of the FPRC has issued a statement that the troops have been deployed in violation of the Sudan Peace and Unity Accord on February 5.

column16: aBangui; Centrafrique Presse Info; Africa 1; AFP; BBC News; Le Potentiel; Corbeau News; RFI; VOA; Twitter; Cameroon Tribune; AP; Jeune Afrique
column17: On 21 May, in Koundjili, Djoumjoum and several other villages of Ouham Pende, 3R has attacked and massacred 50 civilians. The group is one of the 14 armed groups that signed the Sudan Peace and Unity Accord with the CAR government on February 5. The killings caused international outcry and statements by MINUSCA and CAR Government's ultimatum to the leader of the group to hand culprits.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: Radio Ndeke Luka; VOA; Twitter; AFP
column17: On 21 May, in Bangui, Russia has delivered 1st batch of arms and munition to CAR Armed Forces since arms embargo imposed on CAR in 2013.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 22 May, in Ippy, UPC militiamen have been extorting money from traders as payment for passage. The armed group's spokesperson refuted the accusations.

column16: Africa 1; Radio Ndeke Luka; Corbeau News; Twitter; Centrafrique Presse Info
column17: On 22 May, in Nola, unidentified armed group has killed and beheaded 77 y.o. French-Spanish aid worker and Catholic missionary who taught sewing to girls.
On 22 May, in Bohong, 3R has attacked and pillaged a village, killing 7 civilians and injuring 3. The inhabitants of the village have fled.

On 26 May, near Mboki, 2 LRA elements ambushed a young man, his wife, and child. They ordered the man to go buy them flour, while they held his family hostage. They also looted 2 other men. They released all of the victims once the man returned with the flour.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 26 May, in Paoua, FACA Capitan has shot several times at president of Paoua Youth in what is believed to be unsuccessful assassination attempt. MINUSCA Human Rights Section is monitoring the situation.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 26 May, in Bambari, UPC militiamen have been attacking and robbing local community members.

column6: PRNC: Party of the Rally of the Central African Nation
column17: On 28 May, in Ouaka area, factions of the FPRC dissatisfied with peace deal formed new armed group Parti du Rassemblement de la nation Centrafricaine (PRNC).
On 29 May, in Bambari, 50 people protested against rotation of MINUSCA troops and arrival of Mauritanian soldiers due to rumors of latter collaborating with ex-Seleka militia. [size=50]
On 2 June, in Paoua, several dozen of women protested against 3R killings in the city.[size=several dozen]
On 3 June, in Bambari, residents protested against rotation of Mauritanian contingent of MINUSCA. [size=unknown]

column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 4 June, in Bambari, Anti-Balaka has clashed with UPC. No reports on casualties.

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 6 June, in Bambari, a lifeless body of previously abducted civilian has been found.

column6: RJ: Revolution and Justice (Aile Sayo Faction)
column17: On 8 June, in unspecified location [coded to Bangui], Revolution and Justice (Aile Sayo Faction) Armed Group was completely disarmed.
On 10 June, in Obo, the LRA abducted 5 men. The victims had been forced to carry looted goods to the groups camp near the Mbomou River. The abductees were released by the LRA group on 13 June.

column9: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Pastoralists (Central African Republic); Farmers (Central African Republic)
column17: On 10 June, a suspected LRA group, comprised of men, women, and children, attacked a Peuhl camp 4 km northwest of Obo. The assailants stole 4 cattle from the victims. They also looted a nearby field. The farmers of the land fled upon sighting the armed group.

On 10 June, an LRA group, comprised of 3 armed men and 16 unarmed boys, looted fields southwest of Obo. The assailants held 14 civilians, including 2 mothers with 3 children, for several hours. The group released 9 of the civilians but abducted the 5 remaining men.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column16: La Libre Afrique; RFI; Twitter; Centrafrique Presse Info; aBangui; BBC News; AFP
column17: On 15 June, in Bangui, clashes of police with demonstrators during several thousand-strong demonstration. During the demonstration, two French journalists from AFP were brutally assaulted, arrested, and their equipment broken. [size=several thousand]

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: In June [coded to 15 June], 3 FACA soldiers have gang-raped and seriously injured a woman in Bozoum.

On 17 June, an LRA group, comprised of men, women, and children looted field camps 10 km southeast of Mboki. The assailants looted cassava, maize and peanuts. They spoke Acholi, Zande, and broken Sango. Some were armed with AK-47s.

On 18 June, in Kpabou [coordinates are approximate based on CT map], an LRA group, comprised of women, children, and 7 armed men, looted a field. The group looted maize and peanuts. The assailants spoke Acholi and Zande, and were dressed in civilian and military attire. The group left heading east towards Mboki.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 19 June, in Bangui, unidentified men have attempted to kidnap minister of livestock of CAR. The victim has narrowly escaped.

On 25 June, in Batangafo, 1 INGO staff member was assaulted and injured after anti-Balaka armed actors broke into his home. During the armed incursion, four others in the home were robbed of their mobile phones, cash, and other items. The staff member received medical treatment at a local hospital, and the perpetrators were handed over to MINUSCA by a local anti-Balaka leader.

column7: SYNAES: Autonomous Union of Higher Education Teachers; Teachers (Central African Republic); Students (Central African Republic)
column17: On 26 June, in Bangui, an unspecified number of university teachers, SYNASES members and students, protested demanding 3 years of leave. The demonstration started at campus and moved along Bangui streets, temporary disrupting traffic. [size=no report]
On 1 July, in Bangui, unidentified assailants vandalized Renaissance Party HQ destroying furniture and damaging facilities. The head of the new party, Augustin Agou, claims that the act is political.

column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 2 July, in Foro, at 167 FDPC combatants surrendered their arms as a part of Disarmament and Demobilization process, in accordance with the February Peace Accord.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 3 July, near Garoua Boulai, a brigade of military forces of Central African troops was deployed to secure Bangui - Garoua Boulai route.

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 3 July, in Beloko, at least 13 FDPC combatants surrendered their arms as a part of Disarmament and Demobilization process, in accordance with the February Peace Accord. 12 SMGs and 1 grenade launcher have been seized.

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 4 July, in Beloko, at least 30 FDPC combatants surrendered their arms as a part of Disarmament and Demobilization process, in accordance with the February Peace Accord. Several SMGs and grenade launchers have been seized.

On 5 July, in Ouham area [coded to Bambara], 2 national INGO staff members were assaulted by unidentified armed group while transporting two patients on motorcycles in the Ouham prefecture. The aid workers were ambushed by armed men suspected to be MPC or FPRC, robbed, and assaulted. The aid workers and patients later managed to reach Batangafo where they received treatment at an INGO hospital.

column6: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 6 July, in Nana-Mambere area [coded to Baoro], FDPC armed group started DDR process in accordance with provisions of the Khartoum Peace Agreement. The group also began to dismantle their checkpoints.

column8: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 6 July, in Ouham Pende area [coded to Bozoum], 3R started the DDR process in accordance with provisions of the Khartoum Peace Agreement. The group also began to dismantle their checkpoints.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 8 July, near Bambari, 2 FACA soldiers assaulted a demobilized Anti-Balaka sector leader. The intoxicated soldiers also fired in the air causing panic.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 8 July, in Bria, FPRC elements kidnapped a civilian, 50 yo man, who allegedly raped his neighbor's underage daughter. The kidnappers tortured the alleged rapist to death.

column17: On 10 July, in Vakaga area [coded to Birao], MLCJ armed group dismantled their checkpoints in accordance with provisions of the Khartoum Peace Agreement.

column17: On 10 July, in Bangui, several OCRB officers have seized control of a police station and barricaded entrances after not finding their names among lists of police officers for promotion. Police force leaders negotiated their promotions to end the siege.

On 10 July, in Bani, a large group of LRA, comprised of men, women, and children attacked the city. The assailants were armed with AK-47s. Unspecified ex-Seleka forces clashed with the group, resulting in injuries of multiple LRA combatants. The attackers fled south.

column16: RFI; Radio Ndeke Luka; Centrafrique Presse Info; aBangui; Twitter; 24hcongo; AFP; Africa 1

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme; Corbeau News
column17: On 11 July, in Bangui, students of the Bangui university protested demanding replacement of outdated equipment in the library and improvement of studying conditions. The protest was caused by the government's donation of outdated Chinese rice to the students. [size=no report]

column17: On 15 July, in Bangui, unspecified number of E Zingo Biani activists protested and clashed with police. [size=no report]

column8: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic

column17: On 2 March 2020, a rebel colonel of Goula ethnicity in the Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa was ambushed by members of the MPC in Bamingui (Bamingui-Bangoran). A shoot-out ensued between the rival forces as FRPC rebels came to the rescue of the victim. As a result several, FRPC rebels were wounded, with the colonel dying the day after.

As reported on 3 March 2020, members of the 3R Militia (Sidiki) attacked civilian populations for several weeks in the Berberati area (Mambere-Kadei), and in Ombella M'Poko prefecture. Two civilians killed and many injured. Fatalities split across two events

As reported on 3 March 2020, members of the 3R Militia (Sidiki) attacked civilian populations for several weeks in the Berberati area (Mambere-Kadei), and in Ombella M'Poko prefecture. Two civilians killed and many injured. Fatalities split across two events

As reported on 3 March 2020, rebel armed men of the 3R Militia (Sidiki) made incursions across Gadzi, 18 km away from Djomo (Mambere-Kadei), as well as Yaloke and Carnot. At least 10 civilians were killed and one was severely injured across the different villages on the same day. The number of fatalities is spread over the three events.

As reported on 3 March 2020, rebel armed men of the 3R Militia (Sidiki) made incursions across Yaloke (Mambere-Kadei), as well as Carnot and Gadzi. At least 10 civilians were killed and one was severely injured across the different villages on the same day. The number of fatalities is spread over the three events.

On 3 March 2020, dozens of students from the University of Bangui marched in protest across the city of Bangui (Bangui) against the Government. Student were demanding authorities to pay their scholarships for the year 2019-2020, which were three months behind schedule. [size=dozens]

As reported on 3 March 2020, rebel armed men of the 3R Militia (Sidiki) made incursions across Carnot (Mambere-Kadei), Yaloke and Gadzi. At least 10 civilians were killed and one was severely injured across the different villages on the same day. The number of fatalities is spread over the three events.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 4 March 2020, unemployed teachers gathered in front of the Office of the Prime Minister in protest against the regime's policies, in Bangui-5 (Bangui). More specifically, teachers were calling the Government to reintegrate them in the labour market. Police forces intervened and arrested at least 11 protesters. No incidents of force or violence were reported. [size=at least 11]
In the week of 4 March 2020, Fulani militiamen killed two young pastoralists near Pounangola village, close to Grimari (Ouaka).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: Between 4 and 6 March 2020, detonations were heard across Ndele (Bamingui-Bangoran), following the assassination of an FPRC colonel by members of the MPC on March 2 in Bamingui. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported. During the clashes between armed groups, several homes were burned down, with thousands of displaced people fleeing as a result.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On or before 7 March 2020, the body of a MINUSCA officer was found dead bearing gunshots in the bushes of Ndele (Bamingui-Bangoran). The circumstances of his death remained unclear. This took place in the context of ongoing clashes between FPRC and RPRC fighters following the assassination of a FPRC colonel by RPRC members last March 2 in Bamingui.
As reported on 9 March 2020, people carried out protests against MINUSCA, in Ndele (Bamingui-Bangoran), due to allegations of officials' collaboration with militias in the region. [size=no report]

column9: Fulani Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo); Women (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 9 March 2020, two Fulani women were killed by an unidentified armed group in Pounangola village, close to Grimari (Ouaka). It was reported the crime was committed in revenge after the killings of two young men the week before.

column6: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column7: MLCJ: Movement of Central African Liberators for Justice
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Between 11 and 12 March 2020, RPRC rebels, supported by Sudanese MLCJ fighters, overtook some parts of the city of Ndele (Bamingui-Bangoran), following attacks on FPRC positions. This split the city in two parts, with each one of them controlled by the rival forces. Around 40 civilians, mostly Rounga, were killed and hundreds fled.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 15 March 2020, an armed clash took place between Christian Anti-Balaka armed men and MINUSCA officials in Grimari (Ouaka), following an attack by the former against the houses of the deputy prefect and the city's Mayor. A Burundian blue helmet was killed during the shoot-out.

column6: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 15 March 2020, RPRC forces engaged in an armed clash with Pakistani MINUSCA officers in Ndele (Bamingui-Bangoran), following an attempted ambush by the former. Two people were killed and a third one injured.

As reported on 15 March 2020, several thousand citizens were seen in Birao (Vakaga) moving towards the Sudanese border to seek asylum in this neighboring country. This took place in the context of ongoing inter-ethnic violence between Rounga and Goula ethnic groups in the northeastern horn of the country.

column9: Former Seleka Militia; UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 15 March 2020, an angry mob of young people set on fire the house of an ex-Seleka (UPC) commander in Mboki locality (Obo, Haut-Mbomou), after the latter had tortured a man. No injured nor fatalities reported. [size=no report]

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 15 March 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) men tortured and mutilated a civilian man accused of concubinage in Mboki locality (Obo, Haut-Mbomou).

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 16 March 2020, an ex-Seleka (UPC) man raped a girl and beat up her brother in Bambouti (Bambouti, Haut-Mbomou).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Sara Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 16 March 2020, a group of ex-Seleka (FPRC) combatants destroyed property of a local chief, 18 km from Bria (Bria, Haute-Kotto). The motive of the attack is not reported but was not ethnic, since the chief was actually Sara, neutral to the conflict.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 17 March 2020, an ex-Seleka (UPC) combatant robbed a civilian member of a local CSO in Bria (Bria, Haute-Kotto).

column6: MLCJ: Movement of Central African Liberators for Justice
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column16: Corbeau News; Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: On 19 March 2020, UPC reached a peace agreement between MLCJ and FPRC in Bria (Haute-Kotto), to put an end to their clashes in the prefectures of Vakaga, Haute-Kotto and Bamingui-Bangoran. This had caused hundreds of deaths and injuries, as well as massive displacement of the population since July 2019.

On 22 March 2020, an unidentified armed group ambushed and shot 5 civilian men near Ouadda Djalle (Ouanda-Djalle,Vakaga), killing 3 and injuring 2. The injured men managed to escape and alert the nearby community.
On 24 March 2020, five men were attacked by unidentified men between Saragobo and Ouanda-Djalle (Vakaga) during an ambush. Three men were killed and two were injured.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 24 March 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) armed men killed a civilian and injured another in Ippy (Ippy, Ouaka) after having tortured them for robbing a store.

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 24 March 2020, approximately 200 South Sudanese rebels were observed 7 km north of Sam Ouandja (Ouadda, Haute-Kotto) with AK-47s, grenade launchers and machine guns installed on trucks. They reportedly met with ex-Seleka (FPRC) forces before leaving.

column6: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: Between 25 and 26 March 2020, an armed clash between RPRC and FPRC elements in Gozbeda, near Ndele (Bamingui-Bangoran), after the former raided the locality, burning down houses and establishments. The death toll resulted in 3 FPRC militants killed and others injured. Other sources reported 8 RPRC fighters killed and 7 injured, although this was not confirmed.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 26 March 2020, ex-Seleka UPC combatants looted telephones, a radio, and money from 2 civilians 12 km from Mboki locality (Obo, Haut-Mbomou).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 27 March 2020, a school was set on fire in Ndele (Bamingui-Bangoran). The authorship of the property destruction was attributed to FPRC elements, although it was reported MLCJ fighters could also be involved. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.

Between 26 and 27 March 2020, NGO workers were ambushed by unidentified armed men near Mboki (Haut-Mbomou). The former, on a motorbike, managed to escape from the perpetrators after they started to shoot in the air. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.
On 28 March 2020, LRA combatants, wearing military disguises, looted goods from the Zangale mining site, near Dembia (Mbomou), where they stole minerals and other residents' goods.

On 29 March 2020, around 700 elements of the Sudanese Misseria ethnic group and Dam Alserie militiamen attacked civilians in Ndiffa village, located 170km afar from Birao (Vakaga). It was reported the perpetrators arrived at the site to seek revenge against the killing of one of his members on March 27 (circumstances unknown). Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.
On 29 March 2020, six civilians were abducted by LRA combatants near Bougoua, proximate to Obo (Haut-Mbomou), after being ambushed by them. No further information on the event was reported.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 29 March 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) men tortured a civilian man in Bambouti (Bambouti, Haut-Mbomou) for not notifying them that he had travelers staying with him. The victim was released after paying a fine.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 30 March 2020, FPRC militants in two pick-up trucks, carried out an attack on a refugee camp in Ndele (Bamingui-Bangoran), forcing the displaced to return to their respective homes. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 30 March 2020, ex-Seleka (FPRC) forces tortured a child accused of theft in Aigbando (Bria, Haute-Kotto). A member of the local civil society negotiated the child's release for a fine.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 30 March 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) combatants ambushed and robbed food and money from civilians near Mboki (Obo, Haut-Mbomou).
On 30 March 2020, 5 Anti-Balaka combatants abducted a man accused of theft in Bria (Bria, Haute-Kotto). A local leader intervened and released the victim.

On 31 March 2020, five civilians were ambushed by LRA combatants along the Bougoua road, near Obo (Haut-Mbomou). The latter looted all the victims' belongings, who were held in the bush with other abducted civilians. The victims were released later on, and one of them was reported injured.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 31 March 2020, ex-Seleka (FPRC) armed men abducted a civilian man in Gbatahao village, located 24 km northeast of Yangou Droundja (Bria, Haute-Kotto) after he accidentally shot and killed his nephew while hunting.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 1 April 2020, elements of two different FPRC factions clashed in Ndele's Bornou neighbourhood (Bamingui-Bangoran), after one attacked a trader and stole his posessions. Injuries were reported on both sides. After the incident, FPRC combatants demanded the resignation of the group's chief.

column6: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column17: On 2 April 2020, a 6 year-old girl was beheaded by suspected RPRC militants at a residence in Ndele's Kpetene neighbourhood (Bamingui-Bangoran).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 3 April 2020, ex-Seleka (FPRC) armed men abducted and beat 1 woman in Bria (Haute-Kotto) as punishment for running away from home. Local leaders intervened to secure the release of the woman and took her to the hospital.

column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Labour Group (Central African Republic)
column17: On 3 April 2020, 2 guards were stabbed and injured by anti-Balaka militiamen during a robbery on an NGO's premise in Batangafo (Batangafo, Ouham). The perpetrators stole communication equipment, electronics and cash.

On 5 April 2020, an LRA group abducted a man travelling from Obo to Mboki, 8 km east of Kadjema (Obo, Haut-Mbomou). The assailants released the man after learning he was transporting goods for ex-Seleka (UPC) forces. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 6 April 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) armed men looted 6 motorcycles from civilians in Zemio (Haut-Mbomou).

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 6 April 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) militiamen looted at least 12 motorcycles from civilians in Mboki (Obo, Haut-Mbomou).

column6: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column7: MLCJ: Movement of Central African Liberators for Justice; PRNC: Party of the Rally of the Central African Nation
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 6 April 2020, RPRC (supported by MLCJ and PRNC fighters) and FPRC elements engaged in an armed clash in the city of Ndele (Bamingui-Bangoran), after the former carried out attacks against FPRC positions in the city.The provisional dead toll was unknown.

On 6 April 2020, an LRA group abducted 15 boys to carry looted goods stolen from the community of Bougoua (Obo, Haut-Mbomou). They released the boys later that day. No fatalities and/or injuries reported, but the LRA group had been camped out in this area for 4 days.

On 6 April 2020, an LRA group armed with AK-47s and dressed in civilian attire, looted the community of Ligoua (Obo, Haut-Mbomou). Community members fled to Obo and alerted authorities. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 7 April 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) militiamen beat and abducted 2 young men who resisted looting in Ippy (Ouaka). Civil society leaders negotiated their release in exchange for money.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Refugees/IDPs (Central African Republic); Labour Group (Central African Republic)
column17: On 7 April 2020, ex-Seleka (FPRC) armed men killed 1 IDP man for selling goods in Ngoundja (Bria, Haute-Kotto).

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 7 April 2020, 2 ex-Seleka (UPC) combatants attacked a civilian man in Ippy (Ippy, Ouaka). No injuries nor fatalities reported.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 9 April 2020, residents destroyed a MINUSCA temporary operational base in Beboura 3 (Ouham Pende) after a fatal car accident between patrolling MINUSCA officials and a woman, who died soon after. Witnesses asked officials for immediate compensation. Soon after the angry population set the base on fire and destroyed the facilities. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported. [size=no report]

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 12 April 2020, MINUSCA decided to withdraw its Temporary Operational Base (TOB) in Beboura 3 (Ouham Pende) following hostility from the local population against the base, triggered by a fatal car accident who left one civilian killed on 9 April. Authorities has warned about the security vacuum left.

On 13 April 2020, 7 unidentified men armed with guns and machetes looted various houses of the village of Ngoundja, located about 55 kilometers north of Bria (Haute-Kotto), forcing the locals to flee for security. Some sources indicated that the assailants could be members of the FPRC.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 17 April 2020, ex-Seleka (FPRC) rebels tortured a man whom they had abducted in Aigbando I (Bria, Haute-Kotto). The motive was not reported.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 17 April 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) forces and MINUSCA clashed during an attempted abduction of 3 telecom workers in Ippy (Ouaka). MINUSCA forces secured the release of the 3 men. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Special Forces Battalion
column17: On 18 April 2020, around 400 elements of the military Special Security Units (USMS) blocked the Bouar-Baor road 10 Km from Bouar locality (Bouar, Nana-Mambere). The demonstration came amid an ongoing strike over a wage dispute. [size=around 400]

On 18 April 2020, Anti-Balaka armed men abducted a man in Bria (Haute-Kotto) and demanded money for his release. Civil society leaders intervened and secured the man's release after paying an amount of money.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Street Traders (Central African Republic)
column17: On 18 April 2020, ex-Seleka (FPRC) militiamen beat a Fulani man who tried to stop them from forcing a man to eat an owl in front of villagers in Yalinga (Haute-Kotto). The latter, a market chief, was accused of ordering an increase of market prices.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 21 April 2020, ex-Seleka (FPRC) armed men robbed a young man in Bria (Haute-Kotto).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 24 April 2020, ex-Seleka (FPRC) abducted a man from Ngoukaga village, 35 km from Yangoudroundja (Bria, Haute-Kotto), after the man set his wife's property on fire during a dispute. The man was released after civil society leaders negotiated a lowered ransom for his release.

column8: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column17: On 25 April 2020, a group of Fulani pastoralists clashed with rebels of the Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic (MPC) in Bamingui (Bamingui, Bamingui-Bangoran) after the latter had forced the Fulani to pay taxes. 1 MPC combatant was killed.

On 26 April 2020, 3 Anti-Balaka militiamen robbed the base of the DRC (Danish Refugee Council) INGO in Batangafo (Ouham, Batangafo) and took away 1 computer and office material. The 3 robbers were later handed over to MINUSCA by their Anti-Balaka leader (Arnaud) for prosecution but escaped from the MINUSCA base.
On 26 April 2020, Anti-Balaka abducted a man in Bria (Haute-Kotto) accused of not paying a tax to this armed group. They released the man after he paid.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 26 April 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) rebels clashed with Fulani armed men 10 km north of Ngouyo (Zemio, Haut-Mbomou). The UPC rebels had pursued the Fulani because the latter had fired into the air after they were denied access to a local market by the community. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.
On 28 April 2020, Anti-balaka armed men abducted a man in Gbama, 29 km from Bria (Haute-Kotto), accused of violating their leader's mining zone.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 29 April 2020, ex-Seleka (FPRC) militia rebels abducted a man accused of being a traitor in Bria (Haute-Kotto).

column6: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column7: MLCJ: Movement of Central African Liberators for Justice; PRNC: Party of the Rally of the Central African Nation; Kara Ethnic Group (Central African Republic)
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-); Ronga Ethnic Group (Central African Republic)
column16: aBangui; IRIN; Radio Ndeke Luka; Corbeau News; Xinhua; AFP; BBC News
column17: On 29 April 2020, a large group of RPRC militiamen in coalition with MLCJ and PRNC, all of the Kara Ethnic Group, clashed with FPRC rebels, in control of the area and mostly of Ronga ethnicity, during an incursion in the centre of Ndele (Ndele, Bamingui-Bangoran). The FPRC, outnumbered, reportedly tried to fight the assailants and with MINUSCA support to protect civilians. The Government stated that 25 people were killed, including 21 civilians, while 51 were injured, but other sources reported at least 37 were killed.

column6: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column7: MLCJ: Movement of Central African Liberators for Justice; PRNC: Party of the Rally of the Central African Nation; Kara Ethnic Group (Central African Republic)
column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; Labour Group (Central African Republic)
column17: On 30 April 2020, RPRC militiamen in coalition with MLCJ and PRNC armed groups (all Kara Ethnic Group) looted several shops in Ndele (Ndele, Bamingui-Bangoran) the day after they attacked the town. They also looted the buildings of 2 international NGOs (ICRC and NRC).

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 2 May 2020, a group of local young men severely beat up a soldier following a dispute in Bozoum (Bozoum, Ouham Pende). The soldier died later from his injuries, triggering the anger of his fellow soldiers, who patrolled the town firing into air and paralyzing all the activity for a day, forcing also many locals to flee towards the forest for security. [size=no report]

column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 3 May 2020, a group of locals attacked and injured an ex-Seleka (FPRC) combatant who shot and killed a shopkeeper in Bria (Haute-Kotto). [size=no report]

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column9: Women (Central African Republic); Fulani Ethnic Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 4 May 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) forces abducted a Fulani woman because she had left her husband in Bria (Haute-Kotto). MINUSCA forces secured her release.

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 5 May 2020, 6 ex-Seleka (UPC) combatants raped a woman while she was working in the fields, 10 km from Obo (Haut-Mbomou).

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 5 May 2020, ex-Seleka (UPC) rebels assaulted and injured 3 hunters near Obo (Haut-Mbomou), accusing them of giving information to security forces about their positions.

column7: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 6 May 2020, a group of soldiers of the Central African Republic Army demonstrated in the streets of Bangassou (Bangassou, Mbomou) by firing their firearms into the air for several hours to demand their redeployment from the town, as they claimed that their deployment period was exceeded. No fatalities and/or injuries reported. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column8: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 9 May 2020, Central African soldiers clashed with combatants of the UPC in Obo (Obo, Haut-Mbomou). The FACA managed to disperse the rebels and seized valuables from them. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 10 May 2020, Anti-balaka armed men clashed with MINUSCA after seizing 3 sheep belonging to a man in Bria (Haute-Kotto). MINUSCA peacekeepers forced the assailants to return the looted livestock. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column6: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People
column8: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 12 May 2020, two rival armed groups, the RPRC (Goula ethnic) and the FPRC (Rounga ethnic), clashed in Ndele (Ndele, Bamingui-Bangoran) resulting in 4 FPRC combatants and 2 civilians killed. Several houses were also destroyed during the crossfire. The clash began after the FPRC cadres had been accused of having committed a robbery.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: On 12 May 2020, combatants of the RRR (Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation) armed group confronted and disarmed gendarmes posted in Besson (Baboua, Nana-Mambere) during a simultaneous incursion in various villages of the area. The local population, scared, fled the village towards the forest. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: On 12 May 2020, combatants of the RRR (Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation) armed group confronted and disarmed the Gendarmes posted in Kounde (Baboua, Nana-Mambere) during a simultaneous incursion in various villages of this area. The local population, scared, fled the village towards the forest. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column9: Street Traders (Central African Republic); Pastoralists (Central African Republic)
column17: On 13 May 2020, combatants of the RRR (Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation) stole money from some traders and breeders during an incursion in Bohong locality (Bocaranga, Ouham Pende). No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 13 May 2020, the FACA returned to Ndele (Ndele, Bamingui-Bangoran) to establish a military base, 8 years after they left.

column9: Street Traders (Central African Republic); Pastoralists (Central African Republic)
column17: On 13 May 2020, combatants of the RRR (Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation) stole money from some traders and breeders during an incursion in Niem-Yelewa locality (Bouar, Nana-Mambere). No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 14 May 2020, ex-Seleka (FPRC) armed men abducted a man in Bria (Haute-Kotto) who they accused of making a phone call to a combatant's wife.

On 14 May 2020, an unknown armed group ambushed 1 NGO vehicle on the road in Yagarandji Forest, 15 km south of Kaga-Bandoro (Nana-Grebizi). The driver was critically shot and later died in hospital while the 3 other passengers were unharmed.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 15 May 2020, FPRC rebels abducted a 16-year-old boy accused of sexual harassment against another minor in Bria (Bria, Haute-Kotto). The rebels, in control of the town, asked the family of the boy for a ransom for his release.

On 15 May 2020, combatants of the RRR (Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation) abducted a woman and looted several households during an incursion in Bokayan locality (Bouar, Nana-Mambere). No fatalities and/or injuries reported.
On 15 May 2020, combatants of the RRR (Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation) robbed 10 cows from breeders in Tale locality (Bouar, Nana-Mambere). No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2013-2014) National Security Company
column9: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: On 16 May 2020, a group of locals beat up and injured 8 policemen of the National Security Company at a roadblock in Begoua (Bimbo, Ombella M'Poko). The policemen were accused of having provoked an accident that left 3 passengers injured, when they were trying to stop them allegedly to sensitize them on measures for the coronavirus pandemic. The Police with the support of the military (Gendarmerie) intervened and controlled the situation. [size=no report]

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 17 May 2020, former Seleka (UPC) forces looted motorcycles in Bambouti (Bambouti, Haut-Mbomou).

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 17 May 2020, former Seleka (UPC) forces looted motorcycles from the local population in Mboki (Obo, Haut-Mbomou). No fatalities and/or injuries reported.
