column17: Around 26 August 2020 (as reported), FOCA forces together with MINUSCA troops took control of Yade locality, near Boyaye Boyongo (Koui, Ouham Pende) following a military operation against the 3R armed group, which was forced to flee in small groups. The state forces dismantled several bases and assets of this militia.

column6: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column7: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: Around 26 August 2020 (as reported), FOCA forces together with MINUSCA troops took control of Besson locality (Baboua, Nana-Mambere) following a military operation against the 3R armed group, which was forced to flee in small groups. The state forces dismantled several bases and assets of this militia.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 26 August 2020, FPRC combatants looted 3 tablets and money from ANE electoral agents in Ngui (Yalinga, Haute-Kotto). Once informed of the situation, the Prefect negotiated with the leader of the armed group to return the stolen property.

On 26 August 2020, motorbike taxi drivers marched on the streets in Bangui (Bangui, Bangui) and barricaded some roads for hours to show their outrage for the attack of a fellow taxi driver by a policeman, which left him severely injured. [size=no report]

On 26 August 2020, a group of local people beat up 1 woman and then buried her alive in Barka Panzi village, 20 Km from Berberati town (Berberati, Mambere-Kadei). The woman was accused of witchery. The police intervened and saved the victim, who was seriously injured. [size=no report]

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 28 August 2020, 3R armed rebels intercepted an abducted a team of ANE agents (National Election Authority) in Niem (Bouar, Nana-Mambere). The rebels then forced them to leave the area. The agents were deployed to carry out the voter registration for the upcoming election in December 2020.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 28 August 2020, ex-Seleka FPRC armed men intercepted a team of ANE agents (National Election Authority) near Yalinga (Yalinga, Haute-Kotto). They took their vote registration tablets and forced them to leave the area.

On 30 August 2020, a youth group demonstrated in Bangui-2 (Bangui. Bangui) against alleged discrimination practices during the recruitment of new police officers. They claimed that the locals of this area of the city (Arrondissement 2) were not considered for the recruitment. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 30 August 2020, a group of local armed people clashed with FOCA soldiers and private security guards in a mining site in Gaga village, located 70 Km from Yaloke (Yaloke, Ombella M'Poko). The state forces were forced to retreat, allowing the locals to loot the office of the Chinese mining company which runs the site, including the robbery of Chinese workers. The clash was triggered by an incident in which 1 local was shot and injured by the soldiers. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

column7: Women (Central African Republic); Refugees/IDPs (Central African Republic)
column17: On 1 September 2020, more than 300 people including women and children gathered in front of the UNHCR headquarters in Bangui-2 (Bangui, Bangui). The demonstrators, former Congo-Brazzaville refugees returned into the country, blocked the road and blamed the UNHCR for not having supported them during their return. [size=more than 300]

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 1 September 2020, FPRC combatants looted a motorcycle from a man in Bria town (Bria, Haute-Kotto).

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 1 September 2020, UPC combatants ambushed and looted several goods from 2 young men in a field 8 km west of Obo town (Obo, Haut-Mbomou).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 2 September 2020, 4 FPRC elements ambushed and looted a hunter near Ngoundja (Bria, Haute-Kotto).

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 2 September 2020, UPC armed men abducted 1 man at a check-point in Ippy (Ippy, Ouaka), because he was carrying boxes of ammunition. The man was released after paying money to the armed group.

column7: ANC: Alliance for the new Central African Republic; URCA: Union for Central African Renewal
column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 3 September 2020, a group of supporters of the president Faustin-Archange Touadera marched in front of the parliament in Bangui (Bangui, Bangui) to demand that the members of the parliament lift the immunity of the opponent Anicet Georges Dologuele (from the Union for Central African Renewal), who they accuse of being behind the attempted coup against Touadera in 2017. Other supporters of Dologuele demonstrated also in the same place. The police intervened to prevent the groups from clashing. [size=no report]

column7: ANC: Alliance for the new Central African Republic
column17: On 4 September 2020, a group of members and supporters of the Alliance for the new Central African Republic, the president's party, gathered and broke into the building of the Ministry of Communication in Bangui-1 (Bangui, Bangui). They demanded the dismissal of the Minister and government spokesperson, who they accused of being behind the attempted coup against the president in 2017. [size=no report]

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 6 September 2020, UPC armed men abducted 2 men in Ippy (Ippy, Ouaka) accused of stealing goods from NGO beneficiaries. The 2 men were released after paying money to the armed group.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 6 September 2020, FPRC combatants abducted 2 men in Sam-Ouandja (Ouadda, Haute-Kotto). They were abducted for stealing.
On 6 September 2020, Anti-balaka combatants robbed a miner and looted his home in Bria (Bria, Haute-Kotto). The victim was accused of stealing a diamond.

column8: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 7 September 2020, 3R militiamen captured and abducted 2 policemen in the village of Bang (Ngaoundaye, Ouham Pende). Later on, the perpetrators asked for the release of 3 of their fellow combatants, arrested by the FOCA and MINUSCA, in exchange for the policemen.

On 8 September 2020, a group of former refugees who had returned into CAR marched for the second time in front of the UNHCR headquarters in Bangui (Bangui, Bangui). They denounced that this UN agency is not supporting them during the reintegration process. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, a group of local people marched and gathered in front of the police station in Yaloke locality (Yaloke, Ombella M'Poko), over the release of a well-known Anti-Balaka militia combatant by the Police. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, a group of civil servants from the Ministry of Finance staged a demonstration in Bangui (Bangui, Bangui) to denounce malpractice in their office as well as unpaid salaries. They initiated a strike. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, a group of local residents from the Boeing and Cattin neighborhoods set up barricades and burned tires in some streets of Bangui (Bangui, Bangui), in reaction to the killing of a motorbike taxi driver by armed robbers. They deplored the inaction of the police and the increase of insecurity. [size=no report]

column9: Aid Workers (Central African Republic); ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent
column17: On 9 September 2020, 3 armed men wearing military uniforms robbed an ICRC vehicle in Bangui city (Bangui, Bangui). The assailants pretended to be FOCA soldiers to stop the vehicle.

On 10 September 2020, a group of suspected 3R militiamen shot and killed 1 man during an attack in an area 7 Km from Bossemptele locality (Bossemtele, Ouham Pende). The assailants, heavily armed, also looted and torched 2 trucks with Cameroonian license plates. Many local civilians fled the area.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Special Forces Battalion
column17: Around 10 September 2020 (week of), armed rebels from the 3R militia clashed with FOCA Special Military Forces in an area 30 Km from Bocaranga town (Bocaranga, Ouham Pende). At least 9 soldiers were shot and injured in the clash.

On 12 September 2020, more than 1,000 candidates for the police entrance exams marched in Bangui (Bangui, Bangui) against the authorities. They claimed they had been left out from the physical tests and attributed this to malpractice and corruption by the authorities. [size=more than 1,000]

column6: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 13 September 2020, 53 combatants from the MPC militia (Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic) and 7 from the Seleka Renewal militia joined the DDR process (Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration) led by the FOCA forces and MINUSCA in the town of Kaga-Bandoro (Kaga-Bandoro, Nana-Grebizi).

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 14 September 2020, 3R rebels armed with heavy weapons looted the local Town Hall and other public buildings during an incursion in Bohong locality (Bocaranga, Ouham Pende). The local population fled the village towards the forest.

On 16 September 2020, 3R rebels kidnapped a 12-year-old girl and her 18-year-old brother in Ndongori village (Baboua, Nana-Mambere). The victims were the children of a well-known former Anti Balaka leader who threatened to take up arms if the government does not liberate his children.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column7: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People; MLCJ: Movement of Central African Liberators for Justice; Anti-Balaka
column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column9: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 16 September 2020, around 528 combatants from various armed groups (FPRC, RPRC, MLCJ and Anti-Balaka) joined the DDR process (Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration) led by the FOCA forces and MINUSCA in the mining town of Bria (Bria, Haute-Kotto).

On 16 September 2020, 4 Fulani armed men of the 3R armed group abducted a man in Gouffou village, 17 Km from Bouar (Bouar, Nana-Mambere). The man was undressed and robbed by the assailants and released on the same day. Reportedly, these militiamen had recently deserted the FOCA military forces to join this militia.
On 17 September 2020, 3R armed men abducted 1 man (a youth leader) in Bavara village (Paoua, Ouham Pende).

On 17 September 2020, the 3R militia occupied the village of Tale (Markounda, Ouham Pende). They arrived in this village fleeing from military operations by the state forces. They forced some local families to leave the village.

On 17 September 2020, the 3R militia occupied the villages of Yambassa and Bondja, near Paoua (Paoua, Ouham Pende). They arrived in these villages fleeing from military operations by the state forces. They forced some local families to leave these villages.

On 17 September 2020, the 3R militia occupied the village of Bavara (Paoua, Ouham Pende). They arrived in this village fleeing from military operations by the state forces. They forced some local families to leave the village.

On 18 September 2020, several tens of ANE agents (National Electoral Agency) staged a demonstration in Bangui (Bangui, Bangui). They entered the ANE headquarters with pots and pans and whistles to demand their unpaid salaries of the last 2 months. [size= several tens]

column6: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 19 September 2020, UPC combatants beat an NGO driver in Zemio (Zemio, Haut-Mbomou) after he confronted them for running into and damaging the vehicle he was driving.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column7: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
column17: On 20 September 2020, FPRC and UPC armed rebels attacked and injured 2 young men in Yangoudroundja (Bria, Haute-Kotto). No more details were reported.

On 21 September 2020, ANE agents (National Electoral Agency) in charge of the vote registration together with their drivers staged a demonstration in Bangui (Bangui, Bangui) to demand their unpaid salaries and bonuses. [size=no report]

On 21 September 2020, workers of SOCATEL, the national telecom company, marched in Bangui (Bangui, Bangui) against the government. They claimed an unpaid grant that the government had promised. [size=no report]

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 22 September 2020, FPRC armed men abducted 1 man in Bria town (Bria, Haute-Kotto), after he attempted to rob a trader. The man was released after returning the stolen goods.

On 24 September 2020, a suspected LRA group, comprised of men, woman, and children ambushed and looted goods from 2 traders along the Obo-Bambouti axis, 35 km west of Bambouti town (Bambouti, Haut-Mbomou).

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 25 September 2020, FPRC armed men abducted 1 woman in Bria town (Bria, Haute-Kotto) over an issue with the custody of her child. The assailants demanded the woman to pay money to them to release her.
On 25 September 2020, a local militia beat a man accused of witchcraft in Boungou 1 (Ouadda, Haute-Kotto). A community member helped the victim escape before the group could kill him.

column6: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
column17: On 26 September 2020, FPRC combatants abducted 2 men in Bria town (Bria, Haute-Kotto) after they had fought with each other. The armed group released the 2 men after paying money to the rebels.

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
column17: On 27 September 2020, 3R rebels abducted 1 gendarme in Tale (Markounda, Ouham). The gendarme did not resist the rebels.

On 27 September 2020, 3R rebels sabotaged a bridge using remote explosives on a provincial road 25 Km from Bocaranga (Bocaranga, Ouham Pende), forcing travelers to abandon their vehicles and cross the river. Reportedly, these rebels helped travelers to cross in exchange for money. MINUSCA troops fixed the bridge the next day.

On 27 September 2020, 3R militiamen occupied Nanga locality (Nangha Boguila, Ouham). They arrived fleeing from military operations by the state forces and established their camp in a local school. Then, after the MINUSCA demanded them to free the school, they moved into a church. Many locals fled the village fearing for their security.

On 28 September 2020, LRA combatants abducted 13 local civilians in Ligoua-Zewia village (Obo, Haut-Mbomou). Many locals fled towards Obo town fearing for their safety. 12 of the victims were released 2 days later but continued to hold a boy captive.

column9: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: Around 28 September 2020 (as reported), the 3R armed group sabotaged the voting registration in various locations of Ngaoundaye prefecture (Ouham Pende). The ANE agents were forced to return to Bangui and other election-related activities were put on hold.

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 28 September 2020, armed men from an unidentified militia stole arms and ammunition from the MINUSCA in one of its check-points in Bria town (Bria, Haute-Kotto).

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 29 September 2020, 3R rebels clashed with MINUSCA troops in Ngaoundaye town (Ngaoundaye, Ouham Pende) following an offensive by these rebels. The UN troops managed to drive the rebels out of the town and re-establish the voting registration process for the upcoming election. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

On 7 October 2020, 3R militiamen occupied Nana-Bakassa locality (Nangha Boguila, Ouham). They arrived fleeing from military operations by the state forces. Many locals fled the village fearing for their security.
On 10 October 2020, a truck carrying food aid and belonging to the World Food Programme was reportedly looted by Anti-Balaka militants in the village of Gbaddengue near Bossembele (Bossembele).

column8: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
column17: On 13 October 2020, an army chief opened fire on a group of electoral agents protesting in front the headquarters of the National Instance of Elections in Bangui (Bangui) to demand the payment of their compensation fees. Several protesters were reportedly injured. [size=no report]

On 13 October 2020, members of the youth Movement 4500 protested in front the security directorate headquarters in Bangui (Bangui) to demand the release of three movement members arrested to prevent a large-scale mobilization to force a private Lebanese company issuing identity documents to comply with the Finance Law 2020 fixing the price of secured documents at 4500 Francs. [size=no report]

On 18 October 2020, unidentified armed men shot and killed a teacher in Kabo town (Kabo, Ouham). The victim was killed because he resisted being robbed by these armed men, who were believed to belong to one of the militias controlling the area.

Around 19 October 2020 (as reported), a group of locals demonstrated in Mpoko Ngomon village, near Bimbo (Bimbo, Ombella M'Poko). They blocked the road to try to stop a convoy made of prominent military officers who had been prospecting for minerals. [size=no report]

column8: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column17: On 22 October 2020, more than 600 members of local communal militias and others with weapons agreed to hand over their arms to the MINUSCA in Bangui city (Bangui, Bangui). They handed over 24 weapons, 104 ammunition and 13 mortar shells to join a community DRR program to promote alternative livelihoods.

On 22 October 2020, around 30 workers from the national Telecommunications Department demonstrated and called for a strike in Bangui (Bangui, Bangui) to demand their unpaid bonuses. They barricaded the main door and chased the other employees to join them. [size=around 30]

Around 24 October 2020 (as reported), a group of local civilians barricaded streets in Gambo (Gambo, Mbomou) to show their outrage for the release of an Anti Balaka combatant thanks to the intervention of the local authorities. [size=no report]
Three prison guards reportedly burst into a cell where 13 women were sleeping and tried to rape them.
Three prisoners were killed during a riot at the prison of Abeche. Prisoners allegedly threw stones at the guards, who shot in retaliation.
Nine men died of asphyxiation four hours after being detained at the National Gendarmerie detention facility in the town of Lere.

One men died in detention after having been transferred to NDjamena central prison from National Gendarmerie detention facility in the town of Lere where nine prisoners had earlier died form asphyxiation.
Two prisoners were killed and five wounded when the prison security forces used firearms during a riot in Bongor prison.
Two prisoners were killed and at least two seriously wounded after prison guards opened fire on prisoners following a riot in Moussoro prison.
A man thought to be a Chadian soldier shot at two French soldiers as they left a military base near the capital NDjamena.
""One male international staffer injured when 50 to 60 Chadians raided the INGO compound.""

column8: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Members of the Nigeria military engaged two suspected members of Boko Haram attempting to smuggle a large cache of weapons into Nigeria from Chad near Lake Chad. Two militants killed in the struggle.
Students protesting against the cancellation of their exams results took to the street in protest
A journalist with Radio Terre Nouvelle, was beaten by police officers in Chads southwestern Mayo-Kebbi Est region for asking questions about a civil disturbance he was reporting on

column9: ATPDH: Chadian Association for the Promotion and Defence of Human Rights
column17: A lawyer and president of the human rights organization Association tchadienne de promotion et de defense des droits de l'homme (ATPDH), was attacked by unidentified armed men in front of her house in N'Djamena.
Armed Agents From the National Security Agency in Ndjamena the capital and detained them in handcuffs on the premises of a private hospital
""""One UN staff was attacked and killed in UN accommodation.""""

Four military officials have been arrested in connection with a foiled attempt to overthrow the government in the Central African nation of Chad, the countries state prosecutor announced on Thursday. Reported that three people were killed in the shoot-out which ensued when police attempted to arrest conspirators.

column8: JEM-Bashar: Justice and Equality Movement (Bashar Faction)
column17: The leader of a breakaway faction of Darfurs main rebel and his deputy have been killed following an attack inside Chad near the border with Sudan. No details on location: approximation used. Two fatalities (total) reported.
The ruling Patriotic Movement for Salvation, MPS, party yesterday [5 July] held a demonstration in which the former political prisoners in the Habre government took part.
Movement of forces: Military sent to gold mining area which was delcared a military zone. Military was ordered to shoot or arrest intruders.
Police officers were beaten & their vehicles stoned when they tried to intervene in an attack against a young girl by a group of about 20 people
The head of President's security, Lieutenant Colonel Dilloh Nassour Deby, was assassinated in Ndjamena when armed men tried to steal his vehicle following an attack on the Dembe police station
Armed men killed 3 police officers at the Dembe police station in N'Djamena
Doctors began a 3-day protest over the killing of a colleague in N'Djamena & over working conditions

Chadian troops and unnamed Chadian opposition forces clashed on the Sudanese-Chadian borders at 3:00pm on Thursday; 11 members of the opposition forces were killed and 56 were caputred; 4 Chadian troops were killed and a vehicle destroyed
A sub-prefect and district chief were taken hostage by Fulani herders angry over the death of a Fulani
4 young men were killed while harvesting straw by unidentified assailants
""Knife attack by three men on INGO and INGO partner staff member in bar. The 2 men were taken to hospital for emergency care.""
Chadian lawyers have observed a 72-hour work stoppage to protest the prosecution of some of their colleagues

column6: Military Forces of the United States (2009-2017)
column17: Movement of forces: 80 US soldiers (two teams of 40) have been sent to Chad to assist in searching for the Nigerian girls kidnapped by Boko Haram

column7: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014); Military Forces of Mauritania (2009-); Military Forces of Chad (1990-); Military Forces of Niger (2011-); Military Forces of Mali (2013-2020)
column17: Movement of forces: France has officially announced the end of Operation Serval and the beginning of Operation Barkhane, which will focus on anti-terrorism in the broader Sahel region, in partnership with Burkina Faso, Chad, Mali, Mauritania, and Niger, to be based in NDjamena; 1000 troops will continue to be stationed in Mali, while 3000 total will be deployed across the Sahel; they will be supported by 3 drones, 20 helicopters, 6 fighter jets, 200 armoured vehicles and 10 transport aircraft.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram militants crossed into Chad from Kirenowa and killed six Nigerians taking refuge in the village of Dubuwa.
20 people were killed while another 50 were wounded in ethnic clashes between Arabs and Ouaddaians in Jaradet. The military sent helicopters to intervene to break up the violence.
Protests over fuel shortage.
Prisoners protested, police forces fired shots in the air. Reports of one death and others injured.
Youth attacked a filling station and petrol tanker during demonstrations, and security agents intervenced and chased the demonstrators.
Youth attacked state-owned vehicles during protests, and security agents intervened and chased the demonstrators.
Teachers led strikes and demonstrations and security agents responded with live ammunition that injured two people.
Thousands of Chadiens from multiple faiths conducted a public group prayer for peace and unity. Local and foreign government officials also participated, along with civil society organizations.
Opposition parties and activists boycotted the national celebrations for the 24th anniversary of President Idriss Deby Itnos accession to power.

column6: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
column8: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: Agreement: Former rebel leader Abdel Kader Baba Ladde was extradicted to Chad from CAR
Tens of thousands marched in support of Chadian troops heading to Nigeria and Cameroon to fight Boko Haram.

High school students rioted against new Baccalaureate regulations, ransacking school facilities. Security forces intervened, and four students and one onlooker were killed. Eight people were seriously injured including five security forces and five students.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Boko Haram fighters crossed from Baga into Ngoubo and started firing indiscriminately, torching 2/3 of the town. Chadian forces returned fire and routed the militants. At least one civilian - the village chief- and one soldier were killed, along with two Boko Haram fighters.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Chadian military planes destroyed 5 boats of Boko Haram combatants that were trying to enter the country on Lake Chad.
The Cameroonian community in Chad organized a march in support of Chadian and Cameroonian soldiers fighting Boko Haram.

Students protested against a rise in helmet prices after their use became obligatory this month, setting fire to several vehicles and blocking access to schools. They broke out in clashes with security forces who used tear gas to disperse them, leaving 1 - 4 dead, several injured and several arrested. They also attacked motorcyclists, stealing and breaking their helmets. 12 police officers were later arrested in an inquiry into the incident.

column6: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Mobile Intervention Unit
column17: At least 8 police officers from the elite mobile intervention unit tortured protesters after they were arrested on March 9th.
Chadian and French troops exchanged fire due to a misunderstanding. Two people were injured.
Hundreds of Nigerians marched to support Chadian and Cameroonian troops fighting against Boko Haram.
Boko Haram ambushed civilians going to market and killed 7 with knives and guns.
Boko Haram militants attacked the market town of Ngouboua looting property and stealing as many as 500 head of livestock. No casualties were reported.
After a suspect died in police custody, protesters burned vehicles and markets and ransacked offices. Police responded with gunfire; four died and more than ten were injured in the violent clashes.
Seven were killed and several injured in inter-communal clashes in the Salamat area.
Boko Haram attacked Chadian military forces on the island of Choua in Lake Chad. 4 soldiers and 33 militants were killed.
Chadian military planes targeted Boko haram positions on Lake Chad and destroyed food, fuel, and munitions belonging to the insurgents.
Chadian military planes targeted Boko haram positions on Lake Chad and destroyed food, fuel, and munitions belonging to the insurgents.

column16: Daily Leadership (Nigeria); Xinhua; Deutsche Welle; AP
column17: Suicide bombers on motorcycles simultaneously attacked police headquarters and the national police academy, killing at least 23 immediately, with a final death toll of 37. They also wounded more than 100 others and security agents returned fire. At least four of the dead were suspected Boko Haram fighters.
Two men tried to detonate suicide bombs outside the central police station but were intercepted and arrested.
After an exchange of gunfire, police arrested Boko Harams leader for Chad and Northern Cameroon, Baana fanay alias Mahamat Moustapha, with at least two of his accomplices.

Six militants blew themselves up, initially killing themselves as well as five Chadian police officers and injuring at least one other, during a police operation launched Monday against Boko Haram. The death toll was later revised upwards to 13.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Memorom on Lake Chad, killing at least 3 and wounding around 12.
A Boko Haram suicide bomb attack killed 15 and wounded at least 74 others near the central market in NDjamena.

15 people were killed, including one gendarme, and 80 injured in a suicide attack at the entrance of a central market in Ndjamena. The suicide bomber was allegedly wearing a burqa and detonated the bomb when a municipal police officer and paramilitary official stopped the bomber to search him. The attack was claimed by Boko Haram.

Boko Haram fighters attacked Tetewa Island on Lake Chad, near the border with Nigeria. Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Medi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia).
19 Boko Haram fighters and 1 Chadian soldier were killed in an attack on a military position in Konguia (lat/longs not available).
1 villager was killed and 3 others injured in a suspected Boko Haram raid on Midi on the banks of Lake Chad.

Clashes between military and Boko Haram in Blarigi Island on Lake Chad. Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Medi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia).

Clashes between military and Boko Haram in Medi Koura, during a search operation for Boko Haram hiding on the lakes islands. At time of fighting, reported that 6 Boko Haram killed, 15 wounded. One soldier killed. Later, Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Medi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia). In Medi Koura, Boko Haram reported to have kidnapped women and children.

Clashes between military and Boko Haram 20kms south of Baga Sola, Lake Chad. Boko Haram reportedly abducted an unknown number of soldiers. Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Medi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia).
In a battle between Boko Haram and the Chadian military near Tchoukou Telia on Lake Chad, 7 Islamists were killed and 2 soldiers were injured.
Some 10 people have been killed in clashes between rival tribes (Toubou and Zaghawa) near a gold mine.
Two suspected Boko Haram members blew themselves up on Lake Chad while being pursued by the Chadian military.
Boko Haram carried out a pre-dawn strike near Lake Chad, killing 11 soldiers and wounding several. 17 Boko Haram militants also died in the clashes.
Suicide bombers, including 3 women and 2 children likely affiliated with Boko Haram, attacked a fish market and IDP camps, killing 47 and injuring dozens.
Arrests: Police arrested 62 women for wearing full veils in public and also arrested 8 suspected ""jihadis"" in the first major arrests since the veil ban.

Three Boko Haram died and 11 civilians were wounded as soldiers repelled an attempted suicide bombing at the Bougama military post near Bamou village on Lake Chad. Simultaneously soldiers killed 11 Boko Haram members during an attempted suicide attack on the Kaika army post. Two soldiers were also killed.

Two female suicide bombers killed themselves and at least two civilians in an attack attributed to Boko Haram on Ngouboua village. 14 were injured. Days later, the government imposed a state of emergency, limiting movement and authorizing searches.

column16: MSF; AP; RFI; AFP; Deutsche Welle
column17: Three or four suicide attacks at markets on Loulou Fou or Koulfoua island killed at least 27 people including the attackers and injured more than 80.
A Darfuri refugee was found dead outside of the Iridimi camp with ""markings of beatings and torture all over his body.""
Boko Haram suicide bomber attacked a mosque in the village of Miterine on Lake Chad, killing himself and two others and wounding 24.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 31 January 2016, a Boko Haram suicide bomber tried to attack a market at Guie on Lake Chad, but was stopped by local militia. The bomber detonated, killing a vigilante and himself and wounding over 30.
Unemployed graduates held a sit-in to demand government jobs and police dispersed them. Claims that some protesters were ""lightly injured"" denied by authorities.

column7: CAMOJET: Collective of Youth Associations and Movements of Chad
column17: 23 arrested as police dispersed a protest against alleged police violence towards youth at previous demonstrations.
Protesters demonstrated against a recent gang-rape of a young girl, and some student protesters reportedly attacked a police vehicle. Police used tear gas and gunfire in response, killing one.
Students protested against the recent death of a protester at the hands of police, and police dispersed them with tear gas.
Students protested against the recent gang rape of a young girl. Police dispersed them with tear gas.
Students protested against the recent death of a protester at the hands of police, and police dispersed them with tear gas.
Youth protested against the recent gang rape of a young girl and set a market on fire. Seventeen arrested.
Students at two major high schools skipped school in a cotinuation of anti-rape protest despite government bans on protest.
One student shot dead and five injured by soldiers breaking up an anti-rape protest.
Police blocked protesters trying to march against President Deby.
Protesters against President Deby went on strike, shutting down village activities.
Protesters against President Deby went on strike, shutting down village activities.
Protesters against President Deby went on strike, shutting down markets, schools, and transportation.
Protesters against President Deby went on strike, shutting down village activities.
The ruling Patriotic Movement for Salvation hold a counter protest with other parties to support Idriss Debys candidature in the April elections.
Ten civil society groups nited under the banner Enough is Enough periodically meet en masse throughout the day and whistle to show their opposition to Idriss Debys continued rule.
Police disperse about 100 of demonstrating students in Moundou. The students were demanding six months of student grant arrears.
Police used tear gas to disperse opposition protest.
Police fired lived rounds in the air and tear gas to disperse hundreds of protesters gathered to support imprisoned anti-government activists.

column9: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Prison Guards
column17: Prisoners rioted to protest prison conditions and lack of food. Police responded, killing three. Two security forces injured.

column9: CTPD: Chadian Convention for Peace and Development
column17: Reports that supporters of the CTPD opposition were arrested and tortured for a week surrounding recent presidential elections.
Arrests: More than 40 members of the security forces arrested or missing around the time of the presidential elections on April 10th.
Bodies of four members of security forces found in the Chari river after dozens of security forces went missing during presidential elections.
French author Thomas Dietrich, famous for denouncing President Debys regime, was detained upon arrival to NDjamena and expelled to Cameroon. Claims he was beaten and robbed after arrest.
A demonstration by students in Lere was dispersed with forces, resulting in 9 injured, 4 seriously. Several people were also arrested.
Up to 250 people celebrated the sentencing of former dictator Hissene Habre by rushing to the streets, blocking roads.

column7: FONAC: New Opposition Front for Change
column17: Police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse a few hundred opposition protesters demonstrating against the investiture of President Deby.

column7: FONAC: New Opposition Front for Change
column17: Opposition supporters peacefully protested the day before the inauguration of President Deby, but were dispersed by riot police with tear gas. One protester was killed by a bullet after tearing the flag of the ruling party, and another was injured by a bullet.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Four Chadian soldiers have been killed after a mine planted by Boko Haram Islamists destroyed their vehicle. The explosion occurred in Kaiga Kindji, near the border of Chad and Niger.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 4 Chadian soldiers were killed in a raid by Boko Haram fighters into Chad near the Djoroye area on the border with Niger. 6 others were injured. Boko Haram allegedly lost 7 fighters in the fighting.

Students of the University of NDjamena demonstrated in support of their strike (launched 10 days prior, on 15 September) to protest the abolition of scholarships. Police in riot gear were deployed to disperse the protesters, who had burned tires and smashed windows in some cases. 4 student leaders involved in the events were arrested the next day, and released on Sept.28.

Chadian judges decided on Friday to stop work for two weeks on the whole territory, protesting against the 50% of allowances and bonuses for state employees, decided by the government to mitigate the effects of the financial and economic crisis affecting the country.

column7: UNDR: National Union for Democracy and Renewal
column17: The security forces disperse protesters with tear gas on the street as they marched towards a stadium after holding a public meeting at the headquarters of Kebzabos party, the UNDR, in an attempt by the opposition to defy a ban by President Idriss Debys government on a demonstration organised as public anger soared over the nations growing economic crisis. 30 people were arrested.
A man fired on the embassy of the US in Ndjamena but was fought off by Chadian security officers who barricaded the entrance. He is believed to be affiliated with IS.
A group of women staged a protest in Moundou in solidarity with striking labour union members, teachers and students. Some of those who participated were arrested.

column6: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column8: FACT: Front for Alteration and Harmony in Chad
column17: A Chadian rebel group, FACT, claims it was bombed by the Libyan air forces of Khalifa Haftar in the Jebel Saoudah area of northern Chad. The attack killed 1 and wounded 2.
11 people were killed, including 8 farmers and 3 pastoralists, in clashes between the two groups in the Abeche area.
Some parents and their kids gathered at two high schools in NDjamena to demand the government negotiate with striking teachers so the strike can end.

2 people were killed and 10 injured during a dispute between two groups of Mongo. A group related to a military chief in the region fired upon protesting students resulting in 2 deaths and injuries. It was not clear what led to the violence.
60 students were arrested following a protest during which they threw stones at the cars of the Minister of Higher Education and his visiting Senegalese counterpart in N'Djamena.

A journalist was abducted by unidentified assailants in N'Djamena after leaving church. The arrest came shortly after he released an article critical of the president and security/intelligence services.
6 people were killed and 10 injured in a dispute between two families in Gore. Police intervened to restore order.

column7: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
column17: CCVC organized a national phone boycott against a new tax set to come in relating to communications services.
A French national working for a French company was kidnapped by unidentified assailants in Abeche.
12 activists of the Iyina movement were arrested as they prepared to demonstrate at the Labour Exchange in N'Djamena over alleged mismanagement by the government. They were later released.

At least 10 Chadian soldiers were killed and 2 were injured in an attack by unidentified assailants on a prisoner convoy about 60km away from N'Djamena, heading for Koro Toro. Chadian soldiers were believed to have been involved in the attack, which resulted in as many as 80 soldiers released.
Maounde Decladore, spokesman of ""Ca doit changer"" movement disappeared. The Chadian ANS (Agence national de securite) is suspected by his fellow activists.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Nine Chadian soldiers were killed and twenty were wounded in a Boko Haram attack on an army post in the Lake Chad region on Friday. 38 Boko Haram jihadists were also killed as the army responded to the attack on the Kaiga post. The attack does not seem to have been pre-meditated. The weakened jihadists have been forced to constantly move around for several weeks on the shores of Lake Chad in search for food from residents, but also to escape from regular patrols by the army that are criss-crossing the area

column16: Reseau des Journalistes pour les Droits de l'Homme
column17: Chadian refugees settled in Ambassala in Central African Republic fleeing Zaghawa razzias and violence in the village of Mambassa.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Eight Chadian soldiers have been killed in clashes with the Islamist militant group, Boko Haram, on the weekend. Another 18 were wounded in the fighting with the militant group on five islands near the border with Nigeria, the Chadian army confirmed. The army claimed their troops had killed 162 Boko Haram fighters and destroyed six vehicles along with many of the motorcycles often used by Boko Haram fighters in their raids. In contrast, Boko Haram says they killed 74 Chadians in attacks.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Eight Chadian soldiers have been killed in clashes with the Islamist militant group, Boko Haram, on the weekend. Another 18 were wounded in the fighting with the militant group on five islands near the border with Nigeria, the Chadian army confirmed. The army claimed their troops had killed 162 Boko Haram fighters and destroyed six vehicles along with many of the motorcycles often used by Boko Haram fighters in their raids. In contrast, Boko Haram says they killed 74 Chadians in attacks.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: Eight Chadian soldiers have been killed in clashes with the Islamist militant group, Boko Haram, on the weekend. Another 18 were wounded in the fighting with the militant group on five islands near the border with Nigeria, the Chadian army confirmed. The army claimed their troops had killed 162 Boko Haram fighters and destroyed six vehicles along with many of the motorcycles often used by Boko Haram fighters in their raids. In contrast, Boko Haram says they killed 74 Chadians in attacks.
Former opposition leader Laoukein Medard was brutally arrested and brought to the police station: during the operation, teargas were used against his supporters and a number of people were wounded.
Police reportedly physically assaulted opposition leaders who had come to visit the Mayor of Moundou in prison. Some were injured and one was arrested.

A policeman fired shots to disperse a group of agitated teachers who had gathered at the Education Ministry's HQ in Ndjamena for administrative purposes. The shot injured at least five teachers. The policeman was arrested, while syndicates say other policemen fired tear gas.
A vehicle transporting gold panners was hit by a IED. 8 dead, 11 wounded (6 severely).

column6: CCMSR: Military Command Council for the Salvation of the Republic
column17: 6 special anti-terrorist unit vehicles were ambushed while patrolling the area. 3 vehicles burnt, one disappeared. Several dead reported.
Clashes between different communities in Darasna provoked 11 dead, including the gendarmerie company commander of Aboudeia and the Darasna brigade commander who interposed to avoid violence.

Ten people were killed in clashes at a gold mine in the Tibesti Mountains in northern Chad, pitting locals against outsiders in search of riches, a security source told AFP. The violence erupted early Tuesday when local residents told gold miners who had flocked to the central Sahara mountain region from other parts of Chad to leave, the source said on condition of anonymity. ""A fight broke out and the outsiders killed three locals,"" he said. ""The locals then ambushed the outsiders, who ended up leaving the area ... but seven gold miners were killed while the others got away.""
On November 8 2017, a civilian vehicle was struck by a mine in the area of Zouar, resulting in three dead and several wounded.

One person was killed and one wounded in the attack of armed men against a market in the Chadian town of Koulbous. After looting the market, killing one person and wounding another, the attackers retreated to Sudan.

On Sunday, a few hundred people had protested, with the authorization of the police and on the initiative of a coalition of associations claiming to be members of ""civil society"", to denounce the attitude of the United States.

Fighting between rival gold miners left at least 15 people dead in northern Chad on Monday, a security source said. The violence erupted in Iri Bourgouri near the border with Libya, in the Tibesti region. ""A first fight between a local man and an outsider caused one death,"" the source, who asked not to be named, told AFP. ""Then there was a broader clash which left about 15 other people dead and several injured.""

The Chadian army and locals in northern Tibesti were involved in violent clashes on the outskirts of Miski with heavy and light weapons. The armed locals who staged an uprising is believed to have managed to repulse the army, who reportedly left casualties behind.
On September 1, the Chadian air force carried out airstrikes in the areas of Miski and Yebbi-Bou, reports indicated ten civilians injured across the two locations.

High school students demonstrated spontaneously before being dispersed by the police. They erected barricades, burned tires and clogged administrative vehicles approaching the university. According to the spokesman of the police, 10 vehicles were damaged, including 4 police vehicles and 6 private vehicles, on the sidelines of these demonstrations. 143 people including 64 students and 67 thugs were arrested.

Security forces prevented any gathering in the Chadian capital where the authorities had banned a march of civil society. Representatives of Chadian civil society, contacted by AFP, deplored for their part ""several arrests"" of members of civil society on the sidelines of the beginning of demonstrations, and ""violent"" interventions of the police force. Teargas were used and several demonstrators were wounded.

Chadian police used tear gas to disperse youths protesting the anti-austerity measures in N'Djamena. Scores of students and schoolchildren were arrested. Several cars were stoned during the unrest. Riot police were stationed outside some schools and at several key intersections in the capital.
Chadian police dispersed a gathering of protesters who demonstrated against austerity measures in NDjamena, the police fired teargas and arrested about a dozen individuals.

column8: PDPT: Democratic Party of the Chadian People
column17: Non-violent activity: Tensions mounted as the government suspended ten opposition parties under the pretext of disturbing public order and inciting violence, while unions, civil groups and opposition politicians called for a tougher strike and a Thursday of anger, a planned march banned by authorities.
Low participation of protesters with only a few dozen marching amidst planned Thursday of anger in NDjamena, police responded by arresting a dozen.
Small numbers of protesters gathered in and on the outskirts of NDjamena, shouting anti-government slogans, one gathering was dispersed by police.
Presumed ISWAP militants killed two Chadian soldiers by ambush between the locality of Ngouboua and Nigerian border in the Lake Chad region.
Nine people were killed in intercommunal violence between Arab herders and indigenous tribesmen in the Chigue area of Abeche.

On March 13, protesters stormed the offices of labour exchanges in Ndjamena to participate in the general assembly of the Union of Chadian Trade Unions in order to hear report regarding payment of salaries and cuts.

On 17 March, the security services arrested three opposition party members in Doba, the party claims that their members and a collaborating member of another party have been subjected to forced disappearance.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 23 March, the Chadian army clashed with Boko Haram militants on the islet of Tchoukou Hadje. Twenty militants and one soldier were killed amidst the fighting, five soldiers were also wounded.

column7: Military Forces of Libya (2014-) Haftar Faction
column17: On or around 23 March 2018, Subol Al-Salam Brigade forces carried out a military operation in the territory of Ennedi Ouest, Chad. They freed eight of the twelve truck drivers abducted in the south of Al Kufra by Chadian armed groups. They also killed 3 Chadian militants and captured 2 others in addition to capturing a number of military vehicles in their possession.
On May 22, gendarmes opened fire on the vehicle of a lawyer who had picked up three clients who previously had been imprisoned for taking part in protests.
On May 28, Chad witnessed a massive protest movement with public services disrupted.
On June 15, intercommunal violence between presumed Arab and native militiamen in the area of Molou resulted in at least 7 killed and a dozen wounded.

column6: Military Forces of Chad (1990-) Nomad and National Guard of Chad
column17: On June 29, two people were killed and four wounded when local authories attempted to settle a land dispute with locals in Ataguil, area of Bokoro. A nomad guard and a notable were killed in the clashes.
On June 29, it was reported that unknown gunmen had opened fire and killed two civilians and wounded a third severely in the area of Ngoura, Hadjer-Lamis.
On July 19, ISWAP militants attacked the village of Daboua, 18 civilians were killed, 2 wounded, and 10 women abducted.

column6: CCMSR: Military Command Council for the Salvation of the Republic
column17: On August 11, Chadian rebels (CCMSR) attacked two army positions in the area of Kouri Bougoudi near the Libyan border, several soldiers were killed in the attack including three officers, a dozen soldiers were also taken prisoners and about twenty vehicles seized. Unknown fatalities.

column16: Alwihda (Chad); VOA; Tchad Actuel; Le Tchadanthropus; Toubou Media; Tchad Convergence
column17: On August 16, the Chadian air force carried out airstrikes against the locality of Houo near the mining area of Miski, some reports indicate that four children were wounded and three others gone missing, livestock was also killed and water reservoirs and other infrastructure destroyed.

On August 17, the Chadian air force carried out airstrikes in the area of Kouri Bougoudi, some reports indicate civilians were wounded and that water reservoirs and other infrastructure were destroyed.
On August 21, a bodyguard killed a South African humanitarian worker he worked for in the town of Baga-Sola after a dispute.

column6: CCMSR: Military Command Council for the Salvation of the Republic
column17: On August 21, the Libya-based Chadian rebel group CCMSR announced that it had attacked an army position in the mining area of Kouri Bougoudi near the Libya border, routing the Chadian army who allegedly did not put up any resistance. Chadian authorities denied that the attack had taken place.
On September 1, the Chadian air force carried out airstrikes in the areas of Miski and Yebbi-Bou, reports indicated ten civilians injured across the two locations.

column7: UNET: National Union of Chadian Students
column9: UNET: National Union of Chadian Students
column17: On September 1, a group of students armed with knives, machetes and a gun attacked the president of the National Union of Chadian Students (UNET) who received several stab wounds from knife and machete, the assailants also claimed affiliation with UNET.
On September 13, the Chadian air force carried out airstrikes on the town of Kouri Bougoudi, killing two civilians and wounding two others.

On September 17, green belt employees staged a protest outside the treasury in NDjamena, claiming unpaid wages and social benefits, the protest was violently dispersed by security forces who fired tear gas, three protesters were wounded and three arrested.
On September 29, 2018, Fulani gunmen killed three farmers and wounded others who were returning from the market in Bologo.

On September 29, ISWAP militants killed two soldiers, two rangers and a customs officer in an attack on the areas of Moussarom and neighbouring Nguelea, 17 militants were killed in a counter-attack. Fatalities split between two locations.

On September 29, ISWAP militants killed two soldiers, two rangers and a customs officer in an attack on the areas of Moussarom and neighbouring Nguelea, 17 militants were killed in a counter-attack. Fatalities split between two locations.

column7: CASAS: Coalition of Civil Society Associations for Citizen Action
column17: On September 29, a protest meeting was organized by the civil society organization CASAS in NDjamena to denounce those that the organization deems as wanting to destroy Chad including Islamist militants, drug traffickers and other civil society organizations and activists.

On September 30, it was reported that an armed group in the area of Tibesti had arrested a group it accused of theft, one of the suspected thieves was tied behind a vehicle an dragged, he survived with severe wounds, 14 others went gone missing with no news about their fate.

column6: CCMSR: Military Command Council for the Salvation of the Republic
column17: On October 4, the Libya-based Chadian rebel group CCMSR released the soldiers taken prisoners amidst the attack against army positions in Kouri Bougoudi on August 11, following negotiations between notables on the respective side. Location coded as Kouri Bougoudi at geoprecision 2.
On October 4, ISWAP militants struck a Chadian army headquarters in Litri with a barrage of five mortar shells, killing one soldier, wounding another, and burning the site (approx. Coordinates used).
On October 4, employees of the National High Commission of Demining staged a protest near the presidency in NDjamena, demanding 11 months unpaid salaries.
On October 10, ISWAP militants killed 8 Chadian soldiers and wounded 11 in an attack on army positions in the area of Kaiga Kindjira, 48 militants allegedly killed in a counter-attack.
On October 19, Arab and Ouaddaian militiamen clashed in Djire, four Ouaddaians were killed and one Arab was wounded.
On October 24, the Chadian air force carried out an air raid on the village of Yebbi-Bou allegedly targeting civilian homes.

column8: CCMSR: Military Command Council for the Salvation of the Republic
column16: CCMSR; RFI; Tchad Actuel; Le Tchadanthropus; Tchadinfos; Alwihda (Chad)
column17: On October 24, the Chadian army clashed with Chadian rebels (CCMSR) in the area of Miski, there were wounded reported on both sides.
On October 25, the Chadian air force carried out an air raid in the Bardai area reportedly hitting a wedding cortege, wounding four civilians.
Around October 28, unknown gunmen clashed with a self-defense group after having abducted a father and his son in the village of Toumetchine (coded as Lame at geoprecision 2).

Around October 28, after a father and his son were abducted by unknown gunmen three weeks earlier in the village of Toumetchine (coded as Lame at geoprecision 2), one of the victims was killed by the abductors while the other was released on November 17.
On October 28, a new Chadian rebel group was created named Mouvement de la Liberation du Tchad (MLT) or Chad Liberation Movement.

On October 29, the Chadian army attacked the town of Miski to gain control of the locality, the attack was repelled by armed locals, ten soldiers were reported to have been killed and others wounded in the clashes and when a vehicle was struck by a landmine, wounded were also reported among the local self-defense.
On October 29, locals in Zouar arrested the subprefect, tied him, gunshot wounded him, and took him to an unknown destination.
On October 31, the Chadian army and armed locals clashed in the area of Miski, the army carried out bombardments with aircrafts and artillery. No casualties reported.
On November 9, the Chadian army vehicles were completely destroyed by the explosion of a landmine in Miski resulting in an unknown number of casualties. Unknown fatalities.
On November 10, heavy clashes raged between the Chadian army and a self-defense group in Miski, both sides suffered heavy losses. Unknown fatalities.
On November 12, the Chadian air force struck Miski self-defense positions in the area of Miski.

On November 13, the Chadian air force struck Miski self-defense positions in the area of Miski while army ground forces clashed with the local self-defense fighters, resulting in an unknown number of killed. Unknown fatalities.
On November 17, four people were killed amid intercommunal violence between Arab herders and Maba farmers in the area of Ngormo (coded as Chechan at geoprecision 2).
On November 17, unknown gunmen abducted a woman in the area of Gagal.

On November 17, the Chadian army claimed that it had routed the local self-defense in Miski, the latter claimed the army faked its presence in Miski, but acknowledged that the town was under siege and the humanitarian situation dire.
On November 18, three Pastoralist militia stabbed a cotton farmer to death in the village of Ganboke while herding their livestock across the field of the farmer.
In the week of November 19, a communal militia in coordination with defence and security forces seized a number of military weapons in the area of Tine.

On or around 21 November 2018, IS-aligned Boko Haram militants attacked the Chadian army barracks in the town of Kaiga near the Lake of Chad with mortars, killing two soldiers, injuring some other and destroying two vehicles.
On November 22, four people were killed amidst clashes between Arab Pastoralist militia and Maba farmers militia in the village of Guerry Am Barberi (coded as Am Hidan at geoprecision 2).
On November 22, Arab Pastoralist militia in military fatigues attacked the village of Chombol (coded as Chechan at geoprecision 2), killing eight people and wounding an elderly woman.
On November 23, the Chadian army reportedly lifted their siege of Miski and surroundings areas and withdrew.
On November 24, a group of people killed two teachers while pursuing a thief in Deli, near Moundou.
On November 26, unknown gunmen killed two civilians and abducted a woman and her baby in the area of Lame.
On November 28, security forces clashed with Janjaweed militiamen in the area of Kognere (coded as Biere at geoprecision 2), one gunman was arrested while the others escaped.
On December 4, unknown gunmen abducted a civilian in Zavou (Djavou).
On December 4, security forces supported by a local militia carried out an operation and liberated four hostages in the area of Gagal, a gunman was arrested in the operation.

column8: FPR: Popular Front for the Recovery
column17: On December 6, the Chadian judiciary condemned the long-serving former rebel leader and political figure Baba Ladde to eight years in prison on numerous charges including arson of villages, rapes, association with thugs and more, Ladde has already been imprisoned for three years.
On December 7, hundreds of representatives of herder and farmer communities participated in a reconciliation ceremony in Abeche to end three years of hostilities.
On December 7, it was reported that defence and security forces had begun an disarmament operation in order to remove civilian possession of arms on the outskirts of Abeche.

column6: UFDD: Union of Forces for Democracy and Development
column17: On December 8, a group of 20 former UFDD combatants offically laid down arms in a ceremony in Ounianga Kebir.

On December 12, a police colonel arrested an alleged thief who he and a number of associates tortured for six days at the home of the colonel in NDjamena, the victim succumbed to his wounds on December 21, the colonel was subsequently arrested.

column7: Military Forces of Chad (1990-); Baga Sola Communal Militia (Chad)
column17: On December 15, the Chadian contingent of the MNJTF supported by local vigilante committees killed 21 ISWAP militants and arrested 6 others in the area of Kindjiria.
On December 17, students at the Sarh University in Doyaba staged a protest, demanding improved study conditions including school transport and canteen.

column9: Government of Chad (1990-); Police Forces of Chad (1990-)
column17: On December 18, unknown gunmen in military fatigues aboard a pickup truck robbed the provincial treasury in Faya Largeau and seized a significant sum of cash after having tied up the guard.

On December 26, residents in Bardai burned tires and dismantled a stand intended for the installation ceremony of the newly appointed governor which was the reason for the protests, Chadian military responded with live fire, there were no reports of injuries.
On December 27, 28, and 29, 30 people were killed and around 200 wounded amidst intercommunal violence between Arabs and Ouaddaians in Kouri Bougoudi, fatalities split between three events.
On December 27, residents in Bardai barricaded roads and burned tires in response to the installation of the newly appointed governor, Chadian military dispersed the protests.

column6: FSR: Front for the Salvation of the Republic
column17: On December 28, it was reported that a number of members of the rebel group FSR in the beginning of the week had agreed to and laid down arms in Tissi.
On December 28, unknown gunmen gunshot wounded the son of an army general in front of his residence in the Njari area of NDjamena.
On December 27, 28, and 29, 30 people were killed and around 200 wounded amidst intercommunal violence between Arabs and Ouaddaians in Kouri Bougoudi, fatalities split between three events.
On December 27, 28, and 29, 30 people were killed and around 200 wounded amidst intercommunal violence between Arabs and Ouaddaians in Kouri Bougoudi, fatalities split between three events.
On December 31 and January 1, Libyan Arabs and Ouaddaians clashed in the mining area of Kouri Bougoudi resulting in tens of dead (fatalities split between events).
On December 31, 58 former rebels detained at the Amsinene prison in NDjamena benefited from amnesty and were released.
On December 31 and January 1, Libyan Arabs and Ouaddaians clashed in the mining area of Kouri Bougoudi resulting in tens of dead (fatalities split between events).
On May 1, trade unionists staged a protest march in NDjamena, demanding social justice and the abolishment on taxes levied on payments for social rights.

On January 10, a policeman opened fire to break up a fight in Abeche, one of the individuals involved in the brawl was killed, family members of the victim in turn assaulted a group of policemen and wounded one who was taken to hospital.

On January 10, a policeman opened fire to break up a fight in Abeche, one of the individuals involved in the brawl was killed, family members of the victim in turn assaulted a group of policemen and wounded one who was taken to hospital.
On January 17, Chadian forces arrested 27 suspected ISWAP members in the Lac Region (coded as Bol at geo precision 3).

column7: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Prison Guards
column9: Prisoners (Chad); CCMSR: Military Command Council for the Salvation of the Republic
column17: On January 18, three CCMSR cadres were taken away from the prison in NDjamena and brought to an unknown destination.
On January 21, students at a university in NDjamena staged a protest against the closing of registrations for the academic year 2017-2018.

On January 22, security forces intervened in a land dispute between the family of a chieftain in the area of Bol and members of the Daguia community, the security forces shot dead one Daguia member and seized a heard of livestock.
On January 22, a senior police official in Tibesti announced his defection to the Miski self-defense committee.
On January 23, members of the Daguia community assaulted family members of a chieftain in Bol, two individuals were wounded in the confrontation.
On January 24, students at a university in NDjamena staged a protest against the closing of registrations for the academic year 2017-2018.
On January 25, students at a university in NDjamena staged a protest against the closing of registrations for the academic year 2017-2018.

On January 26, students at a university in NDjamena barricaded offices and prevented access to teachers, a security officer fired gunshots and threw a grenade, wounding several students including one severely.

column8: UFR: Union of Forces for Resistance
column17: On February 1, the Chadian air force carried out airstrikes against UFR rebels crossing into Chad from Libya (coded as Karyari at geoprecision 2).

column8: UFR: Union of Forces for Resistance
column17: On February 2, the Chadian air force carried out airstrikes against UFR rebels crossing into Chad from Libya.

On February 2, an unknown gunman climbed the wall of the prison of Amsinene in N'Djamena and opened fire against the cell of former rebel leader Baba Ladde who escaped unharmed from what possibly was an attempted assassination or intimidation.

column8: UFR: Union of Forces for Resistance
column17: On February 3, French forces carried out airstrikes against a convoy of 40 UFR rebel vehicles who crossed the border from Libya into northeastern Chad (coded as Karyari), the convoy was dispersed with no reported casualties.
On February 4, employees at the National Program for Food Security and the National Office for Rural Development staged a protest in front of the Ministry of Agriculture demanding reimbursement.

column8: UFR: Union of Forces for Resistance
column17: On February 5-6, French forces carried out airstrikes against UFR rebels crossing into Chad from Libya (coded as Karyari at geoprecision 2), 20 vehicles were destroyed by airstrikes in two days, unknown fatalities coded as 20 based on number of vehicles destroyed with minimum number of assessed fatalities as 1 per vehicle, fatalities split between events.

column8: UFR: Union of Forces for Resistance
column17: On February 5-6, French forces carried out airstrikes against UFR rebels crossing into Chad from Libya (coded as Karyari at geoprecision 2), 20 vehicles were destroyed by airstrikes in two days, unknown fatalities coded as 20 based on number of vehicles destroyed with minimum number of assessed fatalities as 1 per vehicle, fatalities split between events.

column6: UFR: Union of Forces for Resistance
column17: On February 5 and 9, UFR rebels surrendered to Chadian forces in the areas of Am Djarass and Bao Bilia in Ennedi-Est.
On February 11, the local office of the governing party MPS organized a protest march in Am Timan to express support for the defence and security forces.

On February 11, dozens of students protested in front of the rectorate of N'Djamena university, the police fired warning shots to prevent the students from entering, and also arrested around ten students.
On February 12, activists of the governing party MPS organized a protest march in Massakory to express their support for the defence and security forces.
On February 13, residents in the province of Hadjer-Lamis marched in support for the defence and security forces.

On February 15, the governing party MPS organized a rally in N'Djamena to put support for the government and the defence and security forces on display in the wake of a rebel incursion repelled by a French aerial intervention, schools were closed down for students to join the rally.

On February 18, students in N'Djamena staged a protest and demanded improved studying conditions and the resignation of the university director and the minister of higher education. Gendarmes fired shots in the air to disperse them.
On February 19, presumed ISWAP militants attacked the village of Bourboura, killing five civilians, wounding five others, and seizing supplies.
On February 19, presumed ISWAP militants abducted 12 people including nine women in a village named Ngatchia.
On February 19, the ruling party MPS organized a protest march in support of defence and security forces in Abeche.
On February 20, presumed ISWAP militants abducted seven people (one later managed to escape) and seized 200 heads of livestock in the village of Bohouma.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: 20 February. Boko Haram attack the village of Hougou in the Ngouboua area of Lac region. No deaths are reported.

On February 23, gendarmes and police opened fire against a group of female students protesting in Abeche, wounding ten with live bullets, eleven men were also arrested in connection to the events. [size=no report]
On February 25 and 26, at least seven people were killed amidst intercommunal violence between Fulani herders and Marba farmers in the village of Messere. Fatalities spread across 2 days of violence.
On February 25, unknown individuals assaulted a journalist and seized his motorbike in N'Djamena.
Around February 26, intercommunal violence between Fulani herders and Marba farmers left more than 40 dead in the canton of Dadji. Coded as 33 fatalities (seven reported in separate event).
On February 25 and 26, at least seven people were killed amidst intercommunal violence between Fulani herders and Marba farmers in the village of Messere. Fatalities spread across 2 days of violence.

On February 26, a Fulani family indicated that men of a customary chief had abducted their daughter in Moile (coded as Massenya at geoprecision 2), there were conflicting reports on exactly when she was taken, the allegations were denied by the customary chief and his entourage who provided an alternative version of the circumstances.

column7: Police Forces of Chad (1990-); Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Mobile Intervention Unit
column17: On March 1, gendarmes, the nomadic guard, and the police arrested 200 illegal immigrants (some of them armed) in the locality of Zagara, 300km from Mao (coded as Mao at geoprecision 3).

column8: UFDD: Union of Forces for Democracy and Development
column16: Toubou Media; Akhbar Libya; AFP; Alwihda (Chad)

On March 2, presumed ISWAP militants attacked the village of Ngollom (coded as Kaiga Kindjiria at geo precision 2), one killed in each camp and two wounded.
On March 3, Chad announced the closure of its border with Libya following repeated rebel incursions.
On March 6, women on Moundou staged a protest in support of president Idriss Deby and to denounce incursions by rebels and militants [size=dozens].

column6: UFDD: Union of Forces for Democracy and Development
column17: On March 6 (during the week), 400 members of the UFDD laid down arms in Wour.

column6: Military Forces of Chad (1990-) Republican Guard

On March 7, two people were killed and five wounded amidst intercommunal violence between Fulani herders and presumed Somrai farmers in the Soumray area of Lai (coded as Lai at geoprecision 2).
On March 18, 12 people were killed amidst intercommunal violence between Fulani herders and Nanchere farmers in the area of Delbian.
On March 20, students in Abeche welcomed the minister of higher education by staging a protest, chanting anti-strike slogans and demanding teachers to get paid. [size= no report]

column16: Tchadinfos; AFP; Xinhua; RFI; Tchad Actuel
column17: On March 22, presumed ISWAP militants attacked a Chadian army position in Dandallah, 23 soldiers were killed and others wounded, the militants seized arms and equipment before withdrawing.

On March 23, the Chadian army arrested 400 artisanal miners in the Ennedi-Ouest Region during sweeps near the border with Libya, a well was also destroyed to prevent armed groups and others to supply while travelling across the desert.

column7: Police Forces of Chad (1990-); GNNT: Nomad and National Guard of Chad; Military Forces of Chad (1990-)
column17: On March 25, a mixed force composed of police, gendarmerie, the nomad guard, and army units was installed in Wour assigned to secure the border with Libya.

On March 25, victims of the Habre-regime staged a protest outside their headquarters in N'Djamena to remind the judiciary and the government about their obligations toward their citizens. [size=two hundreds]
On March 26, the police raided the market in Gaoui in order to dislodge merchants, four civilians were wounded including one severely.
On March 31, three children were killed while picking up some kind of ammunition or explosive device in the area of Boulalaty, near Massakory.

column6: Military Forces of Chad (1990-) Republican Guard
column17: Around April 1, the presidential guard gunshot wounded a civilian aboard a motorbike near the presidential palace in Ndjamena.

column7: Government of Chad (1990-); Labour Group (Chad); Women (Chad)
column17: On April 2, a group of female civil servants staged a protest in front of the town hall in NDjamena, demanding social rights. [size=fifty]
On April 5, a mechanic threw a stone on a bus, breaking a window and wounding a student, triggering a brawl between a group of students and mechanics in the Chaouga area of Ndjamena.[size=two dozen]

column6: Military Forces of Chad (1990-) Republican Guard
column17: On April 7, a presidential guard shot dead an employee of the National Social Insurance Fund who travelled in a vehicle in front of the presidential palace in Ndjamena.
On April 8, students in NDjamena staged a protest in front of the ministry of health, demanding the payment of their arrears for three years.[size=dozens]
On April 13, a vehicle was struck by a mine in the area of Miski, one individual killed and others wounded.

On April 14, a military convoy reportedly led by the prefect of Pende and the canton chief of Koutoutou pillaged the village of Manigaga and assaulted villagers, seven people were arrested and taken to the gendarmerie.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
