column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On April 16 presumed ISWAP/Boko Haram militants attacked a gendarmerie position in Dabantchali (coded as Koultime at geo precision 2), and killed one gendarme and wounded three others.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On April 23, ISWAP/Boko Haram militants attacked an army position on the island of Tetewa, killing four soldiers and wounding two others, six militant were also killed in the attack.

On 25 April 2019, residents in Ndjamena staged a protest in response to the shortage of gas, security forces intervened and beat up and arrested a thirteen activists of the Chadian Collective Against Expensive Life. [size=at least thirteen]

Around April 29, a Chadian-Sudanese joint force clashed with alleged cattle thieves in Ouaddai near the border with Sudan (coded as Adre at geoprecision 3), a Chadian officer of rank colonel was killed in the clashes.

On April 30, students in NDjamena burned tires in protest against a decree setting tuition fees, security forces intervened by firing tear gas, the students also destroyed a walkie-talkie belonging to a member of the seucrity forces.[size=no report]
On May 2, students in NDjamena burned a tire in protest against a decree setting tuition fees, security forces intervened to disperse the protest.[size=no report]

On May 3, journalists of the private press staged a protest in front of a hotel in NDjamena where the ministry of communication had organized festivities, condemning the imbalances in treatment between the public and private press.[size=no report]
On 8 May 2019, a man succumbed to injuries sustained while being tortured by policemen at a police station in NDjamena (N'Djamena).

column8: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Mobile Intervention Unit
column17: On May 15, residents in NDjamena burned checkpoints, a police motorbike, and clashed with police of the Mobile Intervention Unit following the burial of a youth tortured to death in police detention, the police responded by firing teargas and carry out arrests, several policemen were wounded in the confrontations.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On May 16, suspected ISWAP/Boko Haram militants attacked the island of Felia (Falia) and killed thirteen civilians, hamlets were burned, and people on a boat were swiftly detained.
On May 16, Arab militiamen attacked the village of Katafa, and Ouaddaian militiamen fought back, and twelve people were killed including nine Ouaddaians and three Arabs.
On May 18, the gendarmerie arrested 33 people suspected assailants and others involved in the attack on the village of Katafa two days earlier.
On May 19, Arab herdsmen and Ouaddaian farmers clashed in the villages of Am Chaloka, Am Sabarna and Am Siriye (coded as Goz Beida at geoprecision 3), 22 people were killed and 28 wounded.

On May 20, students at the University of Toukra staged a protest demanding improved studing conditions and the reopening of the school restaurant, the police dispatched several vehicles to control the situation. [size=no report]
Between May 21 and 26, the gendarmerie arrested 92 individuals in Chokoyan, in possession of arms and on suspicion of involvement in intercommunal violence.
On May 21, farmers and herders clashed in Nala, three people were killed.
On May 24, intercommmunal violence due to a land dispute between members of the Moundang and the Moussey communities in Mbio left eleven people dead.
On May 25, presumed ISWAP/Boko Haram militants attacked a military position in Berkara near Ngouboua, twenty-three militants and one soldier were killed in the clashes.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column16: Tchadinfos; Alwihda (Chad); RFI; Toumai Web Medias
column17: On May 25, an army convoy was struck by a mine between Baga Sola and Ngouboua, killing five soldiers and a cameraman, and wounding eleven others.
On May 25, policemen in NDjamena tortured a man in detention to death.
On May 28, two groups of students clashed at a secondary school in Sarh clashed with white weapons, leaving sixteen people wounded and at least three arrested.[size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Mobile Intervention Unit
column17: On June 1, the mobile intervention unit of the police broke up a meeting of the political party Transformers (The Party of Changes) at the House of Women in N'Djamena, the policemen fired tear gas and allegedly assaulted attendants of the meeting.
On June 1, defense and security forces arrested 28 individuals for involvement in intercommunal violence in the Torok subprefecture.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On June 2, suspected ISWAP/Boko Haram militants attacked the village of Medi-Koura, a member of the Sultan of Bol's guard corps was killed in the attack and shops pillaged by the assailants.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On June 2, suspected ISWAP/Boko Haram militants seized a vehicle belonging to a humanitarian NGO 15km south of Ngouri (coded as Bourom at approximate location).
On June 14, three people were wounded amidst intercommunal fights between pastoralists and farmers surrounding a land dispute in Deli. [size=no report]

On June 14, water and forest agents and a gendarme exchanged fire with gunmen smuggling illegal wood in the Lamadji area of Ndjamena, the gendarme and a civilian were killed in the shootout and two others wounded.
On June 16, three people were wounded amidst fights between farmers and pastoralists in Deli.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On June 21, suspected ISWAP/Boko Haram militants ambushed the Chadian army near Ngouboua, and killed eleven soldiers and wounded others including senior commanders, twenty-six militants were allegedly killed in the attack.

On June 23, after pastoralists attempted to rob people travelling aboard motorbikes in the area of Mimi, one of the robbers was wounded and succumbed at the hospital in Biltine. This triggered an act of revenge, as people close to the deceased opened fire against civilians in the village of Choukhara, leaving three people dead and others severely wounded.

column8: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Prison Guards
column17: On June 24, detainees at the prison in Bol staged a demonstration against poor prison conditions, the demonstration eventually turned into a prison break and security forces stationed outside the facility shot dead one prisoner and wounded five others, some prisoners reportedly managed to escape.[size=twenty]

Around June 24, Janjaweed militiamen abducted members of an anti-smuggling unit of the joint task force in the process of seizing two vehicles belonging to a group of smugglers in the area of Tissi, both the security force members and the smugglers were taken to Sudanese territory, the abductees were tortured and the vehicles destroyed, the commander of the joint force and a prefect travelled to Sudan 72 hours later to solve the situation.
On June 27, ISWAP/Boko Haram militants targeted an army position in Kogoua with four mortar shells, allegedly causing injuries.

column6: Military Forces of Chad (1990-) Republican Guard
column17: On July 1, soldiers opened fire against a vehicle driving on the road leading to the presidential palace in Ndjamena, and damaged the vehicle. The fate of the driver remains unknown.
On July 1, two pastoralists and their two horses were found dead and buried in a well in the canton of Bourtail, several suspects were reportedly arrested later.
On July 4, several people were wounded amidst clashes in the village of Batrang (coded as Kelo at geoprecision 2).

column6: Military Forces of Chad (1990-) Republican Guard
column17: On July 4, a soldier beat a refinery worker to death for a mobile phone in Djermaya.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On July 7, presumed ISWAP/Boko Haram militants attacked the gendarmerie in Melea, and killed a gendarme and three civilians.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On July 7, an IED struck an ambulance arriving to the scene of an attack to aid wounded in Melea, no casualties reported.

On July 8, unknown gunmen opened fire against people watching football on screen at a bar in Farchana, and killed six people including two members of the Chadian-Sudanese Joint Forces, the bar owner, a manager and two other people, three people were also wounded.

column9: Military Forces of Chad (1990-) Gendarmerie; Bol Communal Militia (Chad)
column17: On July 11, a gendarmerie killed four civilians including a woman, her daughter, and a teacher who was burned alive in Bol. The assailant then opened fire against intervening policemen and wounded at least two. The assailant was eventually overpowered by villagers and gendarmerie.
On July 13, a brawl erupted between displaced persons at the Gaga refugee camp while the UNHCR conducted a census, no injuries reported. [size=no report]
On July 19, a group of artists staged a protest in NDjamena in solidarity with victims of the regime of the former president Hissein Habre.[size=small]
On July 20, six people were killed and fifteen wounded amidst intercommunal violence between farmers and pastoralists in the village of Tchire II (coded as Tchire at geoprecision 2).

column6: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Joint Sudanese-Chadian Border Guards
column17: On July 23, the Joint Sudanese-Chadian Border Guards seized close to three-hundred weapons in the region of Ouaddai as part of an disarmament campaign in order to prevent intercommunal violence.

column6: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Prison Guards
column17: On July 25, rebel and opposition leader Baba Ladde (who is being held by police) was taken away from the Amsinene prison in Ndjamena under unclear circumstances and to an unknown destination.

Around July 29, unknown gunmen abducted a woman near the village of Tapol and kept her chained in the woods, threatened with rape and subjected her to torture, she was found and freed by a hunter a month later.

On August 3, members of several civil society organizations staged a pro-peace march in NDjamena calling on Chadians to consolidate the achievements of peace and to cohabitate peacefully.[size=hundreds]

On August 5, three people were killed amidst intercommunal violence between Arab pastoralists and Ouaddaian farmers, triggered by the presumed murder of a young pastoralist by a suspected Ouaddaian farmer in the area of Mouhadjirye (coded as Ouadi Hamra at geoprecision 2).

On August 6, unknown gunmen described as poachers coming from Cameroon attacked a position of the Forest and Wildlife Guard (GFF) in the in the Binder-Lere Wildlife Reserve. Seven elephant carcasses were found across the Reserve by the rangers in pursuit of the poachers.
On August 6, twenty-five people were killed amidst intercommunal violence between Arab pastoralists and Ouaddaian farmers in the area of Chokoyan.
On August 6, two people were killed and others wounded amidst intercommunal violence between pastoralists and farmers in Khayra in the Abdi area (coded as Abdi at geoprecision 2).
On August 7, eight people were killed amidst intercommunal violence between Arab pastoralists and Ouaddaian farmers in the area of Chokoyan.

Between August 9-12, 65 people were killed and 35 wounded amidst intercommunal clashes between the Dadjo and Mouro communities in the villages of Arata and Sesabane. Fatalities spread across four events.

Between August 9-12, 65 people were killed and 35 wounded amidst intercommunal clashes between the Dadjo and Mouro communities in the villages of Arata and Sesabane. Fatalities spread across four events.

Between August 9-12, 65 people were killed and 35 wounded amidst intercommunal clashes between the Dadjo and Mouro communities in the villages of Arata and Sesabane. Fatalities spread across four events.

Between August 9-12, 65 people were killed and 35 wounded amidst intercommunal clashes between the Dadjo and Mouro communities in the villages of Arata and Sesabane. Fatalities spread across four events.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column16: AFP; Xinhua; RFI; Alwihda (Chad); Jeune Afrique; Tchadinfos
column17: On August 14, a suspected ISWAP/Boko Haram female suicide bomber detonated an explosive belt at the court of the chief of the Tatafirom canton in Kaiga Kindjiria, and killed a soldier, three members of a local vigilante committee (which also is the chief's guard corps), and a representative of the royal court, five soldiers were also wounded.
On August 15, residents in Abeche staged a protest and surrounded the royal court to prevent the eviction of the royal Ourada family entrenched in the palace, the police intervened. [size=100]
On August 15, ISWAP/Boko Haram militants fired two mortar shells targeting a Chadian army position in Litri.

column16: Toumai Web Medias; Tchadinfos; Jeune Afrique; RFI; Alwihda (Chad); Xinhua; AFP
column17: On August 18, the Chadian president declared a three-month state of emergency in the region of Sila, Tibesti, and Ouaddai starting from August 20, following an episode of deadly intercommunal violence between pastoralists and agriculturalists, troops were dispatched to enforce the state of emergency.

column16: Le Tchadanthropus; AFP; Toumai Web Medias
column17: On August 21, villagers in Bardai reportedly attacked the gendarmerie in reaction to the killing of a family member, as the perpetrator hid at the gendarmerie. Gendarmes stationed there responded to the assault and killed at least three villagers and wounded four others.
On August 24, unknown gunmen shot dead three civilians and abducted a fourth in the village of Gamba.
On August 20, Chad closed its borders with Libya, Sudan, and CAR due to a deteriorating security situation and rise in intercommunal violence in the regions of Sila and Ouaddai.
On August 26, eleven people were killed amidst intercommunal clashes between pastoralists and agriculturalists in Koumogo.

On September 1, ISWAP militants reportedly ambushed a Chadian army unit between Litri and Kaiga (coded as Litri at geo precision 2), and killed three soldiers, wounded another, and seized arms and ammunition.

column9: GNNT: Nomad and National Guard of Chad; Police Forces of Chad (1990-)
column16: Journal du Tchad; Tchadinfos; Le Tchadanthropus
column17: On September 1, residents in the Djatiniye quarter of Abeche prevented an escort composed of gendarmes, nomadic guards, and police to install the new Sultan of Ouaddai following the dismissal of the former. The demonstrators threw stones against the security forces who responded by firing teargas and live rounds, one gendarme was wounded by a stray bullet from his colleagues, and a stone throwing woman was beaten with sticks and arrested by security forces. [size=no report]
On September 2, Chadian soldiers shot dead a man between Yebbi-Bou and Bardai (coded as Yebbi-Bou at geoprecision 2). Circumstances unclear.
On 3 September 2019, two men who stole a motorbike in the Farcha area of NDjamena were chased, lynched, and shot dead by locals.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On September 4, three soldiers were killed by the explosion of an IED presumably planted by ISWAP/Boko Haram militants in the area of Kaiga Kindjiria.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On September 4, suspected ISWAP/Boko Haram militants attacked the village of Kaiga Kindjiria and killed two civilians.
On September 4, Chadian soldiers entered the village of Tchigchika, severely injuring at least three men while seventeen other people were kept detained at the site and subjected to torture.

On September 4, Chadian soldiers entered the village of Tire, one man was reportedly taken away and his family has not received news about his fate, several women were also subjected to assaults and wounded.

On September 10, employees at the mayor's office in Moundou staged a protest in response to twenty-six months of unpaid salaries, security forces intervened by barricading the mayor's office to prevent a sit-in.[size=no report]
On September 10, the government extended the state of emergency in the Ouaddai Region with four months.
On September 10, the government extended the state of emergency in the Sila Region with four months.
On September 10, the government extended the state of emergency in the OTibesti Region with four months.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On September 11, ISWAP/Boko Haram militants attacked the island of Medi Koura and killed two people including an individual close to the chief of Bol, and wounded others.

On September 12, policemen fired teargas in order to disperse family members and the local population opposing the medical evacuation by ambulance of a man gunshot wounded by the police.[size=no report]
On September 12, policemen opened fire against a group of civilians near the police school in Ndjamena, a gunshot wounded a man.
On September 12, it was reported that security forces in Abeche used the state of emergency as a means to racketeer the local population by taxing everyone violating the curfew.
On September 13, villagers in Karma, south of Abeche, handed over eleven firearms to the Sultan of Dar Ouaddai.
On September 15, the Sultan of Dar Ouaddai went to Guerri (Am Hidan) where seventeen villages had handed over forty-five illegal arms in the context of a disarmament.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column16: Toumai Web Medias; Tchadinfos; Journal du Tchad; Alwihda (Chad)
column17: On September 17, one officer was killed and other soldiers wounded when the vehicle they were travelling stuck an IED in Kaiga Kindjiria, the device was likely planted by ISWAP/Boko Haram militants.
On September 19, seventy-six arms handed in by civilians in the cantons of Merander and Mabrozo in the context of disarmament were presented by the prefect in Adre.
On September 21, combined army and gendarmerie units entered the village of Katagane and reportedly tortured two men denounced for being in possession of firearms.

On September 23, the mixed disarmament commission composed of soldiers and gendarmes presented 678 arms including assault rifles, RPG launchers, handguns and 4000 rounds of ammunition in Abeche, seized amidst ongoing disarmament campaign in the Ouaddai Region, a significant share was collected in the cantons of Marfa, Guerri and Bourtail. The arms were seized or turned in during the course of a month.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On September 24, presumed ISWAP/Boko Haram militants attacked an army position in Kaiga Kindjiria, outcome not reported and fatalities unknown.

column16: Alwihda (Chad); Tchadinfos; Journal du Tchad; Toumai Web Medias
column17: On September 24, university students in NDjamena demonstrated against the sanitary situation in and around the faculties and a garbage dump nearby, the students burned waste and barricaded the main routes preventing traffic access, the police intervened, fired warning shots in the air, and carried out arrests to disperse the demonstrators, some students resisted.[size=no report]

On September 25, one hundred thirty firearms were seized from armed civilians (communal and/or militias) by the mixed desarmament commission composed of soldiers and gendarmes in the department of Abdi, and presented at a ceremony in the department capital of Abdi.

On September 26, the governor of the Sila Region and the coordinator of the mixed disarmament commission attended a ceremony in Goz Beida, showcasing 1041 weapons including 6 RPG launchers seized in several areas of the Sila Region from various ethnic and communal militia, by the military forces of Chad

On September 27, Chadian soldiers reportedly entered the village of Marchout, and arrested and detained thirty men under the sun for many hours, the village chief was tied-up and subjected to torture-like treatment, and two women raped.
On September 28, ISWAP militants killed a Chadian soldier in the area of Kali (coded as Bol at geo precision 3), according to claim by the Islamic State organization.

column16: Alwihda (Chad); Journal du Tchad; Toumai Web Medias; Tchadhanana; Toubou Media
column17: On October 3, the self-defense community of Miski engaged the Chadian army in clashes in the area of Enneri Arkenia, in response to the army arresting thirty people and confiscating three vehicles. No casualties reported.

column16: Le Tchadanthropus; Alwihda (Chad); Tchadhanana; Toubou Media
column17: On October 3, the Chadian army arrested dozens of people and seized three vehicles in the area of Enneri Arkenia.

On October 3, the minister of defense and security supervised a reunion with the governors of Ouaddai, Sila, and Tibesti, detailing that 4000 weapons and a large amount of ammunition had been seized during a month-long disarmament campaign in three regions under state of emergency.

On October 4, the Chadian president, the minister of defense and security, the chief of staff of the army, and other officials attended a ceremony where 2000 thousand weapons and large amount of ammunition seized in the Ouaddai Region during the course of 35 days.
On October 4, the Chadian army launched airstrikes in the area of Enneri Arkenia that caused material damages and destruction , no casualties reported.

On October 4, two vehicles of the Chadian army were reportedly destroyed after being struck by a mine, presumably planted by the Miski self-defense committee, in the area of Enneri Arkenia, several wounded soldiers evacuated to Faya.
On October 5, a Chadian army commander reportedly succumbed to wounds sustained after being shot by a presumed Miski self-defense committee sniper in the area of Enneri Arkenia.

column16: Xinhua; Toumai Web Medias; Alwihda (Chad); Tchadhanana; AFP; Tchadinfos; RFI
column17: On October 7, detainees at the jail in Abeche staged a violent demonstration and prison break, reportedly in reaction to poor jail conditions and overcrowding, there were reports that prisoners had seized arms from guards and exchanged gunfire, the army and police qwelled the uprising by firing tear gas and live fire, at least two prisoners were shot dead and more than dozen wounded, an army officer was also severely wounded amidst the clashes.

column8: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Prison Guards
column17: On October 12, 2019, unknown gunmen (suspected to be members of the same clan as the prefect) attacked the jail in Guereda and took two prisoners out with them.

column8: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Mobile Intervention Unit
column17: On October 12, mechanic workers staged a demonstration in the Sans Fil quarter of Ndjamena following a murder attempt one of their colleagues, the demonstrators burned tires, barricaded the main roads, and threw stones, the mobile intervention unit of the police reportedly responded by firing tear gas and live fire, several people were wounded including at least two by gunshot.[size=no report]
On October 14, 2019, victims of the Habre-regime staged a demonstration and prevented traffic access in NDjamena.[size=no report]
Reported on November 1, 2019, that a mixed military force installed in Amgamougna (Gamounia) had tortured and racketeered people in the area in the context of a disarmament campaign. Date unknown.
Reported on November 1, 2019, that a military force had tortured men, women, and children in the village of Kibde, in the context of a disarmament campaign. Date unknown.

column16: Journal du Tchad; Alwihda (Chad); RFI; Le Tchadanthropus; CTDDH; Tchadhanana
column17: On October 16, 2019, the self-defense committee of Miski ambushed a Chadian army convoy in the area of Tini (Toni), and reportedly destroyed several vehicles and left ""heavy casualties"" among the soldiers.

Reported on October 20, 2019 that soldiers demonstrating at a location 40km from Sedigui [coded at geoprecision 2], fired in the air and against a pipeline causing minor material damages.[size=no report]
On October 21, 2019, a customs officer (policeman) opened fire and gunshot wounded a man and a woman in Ndjamena, a mob responded to the shooting by attempting to lynch the customs officer.

column8: Police Forces of Chad (1990-) Customs Office
column17: On October 21, 2019, a mob attempted to lynch a customs officer who previously had opened fire and gunshot wounded a man and a woman in NDjamena.[size=small]
On October 24, 2019, skirmishes between Chadian soldiers and Miski self-defense fighters were reported in the area of Arkenia, no casualties reported.

On October 26, 2019, an internal dispute within the student organisation UNET, triggered violent clashes between two factions of students armed with clubs, knives, and other light weapons. Two students were left seriously wounded.[size=no report]
Reported on October 26, 2019, that victims of the Habre-regime staged a demonstration in past week in NDjamena.[size=dozens]

Reported on October 26, 2019, that the Chadian army had arrested 26 soldiers originating in the region of Borkou-Ennedi-Tibesti [coded to Faya-Largeau at geoprecision 3], and taken them to an unknown destination, the arrests came against the backdrop of clashes and tensions in the area of Miski.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column16: Jeunesse Diffa; Tchad Convergence; Alwihda (Chad); Tchadinfos; Xinhua
column17: On 30 October 2019, Boko Haram (JAS) militants abducted three people including a doctor, a nurse, and a driver while they were travelling between Ngouboua and Tchoukoualia (Mamdi, Lac).

On October 30, notables from Miski and emissaries of the Deby-regime reached a temporary agreement to end hostilities between the Miski self-defense committee and the Chadian army in the areas of Arkenia, Miski, and Yebbi-Bou.

column6: Military Forces of Chad (1990-) Republican Guard
column16: Tchadinfos; Tchadhanana; Tchad Actuel; Alwihda (Chad); Jeune Afrique; RFI; Le Tchadanthropus; CTDDH
column17: On November 4, 2019, the guard corps of the president of the national assembly shot dead a motorcycle-taxi driver in NDjamena.

column16: Toumai Web Medias; CTDDH; Tchadhanana; Alwihda (Chad)
column17: On November 6, 2019, the military escort of the canton chief of Sokoto opened fire against villagers in Kamkalaga who were preventing the passage of the motorcade. Two people were killed and six others wounded.[size=no report]
On November 9, 2019, students demonstrated and burned a tire in reaction to the expulsion of a student outside the university directorate in Ndjamena.[size=no report]
Reported on November 10 2019, that an influential member of the Zaghawa community had tortured three men at his property located three kilometers from Abeche.

column16: Toumai Web Medias; Alwihda (Chad); CTDDH; Toubou Media
column17: On November 11 2019, the Miski self-defense committee and a government delegation composed of senior military and security officials reached a final agreement in Miski and the Miski self-defense committee began to disarm.
On November 14 2019, the mixed disarmament commission recovered eighteen FN-FAL rifles from merchants in Abeche.

On November 15 2019, youths attacked two government vehicles in the Habena quarter of NDjamena, the vehicles were set ablaze and the occupants wounded, the attack is believed to be in response to weak statements by the president of the national assembly after a taxi-driver was shot dead by his guard corps in NDjamena.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column16: Alwihda (Chad); AFP; Toumai Web Medias; Journal du Tchad
column17: On November 16 2019, the corpses of five villagers executed (two victims were beheaded and three shot dead) by presumed ISWAP and/or Boko Haram militants were recovered at an unspecified location in the Lac Region.

On 18 November 2019, victims of the Habre-regime staged a demonstration in the Chagoua area of Ndjamena, demanding justice and compensation for the victims of the former regime. Security forces intervened and fired teargas to disperse the protesters. [size=no report]
On November 20 2019, two people were killed and two others wounded amidst intercommunal violence between farmers and pastoralists in the village of Doudeye.
Reported on November 23 2019, three people were killed in intercommunal violence in the village of Meou (Mayo) near the regional capital of Sarh, four individuals reportedly involved were arrested.
On November 23 2019, participants of a funeral procession in NDjamena staged a protest march, demanding justice for the victim shot dead by security forces.[size=large]

On 25 November 2019, Chadian soldiers arrested civilians including a village chief in Asterena, near Goz Beida (coded as Goz Beida at geoprecision 2), and took them to a military camp were they reportedly were subjected to torture.
On 26 November 2019, soldiers of the mixed force (MNJTF) reportedly abducted an individual close to the canton chief in Bol, his fate remains unknown.
On 27 November 2019, security forces intervened and fired tear gas to disperse angry students after another student had been stabbed amidst a dispute.[size=no report]

On 28 November 2019, a senior policeman and his relatives abducted a man in NDjamena and detained him at private property where he was subjected to torture and sustained a fractured arm and other wounds.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 2 December 2019, an IED presumably planted by ISWAP or Boko Haram militants detonated in Kaiga Kindjiria, and killed six cows.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column16: Toumai Web Medias; RFI; Journal du Tchad; Alwihda (Chad); Journal le Gardien; AFP; Jeune Afrique; Tchadinfos
column17: On 2 December 2019, ISWAP or Boko Haram militants attacked an army position located between Ngouboua and Baga Sola (coded as Ngouboua at geoprecision 2). At least four soldiers and thirteen militants were killed in the fighting, three soldiers were also wounded.

On 4 December 2019, students at the Ecole Normale Superieure in NDjamena began observing a strike in response to the school administration's silence on the matter of internship fees and didactic materials.

On 6 December 2019, students at the Ecole Normale Superieure in NDjamena staged a demonstration, removed staff from the facility, and closed down the administration, demanding there fees paid and didactic materials distributed. Security forces attempted to intervene but did not succeed in preventing the demonstration.[size=no report]
On 9 December 2019, students at the university in Pala staged a demonstration after several students were expelled from class for not having their students cars on them during a control.[size=tens]
On 9 December 2019, high school students from two establishments demonstrated in NDjamena.[size=no report]

On 10 December 2019, farmers armed with blade weapons clashed in a sorghum field in the Fitri department of Batha (coded as Yao at geoprecision 2), two farmers were killed and twenty-three others wounded.[size=no report]
On 10 December 2019, high school students from two establishments clashed in Ndjamena, injuries reported.[size=no report]

On 11 December 2019, high school students from two different schools clashed in NDjamena, injuries reported, the police intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the clashing students.[size=no report]

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column16: Alwihda (Chad); RFI; Tchadinfos; Jeune Afrique; Toumai Web Medias
column17: On 17 December 2019, presumed ISWAP and/or Boko Haram militants attacked the village of Kaiga, and killed fourteen fishermen, wounded five others, thirteen people also went missing.

column6: GNNT: Nomad and National Guard of Chad

Althoug an intial report stated that a student was killed in the events, this was later refuted by police sources and the secretary general of the national union of Chadian students (UNET). [size=large]

CCMSR claimed to have killed fifty soldiers while suffering three dead and five wounded in its ranks, local media further reported that nineteen rebels taken prisoners were summary executed by the army.

The declared toll is assessed to be exaggerated and therefore revised and coded as 100.

column17: On 30 July 2020, Boko Haram attacked Tinana, two kilometres away from Kaiga Kindjira (Fouli, Lac), killed 10 residents, abducted 2 and injured many. The village was looted.

On 10 August 2020, an armed group reportedly targeted the village of Fodio (Kaya, Lac). Outcome not reported and eventual casualties or damages unknown, although the event caused a significant displacement of the local population.
On 12 August 2020, Fulani herders and local farmers clashed in Banga-Dormon in the Lai Sub prefecture (Tandjile Est). 4 people were killed and 24 injured.
On 17 August 2020, pastoralists and farmers clashed near Pala (Mayo-Dallah, Mayo-Kebbi Ouest). One person was killed and three others wounded. [size=no report]
On 18 August 2020, unknown gunmen abducted four pastoralists in the area of Late, about 45km south of Lere (Lac Lere, Mayo-Kebbi Ouest).
On 20 August 2020, flood victims demonstrated in N'Djamena (N'Djamena, N'Djamena) over damages and demanded government assistance. Police forces intervened and dispersed the crowd. [size=no report]

On 22 August 2020, a vehicle of a mobile customs unit struck an IED between Ngouboua and Ngasha (Mamdi, Lac). One customs officer was killed and three others wounded. The device was likely planted by ISWAP militants. The group said in a statement that an IED detonated against a Chadian army vehicle on August 26, and killed seven soldiers between Ngouboua and Tchoukou Ali.

On 28 August 2020, farmers equipped with hunting rifles and machetes attacked an Arab pastoralist funeral in the area of Bourou (Ngourkosso, Logone Occidental). At least nine people were killed in the attack, believed to be a reprisal amid fighting between Arab pastoralists and local farmers over stolen cattle.

On 28 August 2020, Arab pastoralists and farmers clashed in the area of Bourou (Ngourkosso, Logone Occidental). 1 pastoralist was killed in the initial clash which erupted when the pastoralists found a stolen cattle on the property of a farmer. [size=no report]

On 29 August 2020, defense and security forces arrested 43 people, including the Gabri-Ngolo canton chief, three village chiefs and administrators in the area of Gabri Ngolo (Tandjile Est, Tandjile). Those arrested are believed to be involved or having incited an attack against an Arab pastoralist funeral amid fighting over stolen cattle in the area of Bourou.
On 3 September 2020, unidentified gunmen attacked Chadian soldiers at Kouri Bougoudi (Tibesti Ouest, Tibesti). 3 soldiers were killed and 2 injured.

On 4 September 2020, demonstrators gathered in Kouri (Tibesti Ouest, Tibesti) over the alleged imposition of corrupt administrative officials by the Central Government. The group attacked an administrative official and almost lynched the victim. [size=no report]

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 5 September 2020, Boko Haram planted an IED in the Lake Chad area (coded as Bol in Lac province), killing 3 Chadian soldiers and wounded 8.

Around 7 September 2020 (as reported), members of the Sudanese Toros Boros gold miner militia clashed with Chadian Armed Forces around Kouri Bougoudi (Tibesti Ouest, Tibesti). 1 soldier was killed and 1 injured.

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 11 September 2020, suspected Boko Haram (JAS) militants made an incursion into an IDP site in Tataverom and killed two men and abducted a woman.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 17 September 2020, Chadian Armed Forces attacked a base of Boko Haram in the Lake Chad region (coded as province Lac). 10 soldiers were killed.

column6: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 17 September 2020, Boko Haram attacked the island of Koulfoua (Mamdi, Lac) in Lac Chad and looted the village.

column8: Islamic State (West Africa) and/or Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 24 September 2020, Chadian Armed Forces clashed with Boko Haram at Barkalam and Bilabrim, near the Chad-Nigeria Border (coded as Ngouboua, Kaya, Lac). 15 BH fighters were killed in Barkalam and 5 in Bilabrim. 2 soldiers were injured in Bilabrim. 12 hostages were freed.
Around 28 September 2020, ISWAP militants ambushed Chadian troops near Maria situated 31 km southwest of Ngouboua (Lac, Mamdi). Two Chadian soldiers and one civilian were reportedly killed.
On 3 October 2020, an IED exploded at the passage of a donkey in Yakou (Lac). No damages or causalities were reported.

Around 7 October 2020 (as reported), farmers and pastoralists clashed over a land dispute in the village of Nguette situated 35km from Pala (Mayo-Kebi Ouest, Mayo-Dallah). One person was reported killed and another one is missing. [size=no report]
On 8 October 2020, unidentified armed men on motorcycles opened fire and killed a civilian in Gongla situated in Pala (Mayo-Kebbi Ouest, Mayo-Dallah).

column6: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
column17: On 18 October 2020, presumed Ba Koura JAS militants ambushed a Chadian army patrol killing three soldiers in Kindjiria (Lac, Fouli).

column16: Amaq; Toumai Web Medias; GardaWorld; Undisclosed Source
column17: On 19 October 2020, ISWAP militants ambushed a convoy of civilians escorted by Chadian soldiers with an IED and machine guns, 11km from Ngouboua (Lac, Mamdi). Between 6 and 13 Chadian soldiers and four civilians were reportedly killed, while a dozen others were reportedly injured.

On 20 October 2020, farmers and pastoralists clashed with arrows and rocks over a land dispute in the village of Torrok, situated 30km from Pala (Mayo-Kebi Ouest, Mayo-Dallah). Three people were seriously injured. [size=no report]
Widows gather to demand the development of legislation on protection of their rights, on the occasion of International Day of Widows.

column6: Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Agreement: Political parties across the spectrum sign a code of conduct to foster a climate of peace before, during and after the July 15 parliamentary and local elections of 2013. Document initiated by UNDP.

column8: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: A four-year-old child was hurt by a stray bullet and two other people were wounded in Congo as opposition protesters stormed an elections commission office

column8: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Traders rioted in protest of their evacuation from illegally occupying public spaces. 2 police members injured & one set alight.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Police forces of the republic of Congo shot a civilian dead following a fracas in Brazzaville.
Rioters set fire to a police station following the death of a civilian shot by a policeman.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Police intervened to prevent students from the Universite Marien Ngouabi de Brazzaville protesting in the capital.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: 18 people were killed in a raid on bandits in Brazzaville as they took refuge in the residence of ex-deputy secretary general of the National Security Council, Marcel Ntsourou.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: 22 people were killed when a firefight broke out in Brazzaville between soldiers and the bodyguard of a wanted high-ranking army officer.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Amnesty International released a report on the weekend of Jul.4, 2015 that stated that the Republic of Congo expelled at least 179,000 nationals of the DR-Congo between April and September of 2014, with many being subjected to arbitrary detention, torture and rape. They claim that the actions ""may constitute crimes against humanity"".

column6: Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Displacement: As of 5 May, 72,731 DRC Congolese has been expelled from Congo-Brazzaville (since 5 April 2014)

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Students demonstrated in protest against non-payment of bursaries & lack of information about bursary outcomes. Students threw rocks & police fired tear gas.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column7: Rioters (Republic of Congo); Vigilante Group (Republic of Congo)
column17: Kinshasa condemned violence, torture & lynching of expelled DRC Congolese by police & youth in Congo-Brazzaville

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Men led by DRC ex-rebel leader Udjani Mangbama attacked security personnel at a police check near Owando. 8 attackers & 3 police were killed.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Amnesty International released a report on the weekend of Jul.4, 2015 that stated that the Republic of Congo expelled at least 179,000 nationals of the DR-Congo between April and September of 2014, with many being subjected to arbitrary detention, torture and rape. They claim that the actions ""may constitute crimes against humanity"".
Students from lEcole normale superieure protested over late payment of bursaries, and were dispersed by police
Congolese women from the 'Save the Congo' collective and women from the Nigeria community in Congo gathered to condemn the kidnapping of 200 female students in Nigeria
Some Chinese workers from China Corporation and Equipement Company (CSCEC) protested in front of the Chinese embassy in Brazzaville, in protest over unpaid salaries

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Amnesty International released a report on the weekend of Jul.4, 2015 that stated that the Republic of Congo expelled at least 179,000 nationals of the DR-Congo between April and September of 2014, with many being subjected to arbitrary detention, torture and rape. They claim that the actions ""may constitute crimes against humanity"".

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Amnesty International released a report on the weekend of Jul.4, 2015 that stated that the Republic of Congo expelled at least 179,000 nationals of the DR-Congo between April and September of 2014, with many being subjected to arbitrary detention, torture and rape. They claim that the actions ""may constitute crimes against humanity"".

column6: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
column7: CNT: National Transition Council; Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Agreement: A new round of Central African Republic peace talks began in Brazzaville, with a focus on attaining a ceasefire between the armed groups of CAR, chaired by the Congolese president, and involving members of the transitional CAR government as well as Seleka leaders.

column7: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
column9: FSRJ: Special Forces of Revolutionary Justice
column17: Agreement: Seleka and anti-balaka parties and various other armed groups signed a ceasefire accord in Brazzaville after 3 days of negotiations, calling for an immediate end to hostilities.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Movement of forces: Operations to track down and expel Congolese from the DR Congo were launched in Dolisie, in Niari area

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Amnesty International released a report on the weekend of Jul.4, 2015 that stated that the Republic of Congo expelled at least 179,000 nationals of the DR-Congo between April and September of 2014, with many being subjected to arbitrary detention, torture and rape. They claim that the actions ""may constitute crimes against humanity"".
Unidentified people attacked the leaders of the Collective of Congolese Opposition Parties following a meeting, and then clashed with supporters and militants of the collective.

column9: Journalists (Republic of Congo); Women (Republic of Congo)
column17: Heavily armed men attacked the home of a MNTV journalist, robbed him, and raped his sister. Fellow journalists reported that the attack was a reprisal by police elements for the journalists's comments during his programme, which are thought to have upset the government

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Amnesty International released a report on the weekend of Jul.4, 2015 that stated that the Republic of Congo expelled at least 179,000 nationals of the DR-Congo between April and September of 2014, with many being subjected to arbitrary detention, torture and rape. They claim that the actions ""may constitute crimes against humanity"".

National office of Post and Telecommuications workers started a sit-in near Post and Savings Concog (SOPECO) and the Pointe-Noire Central Station to denounce illegal withdrawals from their salary arrears.
Thousands of women marched for peace in response to rising political tensions over a possible constitutional change ahead of the 2016 presidential election.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Students clashed with police after police refused to let them see the body of a peer who had died of an illness in hospital. The youths threw stones abd bottles and the police responded with tear gas. Unpsecified injuries and arrested were reported.
More than one thousand women from across Kouilou marched in Hinda to mark International Womens Day.
Thousands of women from across the districts of Sangha marched in Ouesso to mark International Womens Day and to support its theme of empowerment and development.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Around 600 foreigners, mostly from West Africa, were rounded up, arrested and reportedly subjected to violence, and inhuman/degrading treatment during their detention.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: For a second day, foreigners, mostly from West Africa, were rounded, arrested and reportedly subjected to violence, and inhuman/degrading treatment.
A political ""mega rally"" was held by the Dynamic for the New Republic (DNR) political movement involving youths, women and many different segments of society to suppot a national dialogue.

Thousands of 2015 Baccalaureate candidates rioted in the streets and at various examinations centres in Brazzaville (particularly Ouenze and Bakongo districts) and set up barricades and burned tires, with similar events reported in Pointe-Noire and Dolisie, following the announcement that the general BA tests would be cancelled due to large-scale fraud that has bee found. The student protesters attacked vehicles and buildings, broke windows, and blocked traffic.

Thousands of 2015 Baccalaureate candidates rioted in the streets and at various examinations centres in Brazzaville (particularly Ouenze and Bakongo districts) and set up barricades and burned tires, with similar events reported in Pointe-Noire and Dolisie, following the announcement that the general BA tests would be cancelled due to large-scale fraud that has bee found. The student protesters attacked vehicles and buildings, broke windows, and blocked traffic.

Thousands of 2015 Baccalaureate candidates rioted in the streets and at various examinations centres in Brazzaville (particularly Ouenze and Bakongo districts) and set up barricades and burned tires, with similar events reported in Pointe-Noire and Dolisie, following the announcement that the general BA tests would be cancelled due to large-scale fraud that has bee found. The student protesters attacked vehicles and buildings, broke windows, and blocked traffic.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Movement of forces: 140 members of the ""Formed Police Unit (UPC)"" left Brazzaville to join MINUSCA for deployment around Bangui and its surroundings.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Weapons Seizure: Police seized explosive materials on the outskirts of Brazzaville which they believe were to be used for ""militant acts"" in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire. They were taken from the home of a gang leader who had networks in both cities.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Land owners held a sit in to demand payment for land seized to build an olympic village three years ago. Police dispersed the protesters using tear gas.

column7: FROCAD: Front for the Constitutional Order and Democratic Change; UDC: Union for Congolese Democracy
column17: Thousands of Congolese demonstrated in Brazzaville to oppose the constitutional referendum announced by President Sassou to allow him to run for another term. It was allegedly the largest events held by the opposition since Sassou came to power in 1997. The event was orgnaized by FROCAD and the Union for Congolese Democracy (UDC).
Town hall workers in Pointe-Noire barricaded the entrance to the municipal garage in the Mpita district to demand resolution of their grievances, including a drawdown in salaries.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Tens of thousands of supporters of Congolese President Sassou took to the streets in Brazzaville to support his bid to change the constitution to allow him to run for another term and to remove the age limit of 70 on the presidency. At least 6 demonstrators were arrested.
A collective of students from Marien Ngouabi University organized a peaceful march in Brazzaville against the use of violence in politics.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column16: Xinhua; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)
column17: 6 people were injured during clashes between radical elements of the opposition police during demonstrations against an extended term for President Sassou in Pointe Noire. An opposition leader stated that 13 people had been injured at a press conference the next day. There were also reports of tires being burned, shops being looted, and some violence against civilians and police elsewhere in the city.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Angry youths attacked a police colonel in Pointe-Noire following violent protests the day before. They seriously injured him before security forces were able to disperse the mob and get the colonel to a hospital.

Demonstrators in the Nkouikou district burned tires and blocked traffic to express their anger after hearing that opposition leaders have been banned from traveling to Brazzaville. The ban was lifted by the afternoon.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column9: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column16: Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); RFI
column17: 4 people were killed in violent clashes in Brazzaville and Pointe Noire between security forces, who fired tear gas and shot into the air, and demonstrators who were protesting against the holding of a constitutional referendum to allow President Sassou to run again. 3 of those killed were in Brazzaville, at least 2 of whom died by gunshot, while 10 people were also injured, including 5 by gunfire. 3 police were also seriously injured. 16 people were arrested and there were reports of houses being burned, including that of the Minister of Trade and Supply. A police station was also allegedly burnt down.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column16: AFP; RFI; AP; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)
column17: 4 people were killed in violent clashes in Brazzaville and Pointe Noire between security forces, who fired tear gas and shot into the air, and demonstrators who were protesting against the holding of a constitutional referendum to allow President Sassou to run again. 3 of those killed were in Brazzaville, at least 2 of whom died by gunshot, while 10 people were also injured, including 5 by gunfire. 3 police were also seriously injured. 16 people were arrested and there were reports of houses being burned, including that of the Minister of Trade and Supply. A police station was also allegedly burnt down.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column9: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Dozens of protesters against the constitutional referendum clashed with the police, who allegedly had to fire into the air several times to disperse them.

column9: Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Demonstrators protesting against the constitutional referendum allegedly took the Minister of Public Works hostage for nearly 5 hours before releasing him.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: According to Reporters Without Borders, a journalist was abducted by men in uniform after being repeatedly threatened by the Pointe Noire police. After escaping he has continued to be threatened with kidnapping and death by the local authorities.

Demonstrators supporting the ""yes"" side of the constitutional referendum to allow President Sassou to have another term staged a peaceful protests in another part of Brazzaville while opposition activists clashed with police.

column7: FROCAD: Front for the Constitutional Order and Democratic Change
column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column16: AFP; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); Radio Okapi
column17: Clashes were reported between police and youths in the southwest district of Brazzaville. The youths erected barricades and burned tires to block traffic. 18 ""members of the opposition"" were also arrested, with police alleging that they caught them trying to make molotov cocktails. Among the 18 were 6 leaders of the Congolese opposition, including of FROCAD.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: 2 men set fire to a market in the Ouenze district of Brazzaville, but it was stopped and they were arrested before it could spread. They were allegedly paid to do so, and it is believed there may have been a political motive.

Students from the ENS and NPHS schools prevented the holding of courses to protest the killing of a Congolese student by a foreign student earlier in the week. The demonstrators vandalized buildings and attempted to burn the Faculty of Letters.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column9: FROCAD: Front for the Constitutional Order and Democratic Change; UDC: Union for Congolese Democracy
column17: Arrests: At least 100 young people were arrested between Dec.18-21 by Congolese police, allegedly to intimidate protesters ahead of elections, although the police have said the raids were to ensure security during new years celebration. The people targeted included UDC and Frocad activists.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: A dozen journalists were beaten at the Maya-Maya airport in Brazzaville by the police. They were awaiting the arrival of General Mokoko who has recently announced his candidacy for the early presidential vote in March.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Military helicopters allegedly bombed Soumouna village, near Kinkale, including the HQ of former Ninjas Nsiloulou leader Pastor Ntoumi, with no reports of casualties, after violence in Brazzaville on Apr.4. A second attack was reported the next day. The BBC also reported that further attacks had been carried out against Ntoumis village in the area, killing the whole population based on a Facebook post, but this could not be confirmed.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column9: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column16: AFP; AP; Xinhua; Deutsche Welle; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)
column17: Ninja Nsiloulou militiamen allegedly infiltrated Brazzaville and attacked a military position in Mayanga and the central police station of Djoue, as well as the police stations of the Bacongo, Makelekele, Lemina and Kinsoudi neighbourhoods, all in the southern areas said to be loyal to the opposition. These police stations were burned, along with many buildings in the Makelekele area, including the mayors office. Gun battles between the militiamen and police/military involving heavy and automatic weapons were reported. There were implications that the attacks were related to the recent presidential election, but no proof was provided. The government also accused the militiamen of committing ""various atrocities on civilians"". In total, 17 people, including 3 police, 2 civilians and 12 militiamen, were killed in the fighting, while 6 police were injured. At least 55 alleged Ninja militiamen were arrested.

column7: MCDDI: Congolese Movement for Democracy and Integral Development
column17: President Sassou was re-elected during the Republic of Congos 2016 presidential election. The election occurred on Mar.20, and Sassou was confirmed as the winner on Mar.24. The constitutional court of RoC validated the results on Apr.4, confirmining President Sassous re-election. The results resulted in protests and are believed to have motivated attacks by Ninja militias on Apr.4. Upon hearing the poll, opposition supporters erected roadblocks in Makelekele

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Military helicopters allegedly bombed Soumouna village, near Kinkale, including the HQ of former Ninjas Nsiloulou leader Pastor Ntoumi, with no reports of casualties, after violence in Brazzaville on Apr.4. A second attack was reported the next day. The BBC also reported that further attacks had been carried out against Ntoumis village in the area, killing the whole population based on a Facebook post, but this could not be confirmed.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Military helicopters allegedly fired on buildings in the Mayama area that former rebel leader Pastor Ntoumi had established. Clashes were also reported between the Ninjas militia and the military.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column9: Teachers (Republic of Congo); Students (Republic of Congo)
column17: Vindza, a previous area of residence for former leader of the Ninjas militia Pastor Ntoumi, was allegedly struck by military helicopters. A resident claimed he saw ""40 shells fall early in the morning mainly on schools and houses"" with the residents fleeing the area. No casualties were reported. Vindza was attacked on either Apr.6 or 7.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Soumouna, near Kinkale, and Mayama were reportedly struck by helicopters again on Apr.6. Although some witnesses said casualties had occurred, most reports seemed skeptical.

column6: Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Security Measures: President Sassou dismissed former leader of the Ninja militia Pastor Ntoumi (Fredereic Ntoumi Bintsamou) from his post as General Delegate to the President of the Republic, following an alleged Ninja attack on Brazzaville and military assaults on areas believed to be loyal to Pastor Ntoumi in Pool region.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Soumouna, near Kinkale, and Mayama were reportedly struck by helicopters again on Apr.6. Although some witnesses said casualties had occurred, most reports seemed skeptical.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Military helicopters were reported to have again attacked several localities in Pool region which are seen as loyal to former leader of the Ninja militia Pastor Ntoumi. Soumouna, near Kinkale, Mayama and Vindza have been hit, some more than once, in recent days. Although some witnesses said casualties had occurred, most reports seemed skeptical.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Military helicopters were reported to have again attacked several localities in Pool region which are seen as loyal to former leader of the Ninja militia Pastor Ntoumi. Soumouna, near Kinkale, Mayama and Vindza have been hit, some more than once, in recent days. Although some witnesses said casualties had occurred, most reports seemed skeptical.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Military helicopters were reported to have again attacked several localities in Pool region which are seen as loyal to former leader of the Ninja militia Pastor Ntoumi. Soumouna, near Kinkale, Mayama and Vindza have been hit, some more than once, in recent days. Although some witnesses said casualties had occurred, most reports seemed skeptical.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: ""Intense shelling"" has again been reported in Soumouna (near Kinkale) as well as ""other areas"" in the Pool region. No specific casualties were reported, and it was not clear what was being targeted.

Property destruction: 9 vehicles, including taxis and trucks, were set on fire by alleged Ninja militiamen between Mayama and Kindamba. The owners were reported to have been forced to leave their vehicles while being threatened with guns.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Non-violent activity: A large police presence has been reported outside the homes of three main opposition leaders (and failed presidential candidates) following expected protests against President Sassous re-election. The protest was cancelled due to this action.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: A group of police and military police clashed in the Talangai area of Brazzaville after the military police unit attempted to arrest a police officer for ""improper conduct on a motorcycle"". The police officer called on his colleagues and the dispute resulted in a gunfight. Some injuries were reported.

column8: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Gunfire and shelling allegedly took place in the Pool region in which military forces have been operating recently allegedly against Ninjas militia, although few details were given in the report.

After a group of knife-wielding assailants attacked a man, residents of the Nzoko area of Brazzaville came to his aid and fought off the assailants. The brawl was dispersed by police who fired tear gas.

column8: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Agreement: One of the main leaders of the former Ninja militia, Augustin Bassoumba, has surrendered to Congolese authorities along with his family.

After a train service between Brazzaville and Pointe-Norie was cancelled, angry travelers demonstrated in front of the station to demand either information or their money back. Police were present during the incident.
Property destruction: Suspected Ninjas militia members burned some trucks in the Pool region.

Nsiloulou Ninjas militiamen have allegedly carried out a large number of crimes in the Pool area since their attack on the capital in March, including rapes, thefts, robberies, killings (unknown fatalities).

column6: OCR: Rally of the Congolese Opposition
column17: Ten political parties, including the PR, DDC, CAR and others have created in Brazzaville a new opposition coalition named the Rally for the Congolese Opposition (OCR).

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column7: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Movement of forces: Opposition forces claimed that military and police forces have been deployed in the Pool region near Mayama, the home of an opposition leader. This follows activities in the area considered a support base for the opposition after violence following President Sassous re-election.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: 2 police officers were killed by suspected Nsiloulou Ninjas militiamen in Mindouli.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: 23 people have been killed by Ninjas militiamen in the Pool area according to the Congolese Minister for Justice and Human Rights. Those killed include 6 soldiers, 4 police, 2 gendarmes, and 11 civilians (20 coded in other events).

column16: Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); Xinhua
column17: Nsiloulou Ninjas militiamen attacked an a bus in Kinkala district, causing 3 injuries and destroying the vehicle.

column8: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: 2 soldiers were killed in a clash with Ninjas militiamen in the Mangola area of Pool as they were guarding a Chinese road construction site.

column8: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column16: AFP; Xinhua; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)
column17: After Nsiloulou Ninjas attacked a bus in the Kinkala area, they attacked an ambulance which came to take away the victims of the first attack and destroyed the vehicle. The driver, another civilian and 2 Congolese soldier were killed in the attack, while 4 others were injured, one seriously.

column9: IDC: Initiative For Democracy in Congo
column17: Congolese opposition figure Augustin Kala Kala, a close associate of the IDCs most recent presidential candidate, was kidnapped. He was later released on Oct.13 with serious injuries. It was not clear who the culprits were.

column8: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column9: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column16: Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo); Xinhua
column17: At least 14 people were killed, primarily military, police, gendarmerie personnel but also including a driver, in an attack by suspected Ninjas militiamen on a freight train near the Mindouli train station. The train was bound for Kinkembo.

column8: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Hundreds of people have fled alleged attacks against civilians and military targets in the Kinkala area of Pool by Ninjas militiamen. No casualties were reported.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Suspected Ninjas militiamen clashed with police on the Mindouli-Kinkala axis, injuring one person seriously.
Property destruction: Suspected Ninjas militiamen ambushed a convoy of vehicles in the Ngandou area, between Mindouli and Mayama. 3 vehicles were burned, although no casualties were reported.

About 300 people have marched in the Republic of Congos capital to demand that the country leave the International Criminal Court. Thursdays march comes shortly after three African countries, South Africa, Gambia and Burundi, announced they would leave the tribunal.
A transport vehicle traveling from Brazzaville to Kindamba was torched by suspected Ninjas militiamen. At least one passenger was assaulted by the militiamen before the vehicle was burned.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column9: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-) Prison Guards
column17: 3 people, including a police officer, were killed and 4 injured in a shooting at a prison in Brazzaville. The incident was described variously as a prison riot and/or an escape attempt.

column9: IDC: Initiative For Democracy in Congo
column17: Arrests: A former presidential candidate and president of the IDC party, Andre Okombi Salissa, was arrested in Brazzaville for ""endangering the internal security of the state"".

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: A Republic of Congo police spokesman claimed that at least 15 suspected Ninjas Nsiloulou militants have been killed in a recent operation by Congolese security forces in the Pool region.
A protest was held outside the HQ of Equatorial Congo Airlines in Brazzaville over the alleged mismanagement of the state airline.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Republic of Congo police forces claim to have dislodged alleged Ninjas Nisloulou rebels from Mpi village in Pool. The rebels left behind supplies, weapons and dependents. No injuries reported.
On 5 April, villagers in Ogooue in Zanaga district in Lekoumou demonstrated for the departure of the sub-prefect. Reports of property destruction by youth who broke a bridge.

column8: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: An army position in the Pool region was attacked by Ninjas-Nsiloulous militiamen in the Herilla area of Mayama locality, causing a number of injuries and deaths among the soldiers (unknown fatalities).
Ninja Nsiloulous attacked buses travelling from Brazzaville to Pointe Noire. Women on the buses were raped and 3 passengers were killed, including an off-duty policemen.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: There was a demonstration in Brazzaville to call for a end to the violence in Pool and for the release of political prisoners. The police dispersed the protesters and arrested 10 people.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: People held a sit-in outside Colonel Tsenzele's residence, near the Mpila barracks, to protest the killing of a local youth. The police used baton sticks to disperse the protesters. No reported injury.
The citizen movement, Ras-le-Bol held a peaceful demonstration outside the University Hospital in Brazzaville, following a report detailing abuses and dysfunctions in the hospital.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: TOTAL workers demonstrated against the economic treatement: the demonstration was broken up with teargas.

column6: Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Agreement: The Congolese Government has offered an amnesty to rebel groups operating in the Pool region.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Students at high schools in Brazzaville have been rioting and causing violence. The police responded strongly.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Supporters of Claudine Munari held a peaceful demonstration at the Moungali roundabout in Brazzaville, demanding the liberation of political prisoners. They were dispersed by the police using teargas.

column6: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Journalists in Brazzaville came to meet with the lawyers of a prisoner, but were arrested and beaten by security forces wearing civilian clothes at the HQ of The African Week. Shots and injuries were sustained.

column17: Lawyers in Congo Brazzaville gathered at the Poointe Noire Bar in solidarity with a colleague who had been arrested earlier in the week. The police broke up the meeting.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: On 18 January, students clashed with police officers who used tear gas after the funeral of a student from their college in Dolisie. Several students were arrested.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-) Prison Guards
column17: On 16 February, a journalist was abducted from a Brazzaville clinic where he was hospitalised. He was reported to have been taken by the director of the Brazzaville prison.

On 3 March, a march was held by the Congolese Wildlife and Protected Areas Agency (ACFAP) in Brazzaville to oppose poachers and raise awareness of challenges for wildlife.

column6: Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Agreement: on 7 March, the Ministry of Interior released four prisoners of the Ninja militia close to Pastor Ntumi as part of the peace agreement and cease-fire in December 2017.

Looting: On the night of 8-9 March, the HQ of the Meeting for Peace and Human Rights (RPDH) in Pointe-Noire were broken into by an unidentified group who took equipment selectively, indicating a political motive.
On 18 March, an elderly man accused of witchcraft was burned alive in front of a crowd in Banda, Niari.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: A student union leader was tortured in a police station in Congo. He was beaten with sticks and had plastic burned on his back. No exact date provided (dated to source).

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column16: RFI; Depeches de Brazzaville (Republic of Congo)
column17: On the night of 22 to 23 July, in Brazzaville, 13 people died inside the Chacona police station in Mpila. The Congolese Observatory of Human Rights claims to have collected several testimonies claiming that they died at the police station after police violence. Other reports suggest they died after clashes involving the ""black babies"" armed group.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: In the night between 22-23 July, sixteen people were arrested after the death of a man in their neighbourhood in Brazzaville and 13 of them were tortured to death. The government admitted the police responsibility soon after.

column6: Government of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: Weapons seizure: on August 29, the Republic of Congo Government launched a national operation aimed at collecting weapons used during the civil war of 2016 by the Ninja Militia. A few days after the operation started, hundreds of weapons had already been collected in the district of Vindza and nearly 2,000 nationwide, out of the expected three thousand.

column8: Military Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-) Gendarmerie
column17: 22 December. Following the death of a college student in Gendarmerie custody, students ransacked university offices before marching to the Gendarmerie with the body of the deceased. The demonstrators barricaded roads and burned tires. The Gendarmerie dispersed the demonstrators by with tear gas and by firing into the air. Two people were wounded by gun shots.

column6: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: 06 February. A police officer assaulted a three year-old child, beating him against a tree in the Bacougni neighborhood of Dolisie. Locals and other police officers intervened.

column9: Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo (2019-)
column17: 08 February. Citizens of the DRC residing in Brazzaville besieged the DRC embassy claiming they were owed payments from the ambassador.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)

28 - 30 March 2019. Amid rising tensions between Angola and the Republic of Congo, Angolan military forces reportedly crossed the border into the forest areas near the Illou-Panga villages, in the Kimongo district. The deployment of Angolan forces at the border and into Congolese territory caused some of the local population to flee the area.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: 17 April 2019 (on or before). Students at Marien Ngouabi University demonstrated, calling for scholarship arrear payments. Police intervened and dispersed the demonstrators. [size=no report]

column9: Women (Democratic Republic of Congo); Farmers (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: In July 2019, military forces of Angola reportedly raped an unspecified number of DRC women working in the fields in Kimongo (Niari) in Republic of Congo.

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: On 16 July, in Brazzaville, police intervened during a protest of STPU (Public Transport Company) workers. Police forced journalists to erase the images and footage. [size=no report]

On 9 September, in Brazzaville, around 500 judges protested in front of Ministry of Justice, demanding unlock of the urgent budget for public service. [size=500]

On 11 October, in Kimongo, unspecified number of residents blocked the main road with barricades in protest of poor condition of the road that led to frequent accidents. Barricades were removable and no violence occurred. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: On 25 December 2019, a civilian and a policeman were killed during an arrest in Odziba, south of Congo. Two other people were injured. The policeman was then killed by the population who was very angry and who also burnt the police office.

As reported on 10 February 2020, 1200 former workers of La Poste staged an ongoing protest in Brazzaville requesting for the payment of their retirement that they would not have received in the last 11 years. [size=1200]
On 11 February 2020, Gabonese gendarmes tortured civilians and looted their houses near Moungoundou-Nord and Pana border villages (Moutamba, Niari).
On 8 March 2020, women and men demonstrated in commemoration of International Women's day near Hinda (Kouilou). [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: On 18 August 2020, a group of local residents barricaded the road with burning tires in Brazzaville city, to resist an eviction operation by the local authorities. The police intervened and disperse the group using teargas. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: On 19 August 2020, a group of local residents barricaded the road with burning tires in Brazzaville for the second straight day to resist an eviction operation by the local authorities. The police intervened and disperse the group using teargas. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Republic of Congo (1997-)
column17: On 29 September 2020, a group of local people vandalized several public buildings including a police station and a public market in Nkayi city (Nkayi, Bouenza). They looted and torched these buildings in reaction to the killing of a woman by a policeman after she had refused to wear a face mask. The state forces, outnumbered, fled the village. Wearing face mask was declared mandatory due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 1 October 2020, a group of assistant teachers (called voluntary teachers) demonstrated in Brazzaville (Brazzaville, Brazzaville) to show their outrage and claim their unpaid salaries of the last 8 months. [size=no report]

On 2 October 2020, a group of local people demonstrated in Nkayi city (Nkayi, Bouenza) to show their refusal to wear face mask. They burned face masks in front of the police in reaction to the killing of a woman by a policeman early that week following a dispute because she had refused to wear a face mask. Wearing face mask was declared mandatory due to the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]
On 21 October 2020, a group of local people killed 1 man in Brazzaville (Brazzaville, Brazzaville). He was accused of being a thief. [size=no report]

column17: Systematic sexual violence continues to be carried out against Congolese women and girls caught up in mass expulsions from Angola to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, a United Nations envoy said on Friday. Community leaders recorded 182 reported rapes in seven villages along the border in January alone, while a UN assessment mission confirmed 1 357 reported rape cases in one village in a six-to-eight-month pe riod last year, said an official. Investigation confirms that violence took place in detention facilitites on both sides of the border.
